Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

At its meeting of 25 August 1988, the Committee considered Civil Aviation Regulations being Statutory Rules 1988 No. 158 and tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee draws the following matters to your attention.

Firstly, in relation to the notification of decisions made under, for example, Regulations 26 (4), 44 (2), 45 (2), 85 and 281 (4) the provisions state that notification of decisions can be served by post on the person or otherwise brought to his or her attention. This latter phrase is unfamiliar to the Committee and the Committee believes that it could lead to considerable problems and potential disputes about proof. The Committee seeks your guidance concerning this phrase and queries whether any criteria have been devised to ensure that the rights of the person receiving notification in this form are being protected.

Secondly, in many of these Regulations there are acts to be carried out by ``an authorised person''. (See, for example, Regulations 2 (1), 30 (4), 33 (2), 35, 36, 38 (5), 47 (1), (3) and (4), 48 (3), 49, 53 (1) and (3), 54 (3), 227, 302 and 305.) The Committee is concerned that there are no provisions requiring ``an authorised person'' to carry and produce appropriate proof of identity.

Where it is merely ``an authorised person'' acting on behalf of the Civil Aviation Authority to give written approvals in an office it may not create too much difficulty. However, where ``an authorised person'' comes on to maintenance areas to inspect (Regulation 30 (4)), or seeks admission to an aircrew compartment (Regulation 227 (3)), or seeks access to an aerodrome or aircraft (Regulation 305), there is potential for very considerable danger of sabotage or harm arising from the entry of an imposter. The Committee believes that, in such cases, proper identity cards should be issued and required to be shown before the authorised person has access to such areas.

Thirdly, in Regulation 298, a reference is made to ``the approved form'' and in Regulation 2 (1) the Committee notes that ``approved'' means ``approved by the Authority''. The Committee is concerned that, as such approval forms may include substantial and important documents, there does not appear to be any provision in the regulations which subjects these ``forms'' to Parliamentary scrutiny.
Your comments and advice in relation to these matters will be welcomed by the Committee.
Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
I refer to the letter of 30 August 1988, addressed to Senator Evans, concerning the Committee's scrutiny of the Civil Aviation Regulations, being Statutory Rules 1988, No. 158.

You have queried the fact that various notifications under the Regulations may be served on a person by post or otherwise brought to his or her attention. The normal method of serving the notices is by post. However, at times a written notice is personally served on the person or the person's agent. In rare instances a written notice may be prominently attached to an unairworthy aircraft because of the impossibility of effecting service in any other way. This practice complies with the spirit of sections 28A and 29 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and has so far been considered an adequate way of serving notifications or directions in all manner of practical situations.

It is important that the flexibility of such arrangements be retained. However, if the Committee continues to have doubts about the wording, I would be happy to bring forward in due course further Statutory Rules that would describe the various methods of service. An example of such description is in the Air Navigation Regulations where subregulation 215B (3), as remade by Statutory Rules 1988 No. 159, provides for service by the methods described above.

You also queried identification of authorised persons. As a matter of practice, identification is carried and produced by an officer of the Civil Aviation Authority who is appointed an authorised person and is carrying out activities related to such appointment away from the Authority's premises.

A second category of authorised persons is that within the industry, consisting of persons who are appointed to enable them to give particular approvals. Such persons are supplied with instruments of appointment to verify their authority. In most instances the person is readily identifiable because of the position held in a firm or other organisation performing maintenance or testing work.

I am sympathetic to your concern that all authorised persons should, ideally, be required to carry proof of identification. Accordingly, I shall arrange for the drafting of Statutory Rules aimed at tightening the provisions currently under consideration.

The phrase ``in the approved form'' in Regulation 298 has been taken as referring to classes of information, such as experience and qualifications, which an applicant for a licence should provide. The regulation has not been used as the basis for design of a form to be completed by applicants.
I refer to your letter of 1 November 1988 concerning the Committee's examination of Civil Aviation Regulations being Statutory Rules 1988, No. 158.
The Committee accepts your offer to bring forward further Statutory Rules to describe the various methods of service of notifications.

The Committee similarly accepts your undertaking to arrange for Statutory rules to tighten the provisions regarding all authorised persons being required to carry proof of identification. The Committee assumes that these provisions will cover both categories of authorised persons mentioned in your letter.

Your advice with respect to r.298 is welcomed. Should the regulation be used in the future as the basis for design of a form, however, then the Committee considers the form should be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.
The Committee thanks you for your co-operation.

At its meeting of 25 August 1988, the Committee considered Air Navigation Regulations (Amendment), being Statutory Rules 1988 No. 159 and tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee draws the following matters to your attention.

Regulation 13 of the amending Regulations inserts into the Principal Regulation new Regulations 191 to 197. Within these provisions are contained a number of discretions which are vested in the Secretary, for example, the issue of licences (Regulation 191), approval of flights (Regulation 192), form and consolidation of licences (Regulation 193), duration, renewal and review of licences (Regulation 194), cancellation or suspension of licences (Regulation 195) and contracts and arrangements for non-licence holders to allow another to operate their services (Regulation 196).

The Committee's concern is that, in dealing with these very important commercial matters and decisions, the Secretary's discretion does not appear to be subject to any review procedures. Part XV of the Principal Regulations use to confer appropriate review rights but with the repeal of that Part by Regulation 16 of these Regulations there appears to the Committee to be a gap in the Principal Regulations as they now stand. Your advice and assistance in relation to this important matter would be appreciated by the Committee.

Regulation 23 inserts new Regulation 315b, which relates to aircraft parking areas, into the Principal Regulations. This new provision also contains a number of discretionary decisions to be made by the Secretary. Again no apparent avenues of review exist in relation to this Regulation and the Committee also seeks your assistance and advice in relation to this matter.
Regulation 22 inserts new Regulation 315aa, which relates to the prohibition of the discharge of firearms at airports except by certain classes of persons, into the Principal Regulations.
``An authorised person may, for a purpose relating to aviation security, discharge a firearm upon or over any part of a Federal airport.''

The Committee's concern is that such an authorised person is not required to produce or wear any form of identification. While it is unlikely that anyone would challenge a person discharging a firearm at an aerodrome and demand an identity card, it would probably be sensible to require such an authorised person to have a proper identity card in the course of carrying out his or her duties.
Your comments in relation to these matters will be welcomed by the Committee.
I refer to the letter of 30 August 1988, addressed to Senator Evans, concerning the Air Navigation Regulations (Amendment), being Statutory Rules 1988, No. 159.

The licensing scheme provided for in regulations 191 to 197 is not new. The regime of control is precisely the same as before, but the provisions were recast by Attorney-General's Department when amendments to the Regulations were being drafted in relation to abandonment of the scheme of domestic air service licensing. I should also point out that the review scheme that existed before the amendments were made related only to personnel licences, by reason of former regulation 254.

The controls provided in respect of international air service operations are necessary to enable Australia to meet its obligations under both multilateral and bilateral agreements with other countries and to permit implementation of Government policy. As regards regular airline services, the matter is dealt with in accordance with agreements negotiated between countries. Charter operations are dealt with in accordance with policies decided from time to time that are well publicised. The current policies in relation to charter operations were tabled in the Senate on 7 October 1987. I therefore do not consider a review mechanism should be provided.

The powers provided by `new' regulation 315b are precisely the same as in the former regulation so designated, except there is reference in subregulation (2) to an aircraft left standing at a departmentally controlled aerodrome in contravention of the Civil Aviation Regulations. Previously, there was reference to an aircraft that was, without the permission of an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, left standing in an area of a departmentally controlled aerodrome other than a designated parking area.

I do not believe it is necessary to incorporate review rights in respect to decisions under regulation 315b. Such a review would be impracticable in regard to decisions relating to removal of an aircraft that was creating a safety hazard or inconveniencing users of the aerodrome, because speedy removal would be necessary. Decisions relating to designation of an aircraft parking area take account of safety and other operational considerations, as well as the possibility of damage to or excessive wear of assets, and need can arise for quick changes or for immediate consideration of a special case, such as in regard to a particular aircraft that has just arrived.
No authorisations have been or are proposed to be made in regard to subregulation 315aa (2). I intend to bring forward amendments to regulation 315aa as soon as possible.
Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support
I refer to your letter of 1 November 1988 in respect of the Committee's examination of Air Navigation Regulations (Amendment) being Statutory Rules 1988, No. 159.

The Committee is grateful for your advice with respect to its concerns. The Committee wishes to point out, however, that the fact that subordinate legislation may restate existing provisions does not foreclose examination by the Committee.
The Committee notes that you propose to bring forward amendments to r.315aa as soon as possible and assumes that these amendments will meet the concerns of the Committee regarding this regulation.

Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business

At its meeting of 1 August 1988, the Committee considered Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations (Amendment) being Statutory Rules 1988 No. 195 of 1988 and tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee draws the following matters to your attention.
These Regulations repeal redundant regulations and prevent the export of ships or aircraft without Ministerial consent. Subregulation 4 (2) and subregulation 7 (2) give the Minister a discretion to:
(i) impose conditions and requirements that have to be complied with; and
(ii) specify a time limit on those conditions.
The Explanatory Statement in relation to these discretions states:
``The discretion introduced by this technical amendment brings the provision into line with other similar provisions recently introduced into the Regulations.''

The Committee's concerns are twofold. Firstly, the Committee in its scrutiny of the Regulations has failed to find any reference to the ``similar provisions recently introduced into the Regulations''. The Committee seeks further assistance and information in relation to this explanation.

Secondly, the Committee seeks your advice in relation to possible avenues of appeal rights in relation to the exercise of Ministerial discretion. The Committee is concerned that the discretions are not subject to review or appeal on the merits of the Ministerial decision and as a result the rights of the holder of a consent may be placed in jeopardy.
I refer to your letter dated 1 September 1988 requesting advice on certain aspects of Statutory Rules 1988 No. 195. In particular, your Committee has sought clarification on two matters, as follows:
(i) Explanatory Statement-explanation relating to new sub-regulations 4 (2) and 7 (2)

Subregulations 4 (2) and 7 (2) provide the statutory basis for imposing conditions or requirements in a permission (ie. a consent or an approval) to export the goods the subject of export control under subregulations 4 (1) and 7 (1) respectively.

In relation to these provisions, the explanatory statement stated that they were technical amendments bringing the provisions into line with other similar permission controls recently introduced into the Regulations.

For the information of the Committee, Subregulation 13d (3), concerning the exportation of certain chemical compounds (introduced into the Regulations by Statutory Rules 1987 No. 97) and subregulation 6 (5), concerning the exportation of coffee (introduced into the Regulations by Statutory Rules 1988 No. 65) are recent examples of similar express provisions conferring a power to impose conditions in an export `permission'. Such a power is common in both the Customs (Prohibited Exports) and (Prohibited Imports) regimes, and it dates back to Statutory Rules 1984 No. 317, which inserted subregulation 4 (1a) into the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. This followed advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that where the regulations were silent as to the power to impose conditions in a permission, there was no such power. The facility to impose conditions in an export or import permission is seen as both an effective mechanism for controlling import and export prohibitions, and a more palatable option than a blanket prohibition on trade in a particular type of goods. Thus, since that date, this express condition making power has appeared in most prohibited import and export controls.
The Committee is concerned that not provision is made for independent review of the discretion to refuse to grant an export permission under both the abovementioned provisions.

The Committee's concern is well-taken. Indeed, the review question arises because of the fact that two items still remain subject to the control regime of the Schedules-ie, ships and aircraft respectively. With regard to ships, it is the Government's intention to restrict the export control over these goods to ships designed or adapted for military purposes, or of major military significance. This will be accommodated by the revision of the defence export control Schedule (Schedule 13), which was announced by the Minister for Defence on 14 June 1988, and is currently being drafted (a copy of the Minister's statement is attached for information). The announced revised Schedule 13 (Regulation 13b) control regime will prohibit the exportation of goods designed or adapted for military purposes (including ships) unless the permission of the Minister for Defence is first obtained. As denials of permission will be on defence and foreign policy grounds, it is not intended to make the Minister's discretion reviewable by the AAT. (This is similar to the position taken on dual-use technology goods in regulation 13e, and chemical precursors in regulation 13d.) However, as with those Regulations and other recent non-reviewable discretions, the decision-maker who might refuse an export-permission will be restricted to the Minister.

In so far as aircraft are concerned, the same control regime outlined above for `military' ships is proposed for `military' aircraft. The Government's policy on whether the exportation of civilian aircraft should remain subject to export control is currently being reviewed.

Pending the introduction of the revised Schedule 13, and so that the exportation of military ships and aircraft might still be controlled however, the existing control regime for ships and aircraft has been retained. While it is acknowledged the control regime at present can go beyond the desired class of military goods, in fact it will be administered (in so far as ships are concerned) only on the basis of controlling such ships, with denials of permissions being made only at Ministerial level.

In so far as aircraft are concerned, the status-quo of requiring an export permission from the Department of Transport and Communications for the exportation of any aircraft is to be continued. If review of the aircraft prohibition results in a continuing need to control non-military aircraft, the question of reviewability of that decision will then be dealt with, consistent with the practice adopted in all recent (Prohibited Export) and (Prohibited Import) Regulations.
I trust the above is of assistance to the Committee.
Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business
I refer to your letter of 20 October 1988 concerning the examination by the Committee of Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations (Amendment) being Statutory Rules 1988, No. 195.
The Committee is grateful for your advice on this matter which meets the concerns of the Committee.
Minister for Community Services and Health

At its meeting of 29 September 1988, the Committee considered Approval of Application Form APP3-A under sub-section 23dc (2) of the Health Insurance Act 1953; Approval of Application Form APA3-A under sub-section 23df (2) of the Health Insurance Act 1953 and tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee brings to your attention the following matters.
The Committee notes that on page 1 and subsequent pages of forms APP3-A and APA3-A the following comment appears:
`Please read Important Notes before completing this application.'

These `Important Notes' were not supplied to the Committee to assist it in its scrutiny of the relevant documents and the Committee seeks a copy of these notes for its information and scrutiny. The Committee further requests that, in the future, could any such additional information be supplied with the appropriate form.

The Committee also notes that there are a number of misprints in relation to form APA3-A. The front approving page refers to the `application form required by paragraph 23df (b) (sic) of the Act'. Section 23df contains a number of paragraph (b)s and the Committee seeks clarification as to whether the correct citation is paragraph 23df (1) (b). On pages 1, 2, 3 and 4 the word `proprierorship' (sic) appears in an incorrect form.
Question 9 on page 5 of form APP3-A is an example of a number of questions which appear in both the forms. It reads:
`9. After due enquiry, has any proprietor named in question 8 above, ever been:-
(a) convicted of a relevant offence pursuant to Section 23da (1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973, or the Crimes Act 1914, or
(b) the subject of an effective determination by a Medicare Participation Review Committee?'.

The Committee's concern relates to the use of the phrase `after due enquiry' which seems to indicate that the person and/or company that is required to fill in the relevant form may be forced to undertake an exhaustive investigation as to the bona fides of the person or persons involved. As there are serious consequences which flow from answering these questions inaccurately the Committee seeks your advice as to the degree of `due enquiry' that is actually required in answering these questions.
The Committee would welcome your views in relation to these matters.
Minister for Community Services and Health

I refer to your letter of 30 September 1988 conveying concerns the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has with regard to the content of application forms required to be lodged by persons seeking status as either an approved pathology practitioner (APP) or an approved pathology authority (APA) under the Health Insurance Act 1973 (`the Act'). I note that you have moved in the Senate on 18 October 1988 for the disallowance of both these forms.

You have firstly drawn attention to the fact that the Committee was not provided with a copy of the `Important Notes', a copy of which is provided to persons wishing to complete either of these forms. A copy of these `Important Notes' is attached for the Committee's consideration.

You have then drawn attention to two typographical errors-one in the application form itself (APA3-A) and one in the approval of that form by the Minister's delegate. I confirm that the term `proprierorship' should in fact read `proprietorship' and the reference in the approval of form APA3-A to `paragraph 23df (b)' should in fact read `paragraph 23df (1) (b)'.

You have finally expressed concern over the use, in both of the above forms, of the expression `after due enquiry' in questions asked of applicants. You cite question 9 in form APA3-A as an example of the type of question about which you are concerned. I offer the following comments in answer to your concern as to what exactly the expression is intended to mean.

When an application, appropriate fee, and an APP or APA undertaking are given to the Minister for acceptance of the undertaking, the Minister cannot accept the undertaking unless he is satisfied that the person giving it is a fit and proper person to be an APP or APA. In determining whether a person is a fit and proper person, the Minister must have regard to whether the person is associated with a `relevant person'.

The term `relevant person' is defined in sub-section 23da (1) of the Act. The definition includes persons who have been convicted of certain offences and persons who have been the subject of a determination made by a Medicare Participation Review Committee or a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry. It is for the purpose of establishing whether or not an applicant is, or has been, associated with a `relevant person', that the questions in the application forms, about which you are concerned, are asked.

It was appreciated, however, at the time these questions were framed that a person may not be aware that an associate is a `relevant person'. For this reason the Health Insurance Commission, in consultation with my Department, the Royal Australasian College of Pathologists and the Australian Medical Association, did not consider it appropriate for a person to be required to commit themselves to an unequivocal response. Hence the use of the expression `after due enquiry'.

It was intended and assumed if an applicant was aware that an associate was a person of the kind specified in the particular question (in other words, a `relevant person'), he or she would answer the question accordingly. If the applicant did not know that an associate was such a person, it was nevertheless considered that he or she should be required to make some enquiries in order to ascertain if this was the case. If an applicant had concerns or worries about any of these matters, he or she would always be able to seek clarification from, for instance, the Health Insurance Commission.

It was never intended that applicants should have to undertake an exhaustive investigation as to the bone fides of past or present associates. It was only ever intended that reasonable enquiries be made appropriate to the circumstances-and this is all that is, and will be, required of applicants. It was considered that the expression `after due enquiry' covered this situation and also addressed the earlier mentioned concern that applicants should not be required to give a unequivocal response.
Should the Committee think it desirable, I am prepared to arrange for an explanation of the expression `due enquiry' to be included in the abovementioned `Important Notes'.
I trust this information proves useful to the Committee in its deliberations.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1988 No. 83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 5 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of certain Australian Federal Police Regulations Statutory Rules 1988 No. 83. I seek leave to make a short statement by way of explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to regulation 25 (b) of the Australian Federal Police regulations has the effect of removing the rank of inspector and the rank of chief inspector of which there are approximately 140 from the prescribed ranks that are entitled to appeal against selection for promotion under regulation 26. Regulation 26 (1) (b) provides a general right of appeal to any person who considers that he or she has a `better claim' to promotion to a certain position than another member selected by the Commissioner for promotion. In such circumstances an aggrieved party may appeal to the Promotions Appeals Board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has put forward an alternative mechanism of appeal to the Merit Protection Review Agency. That appeal however is on much more narrow grounds. Contrary to its title, it is not an appeal on merit but rather whether in the selection process there was a breach of the Act or a serious defect in the selection process. Therefore, on its face, certain Federal Police officers were losing rights presently available. In the meantime what has been agreed to-I think at least in part as a result of the notice that was given in this chamber-is that a new internal grievance review panel be established which will enable an examination of matters relating to the methodology of the selection process or in other words to test the promotions assessment procedure. This is regarded as a reasonable compromise by all concerned. I have therefore withdrawn the notice.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last day of sitting, Thursday, 10 November 1988, Senator Chaney asked me to consider, in the context of relevant resolutions of the Senate, certain remarks made in debate by the Minister for Finance concerning certain private citizens in Western Australia. The Standing Orders of the Senate confer no protection on private individuals in respect of remarks made about them by senators in debate. On that basis I ruled against a point of order which was taken when Senator Walsh was answering a question in relation to the proposed gold companies tax. In his answer, subsequent to that ruling, Senator Walsh named certain individuals and attributed disreputable characteristics to them.

INTERJECT.PARA: On 22 February this year, the Senate passed certain resolutions relating to matters of parliamentary privilege, including two resolutions concerning statements made in debate about private citizens. One resolution, resolution No. 5, provides a procedure whereby persons aggrieved by remarks made about them in debate may seek to have a response incorporated in the parliamentary record. The first step in this procedure is a submission to the President. The other relevant resolution, resolution No. 9, enjoins senators to exercise their freedom of speech in a responsible manner and to take into account the rights of others and the damage which may be done by allegations concerning individuals. That resolution also allows me to draw its provisions to the attention of the Senate when I consider that it is desirable to do so.

Having considered Senator Chaney's comments, and the remarks in question by Senator Walsh, I think that I ought to draw the attention of all senators to resolution No. 9 and to the responsibility which senators have to exercise their freedom of speech in a responsible manner, and to indicate that I will consider carefully any submission made to me under resolution No. 5. I have received a complaint from one of the people named and I am considering the correspondence at the present time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I welcome the fact, Mr President, that you have drawn the attention of the Senate to resolution No. 9 and to the responsibility that senators have to exercise their freedom of speech in a responsible manner. I might have enjoyed the statement more had you drawn the attention specifically of Senator Walsh to resolution No. 9, but I watched him carefully during the statement and he did not seem to flinch or colour or be overcome or mortified by the admonition. Indeed, I heard him repeat the allegation as he came to his place as you were starting to speak. I suspect the problem is not one that has been solved by your statement.

Mr President, I also welcome the fact that you have given a public indication that you will consider carefully any submission made to you under resolution No. 5, which does give aggrieved individuals a chance to have a statement made in this place if they believe their position has been misrepresented. I made the point when I drew your attention to this matter that in the case of one of the individuals named by Senator Walsh it appeared that he had mixed up two individuals of the same name, one of whom was in the mining industry and the other not--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are both in the tax bludging rort and one has been in the slammer.

—The repeated insults by the Minister simply underline the point of concern that I was expressing in a very gentle manner; namely, that your admonition in your statement is at a level where it is certainly not going, I suspect, to change Senator Walsh's habits. I simply draw your attention to the fact that he has again repeated the defamation in the guise of an interjection. Mr President, I await your advice as to whether you hear further from the people who have been defamed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, left on 16 November on Government business overseas. He will return to Australia on 7 December. In his absence the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, is the Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's address to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) on Friday about the Government's intention to seek a further cut in the fiscal position of the States next year. In the light of our continuing balance of payments and inflation problems, and given that Commonwealth general revenue assistance to the States is estimated to fall by 5 1/2 per cent in real terms this year, is the Government proposing a similar reduction next year? Why does the Government continue to have two standards, one for the States and one for itself, given that its own outlays are expected to decline by only 1.8 per cent this year, compared with the 5 per cent cut in financial assistance to the States? In the light of the Treasurer's address to EPAC, in which he said, `For its part the Commonwealth will further restrain its own outlays in 1989-90', has the Government finally accepted the need for proper fiscal restraint? Will it cut its own outlays next year, to the same extent as any cuts to the States, to help solve some of Australia's continuing and more pressing economic problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes an enormous amount of chutzpah for someone who was a member of the Fraser-Howard Government to talk about proper fiscal restraint and in particular to throw it at this Government which, even in this year, has outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) down to a lower level that they were in any of the seven years of the Fraser-Howard regime, and when, as the Treasurer and I have just announced today, on a no policy change assumption outlays will fall again in real terms next year to 24.7 per cent of GDP which, once adjusted for the Medicare changes, will be the lowest level of outlays since 1972-73.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not read the Treasurer's speech. However, I understood from press reports that the real point that he was making is that States as well have a responsibility to exercise tight control over their spendings and borrowings. The fact is that in 1986, in what are now called financial assistance grants, the States received a 2 per cent increase in real terms over the amount received the previous year. In retrospect, I believe that grants to the States in that year were excessively generous, particularly in view of the fact that the great majority of State government expenditure is wages expenditure, and real wages, particularly in the public sector, were at that time falling and had fallen in the previous couple of years. If Senator Messner wants to be critical, one can certainly make the case that the Commonwealth should have been harder on the States in 1986.

We are now in our third year of declining real outlays and looking at a fourth year, as the Forward Estimates published today have shown. There is absolutely no precedent in Australian post-World War II history, or I believe in the post-World War II history of any comparable nation, of any other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development country showing expenditure restraint of that magnitude. In the seven years that the Fraser-Howard regime ruled the roost, it did bring down real outlays in one year, but in all of the other six they went up. Senator Messner may also remember that there are two sides to a responsible fiscal policy: one is the outlays side and the other is the revenue side. Of course, we know that when his Party was last in government, in particular in its final year, it was irresponsible on both counts, to the point that it left us with a prospective deficit of almost $10 billion, as Senator Stone was kind enough to point out at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether the answer to my question is yes, that his restraint in the coming financial year will be equal to that which he is going to apply to the States.
—I have nothing to add.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Le Monde newspaper, published in Paris, which claims that Australian diplomacy has had setbacks in island countries of the South Pacific? Does Australia play the role of `regional policeman' as claimed in the French newspaper? Is France poised to step into a breach between Australia and these countries, as claimed in the Paris press report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Claims of the kind to which Senator Maguire refers, that Australian diplomacy has had setbacks among the island countries of the South Pacific, are not new, including in this place I hasten to add. As I said in a recent speech, there may have been occasions on which criticism of Government policy in the region has been deserved. But claims of declined and declining Australian influence suggest a view of the fragility of Australian influence and interest in the region which is clearly nonsensical.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia does not aspire to the role of regional policeman which was identified for us in the Le Monde article. It would be entirely contrary to the policy of constructive commitment which I outlined in the speech referred to. The policy is based on respect for the full sovereignty of all Pacific island states, promotion of close confident bilateral relations on a foundation of effective regional cooperation, shared perceptions of the security interests of the region and recognising that the Pacific island countries' security hinges on economic and social development. They are all the elements of that particular policy which has been spelt out and they are at the opposite end of the spectrum, and are expressly stated to be such, from the notion of a policeman's role which seems to have been identified for us.

On the specific questions of New Caledonia, which I suppose, underlays the article, it has to be said that as a consequence of the change of policy by France in relation to New Caledonia, a change which the Australian Government believes will contribute very much to the stability of the region, it is the case that relations between France and Pacific island countries have begun to improve. Our reaction to that is very much to welcome it because, as we have consistently acknowledged, France has a valuable role to play itself in the economic, cultural and social development of the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs seen the recent press reports and, in particular, an article in the Melbourne Sun newspaper which suggest, firstly, that the Minister is adopting the same line as the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in his response to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies; secondly, that he has had several meetings with the Prime Minister about the issue and they are at `loggerheads'; and, thirdly, that he is anti-kinship reunion and this view is reflected in the new immigration proposals? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether these articles are a true reflection of his and the Government's attitude? Given that the workshops to discuss the draft agenda for a multicultural Australia are currently proceeding, is the Minister concerned that misinformation could be needlessly worrying, let alone misleading, for all those seriously addressing these issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time one does read press reports about what one is supposed to be doing in a particular policy area. They are normally occasions for amusement as they are so inaccurate. In this case, I would not say I was so much amused as enraged by the stupidity of the article concerned. There is absolutely no substance to the allegation that I am adopting the same immigration policy as John Howard. I would regard that as not only defamatory to myself but probably to John Howard as well. In terms of whether I have had any meetings with the Prime Minister, which was asserted in those articles, no, I have not. I have not had any discussions with the Prime Minister on this matter in the last week, and nor am I likely to. That again is a fabrication on the part of the journalist who has been somewhat gullible in terms of sources. In answer to the third part of the question, on no occasion will I be anti-kinship reunion. I will always believe that family reunion must remain the largest component of any immigration policy.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the details in those articles, I am not going to respond today. I am not going to breach the normal proprieties of Cabinet rules. Submissions are drawn up and go to Cabinet and then they are announced in this chamber. Those proprieties will be followed this time. I just say that I am not responsible for the erratic articles that appear in the paper that, whilst not meant to be malicious, have that effect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On an Australian Broadcasting Corporation AM program earlier this month the Minister, in response to a question, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Bond arranges his company affairs in such a way that he obtains a number of concessions, which are available to gold miners and others, that is a matter I suppose of corporate strategy, which I don't find totally admirable.

Will or can the Minister confirm that the Bond Corporation paid corporate tax at a rate of less than 9 per cent in the 1986-87 financial year, falling to less than one per cent in the 1987-88 financial year? Is the Minister aware that Bond Corporation is already boasting that it will not pay corporate tax this financial year or in 1989-90? Does the Minister agree that our tax structure is inequitable if Bond Corporation pays less than 1c in the dollar tax on a profit of over $400m and a pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayer pays 40c on each $1 earned in excess of $19,500, while the interaction between the tax structure and the various social security cut-off points, creates effective tax rates of up to 120 per cent at the margins for some social security recipients? In view of this tax inequality, why do we have a Bill before us which cuts company tax rates while PAYE taxpayers and social security recipients continue to suffer high personal tax rates with, if statements from some Ministers are to be believed, no real relief in sight?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the last part of the question first. The Government has said repeatedly that there will be cuts in personal tax rates next calendar year, and there is no reason for any scepticism about that. With regard to cuts in company tax rates, yes, certainly that has happened. The burden of the honourable senator's question is not about company tax rates, it is about whether people are paying them, which is a different thing altogether.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to give any detailed answers about the taxation arrangements made by Mr Bond. I can inform the senator that, as I understand it, some of these arrangements were as a result of companies registered in the Cook Islands, which has been a tax haven. That tax haven was closed off in May of this year. Perhaps there will be a different pattern of payment of taxation in coming years as a result of that happening. In so far as the question seeks further detail, I will seek to obtain an answer and provide it to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES: REBATE FOR PATHOLOGY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware of a statement made by the New South Wales Minister for Health that a reduction in the rebate to pathologists for chlamydia, hepatitis B and other sexually transmitted diseases tests would have wide-ranging economic and health care consequences? How are such decisions made and has there been due consideration of how the necessary testing for these damaging diseases can be maintained if, as Mr Collins suggests, private pathologists refuse to perform such tests?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I understand that the purport of Standing Orders is that matters which are currently for debate by the chamber are not matters on which questions can be addressed to Ministers at Question Time. We are part way through a debate on a disallowance motion dealing with pathology schedules and testings, a procedure which has been part heard, deferred at the Government's request, and is to be brought back on for debate later this week. I ask whether, in fact, it is in accordance with the Standing Orders for questions to be asked dealing with that matter which is currently for debate by the chamber.

—I do not think the question is anticipating the debate. Therefore, I think it is in order. A very strict application of that standing order would mean a lot of questions ruled out of order. I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I appreciate the point of order taken by Senator Puplick because debate on this matter has been deferred by common agreement across the chamber. I acknowledge the way in which that was made. I do not propose in my answer to do anything that will reflect on that debate. I am sure that if I do Senator Puplick will rightly be the first on his feet to draw my attention to that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Giles asked whether I am aware of a report in a newspaper. I am aware of a report headed `Medicare rebate cuts hit' by Jenni Cooper, I think in the Australian of today. That article refers to a reduction in schedule fees and rebates for pathology tests for sexually transmitted diseases. A new pathology table was introduced on 1 November following a recommendation from the Pathology Services Advisory Committee (PSAC). The PSAC is an independent body which includes representatives of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia and the Australian Medical Association. It is chaired by a deputy president of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The new table is designed to stop overservicing. This is obviously in the area of the matter we will debate. It is also designed to have the schedule fees more accurately reflect the cost of doing various tests.

The press report incorrectly claims that the fee for a chlamydia test will be reduced from $17.20 to $9. Under the old schedule the appropriate item for a chlamydia test had a schedule fee of $12.20. It is unlikely that chlamydia tests would be done at a financial loss as the reagents for the test cost only about $3.50, out of a schedule fee of $9.

The Federal Government agrees with Health Minister Collins from New South Wales that chlamydia testing is important and commends the New South Wales Government and various medical groups on the planned chlamydia control program. The Federal Government notes the suggestion that we should consider alternative methods of funding these tests. We would be happy to consider funding through the public hospital system if that is what Mr Collins wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care whether it is a fact that in just the last four years, excluding the impact of the most recent increases, average monthly home loan repayments have risen by 82 per cent in New South Wales, 75 per cent in Victoria, 62 per cent in Tasmania, 58 per cent in Western Australia, 44 per cent in South Australia, and 41 per cent in Queensland. Does the Minister agree that many couples are now being forced to delay having children for up to 10 to 15 years in order to save to qualify for a home loan and that Australians are having to make a choice between having a family and a home of their own? What prospect of relief can the Government offer the hundreds of thousands of Australian home buyers who are now being further squeezed by high interest rates following this Government's economic mismanagement?

—The honourable senator raises a number of estimates which she puts forward as accurate calculations regarding repayment increases resulting from increases in interest rates. She then goes on to suggest that somehow or other this is curbing the planning for family growth in Australia. I want to suggest that that is a long bow.
—You are a bit out of touch.

—This is an emotionally charged appeal to the heartstrings which is frankly quite disgusting. Interest rates, as Senator Patterson would know, are a matter for the Treasurer. I can inform her, however, that there is a large amount of finance available for housing. Secured housing finance commitments in August 1988 were 52 per cent higher than in August 1987. Plentiful finance and continued strong demand for housing should keep the industry buoyant throughout 1988 and 1989. We had record dwelling commencements in the June quarter of 1988. According to the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, dwelling commencements during 1988-89 are expected to be between 158,000 and 162,000, a high level of activity by any measure. This will match the underlying demand in 1988-89, which is estimated at between 154,000 and 168,000.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. May I take it from the Minister's answer that he believes there is no connection between the cost of housing and the decision of young people as to whether to have a family?

—In some cases there may be a connection. I do not make the connection that Senator Patterson makes in what is frankly an emotionally charged ploy to try to pretend that what this Government is doing is discriminating against families. This Government's record in terms of assistance to families in Australia and its record on the provision of public housing is second to none. I am absolutely shocked that a party with the record the Liberal Party had under the Fraser Administration would even dare to raise such a question.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald in which it is reported that he wants to change the ratio of family and business migrants from the proportion recommended in the report of the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policy. Can the Minister confirm that this is the case? Is the Minister aware of statements claiming that the recent immigration debate within Australia has created a perception in many Asian countries that Australia discriminates against Asians on the grounds of race? Is this perception justified and is it harming Australia's business migration program and reducing the economic opportunities available to Australia in the region? Will the Minister, as one way of overcoming this perception, consider amending the Migration Act in a way which prohibits discrimination against prospective migrants on the grounds of race?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I had reason, in response to an earlier question, to criticise those headlines saying, `Ray is trying to cut back on family immigration'. Now we have in the Sydney Morning Herald the headline `Ray is cutting back on business migration and skilled migration'. It reminds me of a candidate we once had in the Latrobe Valley. The headline in the Morwell Mercury was `Murphy supports abortion'. In the Traralgon Tattler the headline was `Murphy opposes abortion'. When the television crew finally tracked him down he simply said, `I was misquoted', and walked away, so we never did find out what his attitude was.

ANSWER.PARA: I have read the article that Senator Dunn referred to. I will not respond in any detail. She will have to wait two or three weeks, until we can formally respond to the FitzGerald report, to see what ratio this Government believes is appropriate between the skills stream-the economic focus stream-and the family stream.

Senator Dunn went on to ask whether I was aware of statements claiming that the recent immigration debate in Australia had created a perception in certain Asian countries that we discriminate against Asians in terms of race. That is a perception that exists in Asia. It is one that for better or worse is believed in a variety of Asian countries. It does not take much to promote that belief, given our history prior to 1973, when quite clearly this country, almost in a proud way, discriminated against people from Asia.

As to whether that has gone on to harm our business migration program, I instinctively think, `Yes, it has', but at this stage I cannot measure the extent. There are lags in the system of three to 10 months for approval. The evidence from business migration agents, especially in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea, is that their clientele is diminishing rather than growing. Whereas 70 people turned up to listen to the details at a business migration seminar in Seoul a year ago, only seven turned up at the most recent one. There is no overwhelming or compelling evidence yet, but we do not need much of a drop-off-we need only about 700 in a program of 12,000 not to come-for it to cost this country $350m in terms of money brought in.

I would have thought that the final part of the Senator Dunn's question was quite separate from the others. She asked whether the Government would consider amending the Migration Act to prohibit discrimination against prospective migrants. I would have thought that that should be put as a more general question as to whether the Government was minded to legislate against racism. I must say that I can see both merit in that and problems with it. Sometimes when we introduce legislation to prohibit something we create victims in society, because it can be so distorted. I do not think that it is a straightforward matter of merely introducing legislation to enforce goodness in people. Sometimes that can backfire, not on us, but on some of the other people in society who are the natural victims. It is a suggestion that is certainly worthy of consideration, but it needs to be given lengthy and considered consideration-if that is not too much tautology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. It follows the question asked by Senator Patterson when Senator Cook, in response, made the extraordinary statement that Senator Patterson was drawing a long bow in connecting the cost of housing with the decisions made by young couples to have children. I ask the Minister whether he has seen the sorts of comments which were reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 November when a series of people concerned with housing in Australia made statements bearing out the concerns that were expressed by Senator Patterson. Mr Ian Irvine, Westpac's national manager of personal lending, said that it was estimated that two-thirds of borrowers were reliant on two incomes to repay their loans and, in some cases, it meant putting off having a family for more than 10 years. The Commonwealth Bank's chief manager of retail banking, Mr Murray Westgarth, was quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Couples once would have thought of having a family at an early age, but that's being put back now.
The article quoted people saying, when they applied for a loan:
We don't intend to have a family; we intend to keep on working; therefore we can service the debt.

The coordinator of Credit Line, Mrs Betty Weul, said that many couples were committed to such a heavy outlay that they had to cut expenses for food down to rock bottom, had no money for entertainment and could not afford a family for up to 15 years. Is the Government aware of the difficulties which face young married couples in Australia who wish to purchase a home? Does the Government deny the sorts of facts which were contained in Senator Patterson's question and which I have just referred to in my question? If the Government does not deny those facts, does it admit that there is a problem? What hope does it hold out to young couples that there may be some change which will remedy a situation in which Australia is not reproducing its own population?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite surprised that Senator Chaney should rise on his feet in his pontificating way and pose such a question.
—Do you deny it?

—I will deal with Senator Chaney's question. He should just wait and allow me to do that. I am not aware, in the first instance, of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald to which Senator Chaney referred, but I am aware that there are several factors which affect the price of houses and the availability of land. I am also aware of a multitude of factors, including the whole emphasis on women wanting to participate in the work force and pursue their own careers, which relate to the choices couples make about families. I think that it is absolutely a long bow and it reflects badly on the Opposition to maintain a fiction that interest rates somehow are the cause of all that, and that is the fiction that both Senator Chaney and Senator Patterson have tried to promote.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of housing, the first and fundamental question is the availability of land and in a location in which couples choose to settle. The second question is a marked change in public taste about housing styles and designs and what sort of housing people choose. The third aspect of all that is whether or not the young couple decides that they will both continue working, for whatever reason, and in the end there is a decision about prices and what goes to make up housing prices is a multifaceted thing.

I come to the question of families. This Government would be proud to put its record in terms of assistance to families in Australia alongside that of any other government and in terms of achievement alongside a government of which Senator Chaney was a part and in which he had a responsible Ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the Senate of the Government's reaction to the outcome of the recent meeting of the Palestine National Council in Algiers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government takes the view that the meeting of the Palestine National Council in Algiers last week does represent a positive step forward in the search for peace in the Middle East. We do welcome the Council's acceptance of United Nations (UN) Security Council resolution 242 as the basis of an international conference in the Middle East, which is the way in which it expressed it, although it has to be acknowledged that this still falls short of that absolutely unequivocal statement of Israel's right to exist; that is to say, not conditional upon the holding of conferences or for that matter on the acceptance of other resolutions as well which many countries, including Australia, have been urging the Palestine Liberation Organisation to make. We also welcome the Palestine National Council's explicit rejection of, as it puts it, the threat or use of force, violence and terrorism against the territorial integrity of other states, although again as a significant qualification we remain concerned that the accompanying exception which was made for, and as it was put, the natural right to defend the territorial integrity and independence of the newly declared state of Palestine obviously does not comprehensively rule out, as one would hope would be the case, the use of terrorism in the pursuit of the Palestinians' political objectives.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of Australian recognition of the declaration of a Palestinian state, which was probably the centrepiece of last week's meeting, will arise only in the context of an acceptable negotiated resolution of the future of the occupied territories. The Australian Government takes the view that quite apart from the generally accepted legal preconditions for the recognition of statehood- that is to say, an identifiable territorial unit containing a permanent population under the authority of its own government and capable of entering into relations with other states-the question of a Palestinian state we say cannot be resolved by unilateral declaration but only in the context of an overall settlement of the Middle East dispute.

In the context of an overall settlement, it is our position and continues to be our position that we support the right of self-determination for the Palestinian people, including independence and the possibility of their own independent state. We also, as I have indicated elsewhere, support the convening of an international conference on the Middle East under the auspices of the UN as a means of resolving ultimately, perhaps the only means of resolving, the Arab-Israeli dispute. But the important point to make overall is that, even with the limitations and the weaknesses which I have mentioned, the statements emerging from the Palestine National Council's Algerian meeting are an important significant step forward on the road to peace in the Middle East.

It is vital that the Government of Israel should acknowledge and recognise the new and positive elements in the Palestine National Council's declaration and that it should respond in a constructive and forthright manner. A failure to respond positively to these developments will only entrench further the despair which has become a hallmark of this conflict and support the position of extremists on both sides who deny that there can ever be a political solution to the problem.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS: REFUSAL TO ISSUE DRUG

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November I was asked by Senator Panizza a question concerning prescription of the drug heparin calcium. At that time I took the question on notice and I now give the answer. The article in the Western Australian Sunday Times of 6 November is a continuation of a story first reported in that paper on 16 October. The original article quoted as its informant the President of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), Dr Michael Jones. Dr Jones was alleged in that article to have claimed that a gynaecologist requested authority to prescribe the drug heparin calcium `because of a new authorities system which restricts the type and amount of drugs prescribed. The Federal Government brought in the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to encourage doctors to prescribe cheaper medication'. Dr Jones was further quoted as saying that a bungling public servant refused the vital drug for a pregnant woman and exposed her to a potentially deadly risk.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts of the case in chronological order are: the doctor applied in writing on 4 October 1988 to the Department of Community Services and Health for approval to prescribe an increased maximum quantity of the drug heparin calcium. The application was received in the Perth office on 7 October 1988 and was returned the same day for clarification-heparin calcium-heparin sodium. The doctor rang the Department on 12 October 1988 and approval was granted immediately. The prescription was presented to a pharmacy for dispensing at 4.25 p.m. on Wednesday, 19 October 1988.

For Dr Jones to have made the statements attributed to him in the original article he must have been ignorant of the authority system. The case had nothing to do with a recent Government decision requiring some high cost pharmaceutical benefit drugs to be prescribed `authority only'. Heparin calcium is available as a pharmaceutical benefit without restriction. The gynaecologist in this case sought approval to prescribe more than the standard maximum quantity under regulations that have existed for as long as the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. If the prescriber had a genuine belief that his patient was at risk for her life, a prescription for the standard quantity with repeats would have immediately given 15 days treatment pending issue of approval to prescribe the larger quantity. On the urgency question, it is interesting that the prescription was not presented to a pharmacy for dispensing until seven days after issue.

A more recent story on the same subject, which appeared in the Australian Dr Weekly of 4 November 1988, quoted Dr Jones as now claiming that the gynaecologist applied on an authority form `to save the woman the expense of paying for repeated prescriptions'. Therefore, the issue was money saving and not life saving, as claimed originally by Dr Jones. The incident was blown out of proportion due to misleading and exaggerated public statements by Dr Jones as part of a wider AMA campaign directed against the recent Government decision to extend authority restrictions to some high cost drugs even though the circumstances were irrelevant to that issue. It is not proposed to take action against the public servant who sought clarification of the original application or to amend an authorities system that has operated successfully for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is the second report but the first for a full year's operation of the Affirmative Action Agency, which was established following the passage of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986. The legislation was passed in 1986 with the support of both sides-I suppose all major parties-in this Parliament. It was passed with the support of the Opposition in the Senate and its passage was preceded by the work and report of a working party on which both sides of the Parliament were represented. In fact, I had the privilege of being the Opposition representative on that working party. The debate was fairly memorable. I seem to recall that the Opposition sought some 30 amendments to the legislation, and most would have been very worth while. They included an amendment which sought to extend the cover of equal employment opportunity to women working in Commonwealth statutory authorities. I seem to recall that that amendment was supported by everyone on this side and it has come to pass that that is now the law.

This annual report is a record of achievement by the Affirmative Action Agency, a record of its discharge of its duties under the statute, and a report which brings credit to Ms Pratt and the officers working with her. It is a statement of reassurance for those who feared that the passage of this legislation would be the end of the world as they knew it. There were people who felt that this legislation would require them to employ people who otherwise would have been unsuitable. This report makes it clear to me that that has not been the case, and it was never going to be the case, and should give reassurance to those people. The report is a useful signpost for the future.

I make the point that this report covers the period when only companies with 1,000 or more employees were required to report. TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
