The speeches read as follows-
BROADCASTING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

This Bill is a significant step in the Government's objective to provide more diverse television and radio services. It amends the Broadcasting Act to introduce a special category of limited licences aimed at meeting the need for a variety of specialised services which require technical planning but do not warrant the stringent program conditions applied to current broadcasting services.

These services will include such things as information services and special event coverage. Most significantly in this Bicentennial year, they will provide also an appropriate means of implementing the Government's policy of placing control of broadcasting to remote Aboriginal and Islander communities where it belongs, in the hands of the communities themselves. I refer, of course, to the BRACS scheme, Broadcasting for Remote Aboriginal Communities Services, announced jointly in September last year by my predecessor and by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

The Bill also makes a number of other less significant, but equally necessary, changes. These are desirable reforms to the Broadcasting Act and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act which cannot wait for the thorough reviews of all aspects of broadcasting policy now being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and by the Department of Transport and Communications. The Bill also clarifies the legal status of a number of practices, such as relaying radio services to people ``on hold'' on the telephone.
I will deal now with the proposals in more detail.
New Licensing Arrangements.

The specialised services to be encompassed by limited licences do not have the same public interest implications as current forms of broadcasting, either because of the minor nature of the service or, as in the case of BRACS services, because they are primarily the concern of the community served.
Any possible public interest in these services can be safeguarded without invoking the complex rules applying to existing categories of services.
Initially, limited licences will permit the licensing of services for local information, special event, remote Aboriginal community or national broadcaster channel-sharing purposes.

Limited licences will be administered by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as they involve program origination. However, they will be subject to simplified administrative procedures and flexibility will be ensured by the capacity to create new types of limited licence by regulation.

The Minister currently initiates licensing of all broadcasting services by inviting applications. Prospective limited licensees will be able to apply for licences without invitation. The Minister will retain the power to reject or defer those applications on planning or technical grounds but, otherwise, they will be referred to the Tribunal for consideration.

The licence will specify the purpose for which it is granted and licensees will be required to provide a service consistent with that purpose, not one which is ``adequate and comprehensive'' as for existing forms of service. Either the Minister, through specifying the purposes, or the Tribunal, in imposing licence conditions, may refine the purpose of the service.

A licence for information purposes will authorise one of two kinds of service. The first is an information service relevant to the interests of persons residing in, working in or visiting a particular area. Operators of tourist attractions and leisure resorts and some local councils see potential in broadcasting, for example, up to date information on events or places of interest in the local area. Other services could provide information about local road conditions.

The second kind of information service will provide text or graphic material. Some doubt has arisen as to whether these services are covered by the main broadcasting licence of the service provider. Licensing teletext services as limited licences will allow the legal status of those exiting services to be clarified.

Special event licences will relate to sporting events, festivals, exhibitions, expositions or other special events. For example, a licence may be granted to cover the environs of an exhibition for the duration of the particular event.

The BRACS scheme, which I referred to earlier, will bring broadcasting services to more than 60 remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and provide opportunities for these communities to include their own programs. It will enable communities to control reception and will, therefore, help to protect traditional languages and culture.

Under the scheme, Aboriginal and Islander communities will be able to receive ABC, Public and Commercial Services and rebroadcast them, either live or delayed, under agreements with the host broadcaster. It will be possible to insert other programs like those now being produced by Aboriginal media organisations such as CAAMA, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association in Alice Springs, and the first Aboriginal-owned commercial television service, Imparja. The Communities will be able to delete offensive material or switch off the entire system at certain times, such as during ceremonial occasions.
The Bill empowers the ABC and the SBS to make broadcasting facilities and staff available to limited licensees for broadcasting purposes.

In the past, the national broadcasters have entered into informal channel sharing arrangements with public broadcasters and community based program makers. Examples include the ABC's high frequency inland service where about 45 per cent of week day programming is provided by Aboriginal groups through CAAMA and SBS Television's ``windows'' series. The host broadcaster retains editorial and publishing responsibility for broadcasts and, therefore, potential legal liability for defamation and other breaches. ``special interest'' limited licences will enable the programmers to accept responsibility for programs transmitted with ABC or SBS assistance.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will have flexible licensing powers for limited services. It will retain its powers to refuse to licence a service of the kind applied for and to make program standards for limited licences. It will have to commence inquiries into granting the licence but will be able to terminate those inquiries where it is satisfied that no further investigation is necessary.

Only those limited services providing text information will be permitted to broadcast paid advertisements. However, special event and channel sharing services will be allowed to broadcast sponsorship announcements. The prohibition will not prevent remote Aboriginal community licensees retransmitting advertisements included in the host service where no payment or other consideration is received by the licensee community.

Limited licensees, like other licensees, will be required, as far as possible, to use the services of Australians in the production and presentation of their programs in accordance with section 114 of the Broadcasting Act.

In summary, the essence of limited licences is flexibility-flexibility for the Minister and the Tribunal to consider new, non-commercial forms of broadcasting service; flexibility demanded by technological developments; flexibility long overdue in the labyrinthine Broadcasting Act.
The Bill also introduces temporary transmission and retransmission permit schemes to replace the existing test transmission permits and rebroadcasting and retransmission licences.

Re-broadcasting and re-transmission licences authorise the retransmission of commercial, public or national broadcasts. The new scheme will consolidate these two categories of `licence' and recognise that, since there is no element of program origination in a retransmitted service, the Tribunal's involvement is unnecessary.

The decisions involved are purely planning and technical and thus fall within the responsibilities of the Minister. Ministerial grant of such `permits' will eliminate the need for double handling between the Minister and the Tribunal. This will substantially speed up the process for small communities who seek to obtain or improve reception of broadcasting services. The scheme will also eliminate the need for broadcasters to have a separate licence to relay their service by cable within their own service area.

The permits will also cover retransmission outside a licensee's service area to particular persons or classes of persons. No permit will be required to authorise the playing of radio to people held on telephone queues.

Test transmission permits are granted to existing licensees for testing new technical equipment, to new licensees prior to the formal grant of the licence and to aspirant, generally public, broadcasters who wish to test public reaction to program formats.

While these may involve some program origination, they involve primarily planning questions and the Tribunal's involvement is generally unnecessary. The new scheme will transfer responsibility to the Minister, with a provision for referral to the Tribunal in appropriate circumstances such as where particular programming issues arise.

The maximum length of permits will be extended from the existing 7 days to 14 days. Guidelines will be developed in consultation with interested groups to replace the existing Tribunal policy statement and practice note on test transmission permits.

Fees for limited licences and for retransmission and temporary transmission permits will be introduced under Bills shortly to be introduced. The level of fees has not yet been finalised and will vary with the nature of the service to be provided.
Local Origination

A licensee must currently obtain approval from the Tribunal before it can broadcast different programs from different transmitters within a service area-a practice known as `local origination' and intended to provide more local programs.

The Bill removes the requirement for prior Tribunal permission to locally originate but makes the practice subject to scrutiny by the Tribunal as part of the assessment of the adequacy and comprehensiveness of a service. This will be a relevant issue at licence renewal inquiries. However, failure to locally originate will not of itself disclose a failure to provide an adequate and comprehensive service.

The Bill provides a range of mechanisms for delivering services which will be particularly important for remote and regional audiences. Licensees will have more flexibility in providing local origination. Local communities will be able to receive, more quickly, authorisation to establish their own retransmission facilities. Remote Aboriginal and Islander communities will have enormous flexibility in providing services appropriate to their cultural needs and the national broadcasters will be able to consider proposals by limited licensees to share their facilities. Together, these reforms open the door for significant improvements in the range of broadcasting services available to under-served areas.
ABC Amendments

The Bill will allow the ABC to borrow money from the Commonwealth or other sources with the Finance Minister's or Treasurer's approval respectively and to offer its assets as security. It will permit the Commonwealth to guarantee loans. The Bill also confers powers to enter into hedging contracts to reduce the risks of foreign exchange or interest rate fluctuations and to invest surplus funds in a manner approved by the Treasurer.

These powers are consistent with the greater independence and accountability of the Corporation in financial matters stemming from the Government's decision to introduce three-year funding. They will certainly be of use to the Corporation in financing a number of proposals for development of accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne, amongst others.

The Bill also greatly simplifies the legislative provisions covering the ABC's staffing matters in line with the Government's policy of streamlining those provisions for independent statutory bodies. The Corporation will continue its endeavours to achieve and maintain high standards as an employer in relation to terms and conditions of employment, occupational health, industrial safety, industrial democracy, non-discriminatory employment practices and other matters.

Subject to the co-ordination arrangements which apply to all budget-funded agencies, the Corporation and staff organisations will have greater flexibility in negotiating conditions of employment. The Government expects the Corporation to develop and maintain all future employment arrangements in full consultation and negotiation with relevant unions. These arrangements will be incorporated into industrial agreements or awards which will bind the Corporation in the same way as awards bind the Commonwealth, under section 41A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1901. However, this does not mean that the Commission will be arbitrating or interfering in matters which may be properly regarded as coming within managerial prerogative. The staffing provisions will commence on a date to be proclaimed to allow the Corporation and relevant unions time to finalise the new arrangements.
Similar powers are available to other Commonwealth authorities operating in a competitive environment. The Government believes they will assist in creating a more flexible and efficient ABC.
Tobacco Advertising

The Bill extends the current ban on broadcasting advertisements for cigarettes and cigarette tobacco to cover other tobacco products such as cigars, snuff and chewing tobacco. It will bring the advertising requirements in the Broadcasting Act into line with those set out in the guidelines for Video and Audio Entertainment and Information Services currently licensed under the Radiocommunications Act.
Administrative Matters

The Bill will eliminate areas of administrative duplication in a range of routine planning and technical matters and will allow the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to carry out activities incidental to its functions. In particular, the Bill will allow it to provide and market publications and information services and hold conferences.

The Bill also provides that the Tribunal may require corporations ``related'' within the meaning of the Companies Code to a licensee corporation, to furnish information about the activities or affairs of the related corporation which is relevant to the operation of the licence fees Acts. A corporation is ``related'' to another if they are subsidiaries, holding companies or joint subsidiaries of a third corporation.

The Bill rectifies a defect in legislation which extends the electoral blackout provisions in the Broadcasting Act to elections for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and such other bodies prescribed by Regulation.
Finally, the Bill contains some reorganisation of provisions in the Act covering licensing criteria. These changes have no policy effect and are intended only to make the Act more readable.
Financial Impact

There is expected to be some increase in the administrative workload of the Department and the Tribunal resulting from the planning and licensing of new limited services. In the Department, this will be added to by the assumption of responsibility for temporary transmission and retransmission permits, partially offset by savings from simplified planning and technical procedures. Any additional workload will be absorbed within existing resources. The loss of responsibility for test transmission permits and re-broadcasting and re-transmission licences will provide the Tribunal with small but useful administrative savings. These also can be expected in the ABC with simplified staffing provisions and more efficient cash management.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING (LIMITED LICENCES) FEES BILL 1988

The Bill imposes fees in respect of limited licences granted under the Broadcasting Act 1942 . These fees will be by way of a tax with the amounts to be fixed by regulation. This new category of licence is being introduced into the Broadcasting Act by amendments in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 which has just received its second reading.

Limited licences provide a flexible method of licensing a range of new broadcasting services which do not raise public interest implications of the same magnitude as conventional forms of broadcasting. Consistent with this approach, the limited licence fees Bill provides considerable flexibility in the types of fees which may be set for different forms of limited licences.

The regulations will be able to prescribe fees payable annually or on the grant and renewal of licences. The fees may be set to recover the administrative costs of planning and licensing limited services or to impose charges which ensure that the revenue derived by the Commonwealth properly reflects the value in alternative uses of the frequencies allocated.

The regulations will be able to prescribe that fees for the grant of limited licences be set by tender, bidding or auction. In this situation, the choice by the Tribunal of the most suitable applicant for the particular limited licence will be made by selecting the highest suitable bidder. While none of the forms of limited licence expressly mentioned in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill is expected to be allocated in this way, the provisions give flexibility to apply it to future forms of limited licence if the public interest would thus be best served.
The power to set fees is not mandatory and some forms of limited licence might not attract fees at all.

Regulations will be made to commence on the date of commencement of this Bill. They will be set at levels consistent with those applying for similar users of the spectrum licensed under the Radiocommunications Act 1983.
Financial Impact
It is not expected that significant revenue will be generated by the Bill. The precise amounts will depend on the demand for limited licences, which cannot be estimated with any precision.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING (RETRANSMISSION PERMITS AND TEMPORARY TRANSMISSION PERMITS) FEES BILL 1988

The Bill imposes fees in respect of retransmission and temporary transmission permits granted under the Broadcasting Act 1942. These fees will be by way of a tax with the amounts to be fixed by regulation. These new categories of permits are being introduced into the Broadcasting Act by amendments in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 which has just received its second reading. They replace the existing categories of re-broadcasting and re-transmission licenses and test transmission permits.

Regulations will be made to commence on the date of commencement of this Bill. They will be set at levels consistent with those applying for similar users of the spectrum licensed under the Radiocommunications Act 1983.
Financial Impact
It is not expected that significant revenue will be generated by the Bill. The precise amounts will depend on the demand for permits.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING (NATIONAL METROPOLITAN RADIO PLAN) BILL 1988
This Bill marks a further phase in the Government's policy of extending greater choice in radio and television services to the people of Australia.

It implements the first stage of the national plan for metropolitan radio services which will provide more commercial FM radio outlets in mainland state capital cities and establish AM networks for parliamentary broadcasting and Radio for the Print Handicapped.
The plan, announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Gareth Evans, on 9 August this year, addresses several interlocking issues. These are:
The general desire by existing AM licensees to convert to FM;
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's wish to extend its JJJ Youth Network and to provide for parliamentary broadcasting in a cost-effective manner which does not disrupt ABC programming;
The need to expand and improve Radio for the Print Handicapped services; and

The desirability of reforming the existing system of allocating frequencies for commercial purposes and deriving an appropriate return to the community from the commercial use of a public resource, namely the FM radio spectrum.
The national metropolitan radio plan involves two stages.

Under the first stage eligible commercial AM licensees will be invited to lodge bids for the right to convert from their existing AM frequencies to FM frequencies. The two highest eligible bidders in each capital city will be selected to convert to the FM frequencies.

A condition of eligibility for the tender process will be that the successful tenderers must transfer their AM transmission facilities and sites to the Commonwealth for use by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for Parliamentary broadcasts, and by public licensees for Radio for the Print Handicapped purposes. I intend shortly to invite applications for a public radio licence serving Print Handicapped listeners for the first vacated AM channel in each mainland state capital.

The second stage of the plan will involve invitation for tenders for two new commercial FM Radio licences in each mainland State capital. I intend to bring forward legislation in the autumn sittings 1989 to implement this second stage. This will provide time for more detailed consultation on the process proposed for stage 2. It also will allow these steps to be considered in the context of the review of the Broadcasting Act currently being undertaken by the Department of Transport and Communications, and the current inquiry by the House of Representatives Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee into the role of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Two of the central aims which this Government has consistently pursued in its broadcasting policy have been to maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services and to limit concentration of media ownership and control.

These objectives are being pursued through a significant expansion of existing services and through the introduction of new, competitive services. In television, the policy of equalisation is bringing new commercial television services to regional areas. We are also well advanced in providing additional commercial radio services in regional areas. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has made decisions on new FM commercial radio licences in Newcastle, Geelong, the Gold Coast, Gosford, Shepparton and Moree. Two supplementary FM licences are on air in Canberra. Tribunal inquiries are under way in Ipswich, Geraldton and Townsville, and will soon begin in Mildura, Hobart, Lismore, Mackay, Renmark, Darwin, Albany, Kempsey and Nowra. The program up to the end of 1990 will bring new commercial radio services to some 4.2 million people. I will soon be announcing a further phase of the program for 1991.
In public radio, at least six to eight new services are being introduced each year whilst the ABC continues to expand its services with the development of the second regional radio network.

Consistent with this policy of extension of services, the national metropolitan radio plan should increase the diversity of radio services available to listeners in the mainland State capitals. In conjunction with the existing one-to-a-market ownership limit, the entry of new operators into the industry will further diversify the ownership of radio stations.
Tender Procedures

The Bill empowers the Minister to invite applications from existing metropolitan commercial AM licensees for conversion to FM. Applications will be submitted to the Tender Board of the Department of Transport and Communications. Applications will include sealed bids and a range of other material detailing the nature and value of the AM transmission facilities which will be provided to the Commonwealth in part satisfaction of that bid. The transmission equipment will need to meet technical standards set by the Minister and the interest in the transmission site will need to be sufficient to ensure continuing delivery of Parliamentary and RPH services.
The equipment will be valued by the Department and the site by the Australian Valuation Office, with facility for reference to commercial arbitration in the event of disputes.
Bids will be subject to a confidential reserve price established by the Minister. A secure procedure will be followed to ensure that the reserve price remains confidential.

After the closing date, the Tender Board will examine the applications and reject any which do not meet the prescribed conditions, and provide the Minister with a ranking of applicants whose bids exceed the reserve from the highest bidder down. I will offer FM frequencies to the two highest bidding applicants with the highest bidder having its choice of preferred frequency, subject to normal planning considerations.
Where the successful applicant defaults, the next highest bidder will be offered a frequency.
In making offers to the successful applicants, I will advise the date by which the fee as bid must be paid and the AM facilities transferred.
I will be empowered to re-call tenders if satisfied that there has been collusion in tendering.
Radio for the Print Handicapped

RPH services have been operating unsatisfactorily for some years outside the broadcast band, on low power and with sub-standard equipment. This legislation empowers the Commonwealth to acquire transmission sites and associated AM equipment from existing commercial licensees in part satisfaction of their bid for conversion to FM. The Commonwealth will then lease these facilities to RPH groups at a nominal rent. I will invite applications for a public radio licence to serve print handicapped listeners on the first vacated AM frequency in each mainland State capital. The tender procedure for conversion of AM commercial licensees will ensure that the sites and facilities tendered are adequate to provide an acceptable signal across the metropolitan areas.

The Government had previously intended that RPH services would be provided on FM frequencies. However, the technical characteristics of AM are more appropriate to the predominantly spoken word RPH programs and the availability of vacated AM frequencies and facilities from the conversion of AM commercial stations provide an excellent opportunity to improve the quality of existing RPH services in mainland State capitals. The only disadvantage is that AM transmitters are more expensive than FM to operate. The Government will therefore provide a grant of $100,000 per year to meet this extra cost.

In Canberra and Hobart frequencies are available on the FM band and will be allocated in 1990. A capital grant of $600,000 will be provided in 1990-91 to assist the establishment of these two new RPH stations.
Parliamentary Broadcasts

For many years the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has met its legislative obligation to broadcast parliamentary proceedings. This has been at some cost to the ABC in the development of coherent radio programming and also in building up its audience. This legislation will facilitate the use by the ABC of the sites and facilities of the successful tenderer for the second frequency in each city for the establishment of a parliamentary broadcasting network. The new and permanent network for parliamentary broadcasting will replace the interim parliamentary broadcasting network which is presently being established through the use of the ABC's standby transmission facilities. Following the complete transfer from Radio National to the interim network, the ABC will be able to further develop Radio National as a high quality news and talk service.
The Extension of the ABC's Youth Network

An important part of the national plan is the extension of the ABC's JJJ FM service from Sydney to the other capital cities. This initiative links with the Government's recent establishment of the Australian Contemporary Popular Music Development Company. The Youth Network will be financed by the ABC from its existing resources, and requires no legislative amendments.
Financial Implications

This Bill has no direct financial consequences, because the formal obligation to pay the fees it introduces will be imposed under the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964 through amendments introduced in the accompanying Radio Licence Fees (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988.

In conclusion, I believe this Bill creates new opportunities for commercial radio operators in the mainland capital cities. The ability for some AM stations to convert to FM will help to redress the imbalance between commercial operators using the AM and FM bands. The Government hopes that this will lead to a more dynamic approach to programming, resulting in a more diverse range of services to the community. Commercial broadcasting has shown a capacity to meet changing circumstances.

In recent years, the level of competition has increased markedly with the introduction of new commercial radio services, particularly on FM. Competition is likely to intensify as AM stations convert to FM in Stage 1 of the plan and later with the establishment of two additional commercial stations.
The listening public should welcome the addition of new commercial FM services as testified by the success of existing commercial FM stations.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIO LICENCE FEES (NATIONAL METROPOLITAN RADIO PLAN) BILL 1988

The Bill formally imposes the obligation to pay the fee on conversion from AM to FM broadcasting by large city commercial radio licensees determined in accordance with the tender process introduced in the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988.
It is purely a machinery Bill and all the relevant policy elements are covered by the accompanying Broadcasting Bill.
Financial Implications

The first stage of the National Plan, implemented in this Bill and the accompanying Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan Bill) 1988, is expected to produce net revenue of $79.9m over the five years from 1988-89 to 1992-93, with an on-going annual additional cost of $0.2m. This comprises revenue from tendering for AM/FM conversion, partially offset by the costs of retaining vacated AM sites and facilities for Parliamentary and Radio for the Print Handicapped Networks and some small additional capital and recurrent outlays.

A $0.6m capital grant will be provided in 1990-91 for the establishment of FM RPH stations in Canberra and Hobart. The Appropriation Bills provide for an ongoing annual subsidy to RPH of $100,000 to meet the additional cost of maintaining AM rather than FM facilities, and an increase in the grant-in-aid for RPH from $25,000 to $125,000 per annum. They also provide for additional Departmental administration expenses of $400,000 in 1988-89. An additional $100,000 will be required in 1989-90.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will amend the taxation laws in a number of ways. It will implement several major changes announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 25 May 1988 as part of the May economic statement, and on 23 August 1988 as part of the 1988-89 Budget. In particular, it will remove, subject to phasing-in arrangements, the present income tax exemption that applies to income from goldmining. It will also exclude from assessability under the income tax law up to $200 per year of discounts on shares or rights acquired under certain employee share acquisition schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Other 1988 May economic statement income tax measures contained in the Bill will reduce the rate of deduction for investment in Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent, and modify the imputation provisions as they relate to dividends paid before 1 July 1989 by early balancing companies.

Budget measures contained in the Bill which provide a rebate of tax for lump sum payments in arrears of certain kinds of income, and deductibility for gifts to the Australian National Gallery Foundation.

Other amendments of the income tax law proposed by this Bill will ensure that certain `prepaid' research and development expenditure will be deductable over the period during which relevant services are provided, and will exempt certain cash grants made under the defence service homes scheme. Some minor amendments are also proposed to the fringe benefits tax law.
Finally, the Bill contains measures to clarify the refund provisions of the sales tax law. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Tax Exemption for Goldmining Income

In accordance with the 1988 May economic statement, the Bill will remove the current exemption from taxation of income from goldmining, subject to certain phasing-in arrangements. The Government will honour its commitment to the gold industry by allowing the existing exemption to apply until 1 January 1991.

From that date, the Bill will terminate the tax exemption of income from goldmining; and the exemption for income derived from the sale of gold by the Gold Producers Association Ltd. The impact of these changes will be further eased by allowing certain expenditures incurred prior to 1 January 1991 to be carried forward for deduction after that date.

In particular, the Bill contains transitional arrangements to calculate notional deductions for capital expenditure incurred by goldminers prior to 1 January 1991 in order to determine actual deductions for such expenditure from that date for goldminers that continue to be engaged in mining operations. Notional deductions will be calculated either on the basis of write-off rates specified in the mining provisions of the income tax law or the 5/3 accelerated depreciation provisions.

A separate transitional arrangement will apply to exploration expenditure for gold incurred between 25 May 1988 and 1 January 1991 which will be carried forward and deducted against income from 1 January 1991 for up to seven years from the year in which it is incurred. As is the case in relation to claims for deductions for expenses generally, claims by goldminers for deductions allowed under the transitional arrangements will need to be supported by adequate records.

The tax exemption for income from the sale of rights to mine for gold by bona fide prospectors will be retained, subject to an amendment to confine the exemption to arm's length transactions, as for other minerals. Also consistent with the existing law, the amount of exploration expenditure carried forward during the transitional period will be appropriately reduced in the event of a tax exempt sale of a mining right before 1 January 1991.

In respect of other goldmining assets acquired after 19 September 1985, the capital gains tax will only apply to that part of any gain on disposal of such an asset that accrues after 31 December 1990. This will ensure that any capital gains tax liability on disposal of such assets is entirely prospective.
In relation to income derived or expenditure incurred from 1 January 1991, goldminers will otherwise be subject to tax on the same basis as other miners.
These changes are expected to produce revenue savings of $870m in 1991-92 and $300m per annum in later income years.
Lump Sum Payments in Arrears

The Bill provides for a rebate of tax to be allowed where certain income accrued in years earlier than the year of receipt is received in a lump sum. The rebate will limit the tax payable on the arrears component of the lump sum to an amount comparable to the tax that would have been payable if the income had been received when it accrued.

Lump sum payments of workers and accident compensation, certain pensions, benefits and allowances and, in limited circumstances, payments of salary or wages will be eligible for the rebate. At present, such lump sums are wholly taxable as income of the year in which they are received and this can result in taxpayers paying a higher amount of tax than if the income had been received in each of the years in which it accrued.

The rebate will be available for lump sums received on or after 1 July 1986 where the amount of the accrued income is not less than 10 per cent of the taxpayer's taxable income of the year of receipt, as adjusted for certain kinds of income of an irregular nature. The kind of income that will be excluded in applying the eligibility test are those parts of the lump sums that accrued in prior years together with any capital gains, abnormal income or lump sums paid on termination of employment. The rebate will be calculated by reference to the income of the two most recent years, prior to the year of receipt, over which the lump sum accrued.

Where the lump sum accrued no earlier than those two years the taxation position of a taxpayer as a consequence of the rebate will be the same as if the income had been received in the income years in which it accrued. Where the lump sum accrued over a longer period, the tax payable in respect of the arrears that accrued in those earlier years will be determined broadly on the basis of the rates of tax that would have been borne in the two most recent years before the year of receipt.
The estimated cost of providing this rebate is $3m in 1988-89 and $1m in subsequent financial years.
Employee Share Acquisition Schemes

This Bill gives effect to the proposal announced in the 1988 May economic statement to exclude from income tax up to $200 of discounts on shares or rights acquired by employees under certain employee share acquisition schemes. To qualify for the proposed exclusion, the employee share acquisition scheme will need to be open, on a non-discriminatory basis, to all full time or permanent part time employees of at least 12 months service. In addition, shares or rights acquired under a scheme will need to be held for a minimum of three years except where employment terminates.

The Bill will also ensure that, for capital gains tax purposes, the cost base of the shares or rights will be reduced by any discount that is excluded from assessable income. These changes will apply to shares or rights acquired on or after 1 July 1988, and are expected to have a revenue cost of $5m for each of the first three years, but to decline in subsequent years.
Transitional Imputation Arrangements

The Bill contains the transitional measures announced by the Treasurer in the 1988 May economic statement to prevent franked dividends, paid by early balancing companies with imputation credits calculated on the basis of the 39 per cent company tax rate, from being channelled through later balancing companies which, as the law presently stands, could effectively pass those dividends on to individual shareholders with higher imputation credits based on the 49 per cent company tax rate. This situation will be addressed by deeming dividends paid by early balancing companies between 1 January and 30 June 1989 to a resident company that could pay dividends franked on the basis of the 49 per cent company tax rate to be received by that company, for imputation purposes, on the first day of the franking year that corresponds to its 1989-90 tax year, generally 1 July 1989.

Where, however, the company receiving dividends that have been affected by the deeming provisions has a franking deficit at the end of its 1988-89 franking year, the Bill allows these dividends to be applied to the reduction or elimination of that deficit. Where necessary, up to two-thirds of such dividends may be applied against the franking deficit in this way.
The overall cost of the reduction of the company tax, excluding life companies, with which this transitional measure is associated, is $110m in 1988-89 and $1,850m in 1989-90.
Prepaid Research and Development Expenditure

The Bill will change the timing of deductions for research and development expenditure that is incurred in advance of the provision of the services to which the expenditure relates. Instead of being fully deductable when incurred, deductions for the expenditure will be pro rated over the period during which the services are provided. Immediate deductibility will continue to be available if all of the services are provided within 13 months of incurring the expenditure; if the expenditure is less than $1,000 or if it is required to be incurred by law.

Additionally, preferred treatment will be given to expenditure incurred to an approved research institute or a registered research agency, and to expenditure incurred on syndication projects for which a company is registered by the industry research and development board. For expenditure of this kind, deductions that would be allowable in the second and subsequent years of income will be advanced to the preceding year of income. The amendments will apply to expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987.
Films

As part of the restructuring of the Government's support for the film industry, the Bill reduces the deduction for investments in qualifying Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent, with no exemption from tax for income from such investments. The reduction, which was announced by the Treasurer in the 1988 May economic statement, will apply to expenditure under contracts entered into on or after 25 May 1988.

The Bill also contains transitional provisions to preserve temporarily the higher rates of deduction for films substantially in production or underwritten before 25 May 1988, provided that certain conditions are met. The estimated cost of the proposed amendments is $90m over a four-year period commencing with the 1989-90 financial year.

Future Government assistance to the film industry will be given primarily through the Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd, which has been established as a wholly Commonwealth owned company to fund qualifying Australian films.
Corporate Restructure (Debt Creation) Rules

The Bill will effect a minor amendment to the income tax law to correct a technical deficiency in the corporate restructure debt creation rules which, it is argued, presently grant an exemption from the legislation in a way that was not intended. The amendment will ensure that the exempting provisions do not extend to corporate restructure arrangements under which shares held by a non-resident in one resident company are sold to another company controlled by the non-resident.

Although designed to do no more than clarify the intended operation of the debt creation rules that apply from 1 July 1987, to remove any suggestion of retrospectivity, this measure will apply to relevant transactions entered into after 3 November 1988. This change will have a negligible impact on revenue.
Gifts

As foreshadowed in the Budget, this Bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts made on and after 26 September 1988 to the Australian National Gallery Foundation. The estimated cost of admitting the foundation to the gift provisions is $500,000 in 1988-89 and subsequent years.
Cash Grants under the Defence Service Homes Scheme

The Bill will exempt from income tax certain cash payments made instead of low interest mortgage loans under the defence service homes scheme. The payments were made under transitional arrangements that applied between 16 September 1987 and 9 December 1987 inclusive. The cost to revenue of the exemption is estimated to be $350,000 in 1988-89 and $50,000 in 1989-90.
Fringe Benefits Tax

The Bill contains some minor fine-tuning amendments of the fringe benefits tax law that are of a concessional nature in relation to the operation of the so-called `otherwise-deductable' rule. These amendments will have negligible revenue effect.
Sales Tax Refund

Finally, the refund provisions of the sales tax law will be clarified to ensure that, where tax has been passed on to customers, refunds of overpaid tax are available only if the person who ultimately bore the tax has been recompensed.
