TALK.START.PARA: —The first words of this speech are indeed interesting. I take great pleasure in introducing the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill to the Senate. Honourable senators will have seen from a quick glance at this Bill that its basic purpose is to provide for a new Federal road funding program from 1 January 1989, to replace both of the Government's current programs. However, a closer reading reveals that the Bill contains important new initiatives which distinguish it from previous roads programs. To a greater extent than any of its predecessors, the Australian centennial roads development (ACRD) program looks to the economic future of Australia. As its title implies, this legislation will set the direction of road funding towards the year 2001-the centenary of our Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, the Government's economic agenda is focusing closely on the need for structural adjustment of our major industries. The improvement of our land transport sector is an integral part of this structural adjustment process. Cheaper, safer and more efficient transport can mean only greater success in our attempts to make our industries more competitive. The clear message for all levels of government is that land transport development needs to blend more closely with economic policy. If Australia is to continue to improve its economic performance we cannot afford to ignore this. In the area of roads funding, this requirement is absolutely essential. Roads play a pivotal role in Australia's transport system. About half of all freight transport takes place on roads and if we exclude low value bulk commodities the figure is over 80 per cent. In addition, over 97 per cent of passenger travel is by road. Given these statistics, it is important that we take a long hard look at roads development. With all levels of government coming to grips with the need for economic restraint it is imperative that scarce roads infrastructure be effectively targeted. Only in this way can we ensure the sorts of economic and social benefits we are aiming for.

Of course, much has already been achieved by this Government in the roads sphere. Despite the tough economic climate that has prevailed over the last few years, we have managed to establish an impressive record on the road funding front. Over the six Hawke Government Budgets since 1983, we have allocated more than $7 billion to road funding, an increase in real terms of 21 per cent over the last six Budgets of the Fraser Administration. More importantly, we have made effective and sensible use of these funds.

In 1985, for example, we introduced the Australian land transport program (ALTP). This program broke new ground by presenting a more comprehensive approach to land transport funding with money provided from a share of fuel excise. We have also witnessed the rapid development of our national highway system. This impressive network serves a vital role for the economic and social roads needs of this nation. More and more Australians are remarking on the progress we have made on the national highway. Over recent years we have achieved significant upgrading of the important Sydney to Melbourne link as well as completion of sealing on the Adelaide to Darwin and Brisbane to Darwin sections. These developments are not only providing safer and more efficient transport but are going a long way to bringing our communities closer together. This Government is proud of its roads achievement to date. But it also realises that much more has to be done.

The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill takes a realistic approach to our roads objectives. The program that it enacts will ensure that we not only look to the roads demands of the future but also provide for the maintenance of our existing roads assets. The new arrangements will replace both of our current Federal road funding programs. Most honourable senators will be aware that the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program expires at the end of this year. While the Australian land transport program was not due to finish until mid-1990, it makes administrative sense to have one single program in place from 1989. The Bill itself is the culmination of a detailed Government review earlier this year of Federal road funding arrangements. This review consulted with all major interest groups including State and local government, major road transport bodies and motorist organisations. What was uppermost in mind when conducting the review and subsequently framing this legislation was the need to have careful regard to the relationship between road funding and economic policy. It is a mistake to consider road funding in isolation from the general economy.

As I outlined earlier, one of the Government's principal economic consideration at the present time is the implementation of a process of structural adjustment designed to make our key export and import competing industries more efficient and competitive and so improve longer term security. Federal roads investment can make a major contribution to this process of structural adjustment. But, having said this, the other important economic factor to keep in mind is the pressing need for expenditure restraint. The halcyon times of the 1950s and 1960s are over. We all need to face the fact that funding available for roads development is limited. The new ACRD program clearly reflects these economic considerations.

Firstly, funds are to be concentrated on roads of national economic significance. In particular, the Bill provides for a new category of what are called `national arterials', designed to improve road access for our major industries. The second principal aim of the Bill is to get better value for every dollar spent of roads. To this end, the program provides for revised administrative arrangements based on a quality assurance approach and reduced Federal involvement. The States will assume greater responsibility and accountability for ensuring projects are completed on budget and to an appropriate standard. These arrangements will guarantee efficiency in the delivery of the new road program.

Let me first turn to roads of national economic importance. Until now, the national highway system has provided significant assistance to economic growth by making freight movements faster, cheaper and safer. Funding for this category will continue under the new program so that its benefits can be preserved. However, we need to realise that the national highway is predominantly an inter-capital link. It does not encompass the major feeder routes into and out of these capital cities, nor does it include connections to some of our important manufacturing and primary production centres. What we need to do therefore is build on the achievements of the national highway. For this reason we have introduced the new national arterial category. National arterials will encompass roads which can be shown specifically to enhance the domestic and export competitiveness of Australian industry. To this end, the category will fund projects on key routes linking areas of production with ports, airports, freight forwarding centres, rail freight terminals and terminii of key arterial roads. These new routes will also provide interstate and international travellers with easier access to tourist areas.

One important proviso to the inclusion of projects in the new national arterial category is the requirement that all routes have an advantageous benefit-cost ratio. While everyone may not be happy with this approach, it is nevertheless one of the best single indicators of the economic merit of projects. It also goes hand in hand with the overriding need to obtain more value from less resources. Over the last few months State and Territory governments have been undertaking the process of identifying candidate routes in consultation with Federal officials. The introduction of the national arterial category marks a `great leap forward' for roads development in Australia. Together with the national highway system it gives a clear statement of our national road funding objectives.

In addition to this emphasis on roads of national economic significance, the program also continues a base level of assistance for State arterial and local roads. Local road funding has fared particularly well under the new program with funding being maintained in real terms in 1988-89 at $268.5m, excluding the $4m allocated to Australian Capital Territory (ACT) local roads. This represents more than a $15m increase over 1987-88 expenditure and clearly reflects this Government's continuing commitment to assisting local government to meet its road responsibilities.

Now let me turn to the funding provisions of the Bill as set out in part II. The Government announced in this year's May economic statement that Federal assistance for roads in 1988-89 would be set at $1,215m. While this represents a slight fall on the previous year's level, the Government has guaranteed that the 1988-89 figure will be maintained in real terms over 1989-90 and 1990-91. Unlike the Opposition we have been prepared to set out our funding commitment to roads over the next few years. Honourable senators will have noted that, for the first time, the Australian Capital Territory is to be incorporated into Federal road funding arrangements. The announced 1988-89 funding level of $1,215m does not include the ACT funding requirement. Total funding in 1988-89 under the three road programs will be $1,221.5m including $6.5m for the ACT.

The funding mechanisms under this Bill are similar to current arrangements. As with the ABRD program and the ALTP before it, revenue for this new program will be paid into a special trust fund, operating from 1 January 1989 to the completion of the program on 31 December 1993. Funds will be raised by earmarking a proportion of net receipts from excise levied on motor spirit and diesel. To guarantee the integrity of this revenue, the Bill provides for the amount of excise receipts to be specifically designated as a road user charge. This will enable road users to clearly identify the amount of excise that is devoted to roads. The initial excise charge rate operating under the program will be 4.95c per litre. The rate will be indexed to movements in the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product for the second and third years of the program.

The Bill also provides for two other important types of charge rate adjustments. The first of these seeks to overcome any transitional funding problems that may arise in 1988-89 by ensuring that the guaranteed funding level of $1,221.5m will actually be available for expenditure. A further adjustment gives legislative backing to the Government's guarantee that the 1988-89 funding level will be maintained in real terms over the following two financial years. Considered together, these adjustments guarantee a secure funding environment for Governments and others involved in finding the money for roads.

Funding provided under the program will be available for both construction and maintenance work on national highways, State arterials and local roads. National arterial funding will be restricted to construction purposes only. As with current arrangements, the program adopts a comprehensive approach to land transport funding. Accordingly, the Bill continues the arrangement whereby a proportion of arterial funds, both national and State, may be redirected to either urban public transport projects or capital projects associated with the operation of interstate mainline railways. The level of funding available for urban public transport and rail projects will be approximately the same as was available under current programs. An amount of $6m will be also available for payment to organisations associated with road safety activities and land transport research.

Details of specific State allocations for designated categories are provided within the Bill for State arterials and local roads. Allocations for national highways, national arterials and road safety and research are to be based on national priorities and will therefore be a matter for ministerial determination. In accordance with this latter provision we have announced that funding in 1988-89 will be set at $484.9m for national highways and $160m for national arterials. States and the Northern Territory have been advised of their individual allocations for these categories. Over subsequent years of the program, the proportion of funding directed to national arterials will increase, reflecting the growing significance of this category. State and category allocations are set out in sections 16 and 17 and schedules 1 and 2 of the Bill and are divided into two distinct time periods. The first of these relates to the 1988-89 financial year with allocations shown as money amounts. Separating out this period will simplify administration during the transitional period as it involves the closure of the ABRD and ALTP trust funds and the commencement of the ACRD fund. It also provides States with assured cash allocations for 1988-89 prior to receipt of final revenues into the ABRD and ALTP funds. The second period covers the remainder of the program from 1 July 1989 with State and category allocations for State arterials and local roads. Maximum percentages have been set for amounts payable under these categories in 1988-89.

Before continuing let me make a few comments about prescribed allocations under the Bill. In the case of arterial funding, honourable senators will note that assistance for State arterials in 1988-89 has been set at $298.1m, including the ACT. While this figure on its own may seem a little low it does not mean that the share of arterial funding has fallen. To obtain the full arterial picture, the allocation for State arterials needs to be taken in conjunction with that for national arterials. Seen from this perspective, the proportion of funding directed to arterial roads has increased marginally over 1987-88 expenditure and represents about 37 per cent of total funding. The major difference is a heavier emphasis on those arterial roads which are more closely related to national economic objectives. As applies under current Federal road funding arrangements, the distribution of local road funds by a State to local authorities will be determined on the basis of approved principles. These principles, which take account of such factors as population and road length, are agreed between the States and relevant local government associations. From the Federal Government's viewpoint, these arrangements have been working well to date. Finally, in relation to funding matters, the Bill allows for ministerial approval of transfers of money between certain categories. As with current arrangements this will ensure a degree of flexibility within the program.

I now move on to parts III and IV of the Bill, which deal with administrative arrangements. As I outlined earlier, the administrative arrangements described in this Bill and relevant notes on administration represent a significant change from previous programs. In framing these arrangements our main goal was to achieve improved administrative efficiency and so ensure maximum value for each Federal road dollar. In keeping with this objective, new arrangements make a clear distinction between administrative requirements for national roads and those for State and local roads. This Government has consistently held the view that State arterial and local roads are a State and local government responsibility and it should be left to these governments to determine their own expenditure priorities. Under the new program there is to be minimal Federal involvement in the administration of funding for these roads. In the case of national highways and national arterial roads, however, it is imperative to have an administrative system in place which will ensure national standards and objectives are being met on time and within budget.

Under the new program, an important element of this approach will be the introduction of a quality assurance system. States have acknowledged the need to employ quality assurance systems, and the spirit of co- operation between the States and Federal Government on their development has been very good. In essence, the quality assurance approach will enable the Federal Government to satisfy itself that the practices and procedures employed by State and Territory authorities and contractors are efficient from a planning, engineering, administrative and financial perspective. Once this system of quality control is set up periodic assessments will be used to ensure that State and Territory systems continue to perform satisfactorily. A prime element of the quality systems approach will be the introduction of pavement management systems by the States for national highways. This will enable a predictable system of road restoration to be established and ensure that we are spending our roads dollar in the right place at the right time. Quality assurance will allow State road authorities to adopt a more businesslike approach to road construction. Indeed, in some cases, States have already pursued this approach of their own accord. Quality assurance is simply one more step towards the Bill's aim of achieving more for less.

Having explained the basic framework of the revised administrative arrangements, let me briefly outline the remaining significant provisions within the Bill. In accordance with the objectives I have just described, project approval requirements will focus principally on national highways and national arterials, and will not be necessary for expenditure on State arterial or local roads. Arrangements are being developed in cooperation with the States to improve cost estimation procedures and minimise cost overruns. Project approval will continue to apply to both mainline railway projects and urban public transport projects. In the case of mainline railways, funding will be dependent on the project being able to yield significant benefits based on improvements in the capacity, quality or efficiency of operations. Urban public transport projects will aim to reduce traffic on arterial roads in urban areas.

Tendering requirements will apply to the construction of national highways and national arterials and will now be extended to include major rehabilitation works on national highways. For tendering purposes, major rehabilitation works will cover off those works estimated to cost in excess of $2m. Where appropriate, tendering will also apply to mainline railway and urban transport projects. Administrative measures are also being put in place in relation to tendering procedures to reduce the scope for litigation over the final cost of projects. The program will maintain the requirement that State and Territory Governments together with local authorities acknowledge Federal assistance for programs and projects. The Bill also prevents States from levying tolls on national highways or national arterial roads without written ministerial consent.

Finally, the Bill makes provision for the closing of the existing trust funds under the ABRD program and ALTP by 30 April 1989. No excise payments will be made into these funds after 31 December 1988 and special transitional arrangements will apply to moneys paid out of these funds between 1 January and 30 April 1989.

In closing, let me reiterate that the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill is the right response for the economic times of today. It is a balanced and responsible approach to the question of road funding which dovetails neatly with the Government's overall economic strategy. Like all good money managers we have carefully considered our objectives and priorities and then chosen sound investments to match. Initiatives such as the introduction of national arterials and the establishment of quality systems are integral elements of this roads investment package designed to make the roads dollar work harder. There is no doubt that the Government's investments will pay handsome dividends. Not only will these efforts assist our export and import competing industries but there will also be significant benefits for the truckie, the farmer, the motorist-in fact, all roads users.

The current reassessment of Federal road funding forms part of the Government's wider agenda for restructuring in all sectors of the transport industry-road, rail, sea and air. Together these reforms are helping to develop a more efficient, more competitive industry to the betterment of Australia's overall economic performance. In the long run, this will mean greater benefits for all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The new arrangements for the Rural Adjustment Scheme outlined in this Bill represent a landmark both with respect to structural adjustment policy and to the management of Commonwealth/State programs.

The Bill will serve two purposes. It will allow the Rural Adjustment Scheme to operate in a more flexible and innovative way so as to more adequately address the changing structural adjustment forces acting on businesses in the Australian agricultural sector. It will also set in place innovative arrangements for the management of Commonwealth/State programs. Under these arrangements the Commonwealth's role will be restricted to setting broad policy guidelines. The States will have total managerial and financial responsibility. They will only be accountable to the Commonwealth for the effective achievement of the Scheme's objectives.

In a structural adjustment policy sense the Bill recognises that structural adjustment arises from a whole spectrum of reasons ranging from the adoption of exciting new computer and biological technologies through to the painful process of facilitating the exit from the sector of producers who are no longer viable. Adjustment has become an increasingly more significant issue for the farm business because of the greater degree of volatility of external factors it is now likely to face. This volatility arises from a host of circumstances including variability in world commodity prices, exchange rates, interest rates and climatic conditions. Rigid policy responses and smothering administrative regulations cannot cope with this type of variability. Flexibility and adaptability of policy responses are essential in this context.

The Bill also aims at ensuring that structural adjustment assistance does not centre around the provision of short term quick fix solutions or on the treatment of symptoms. Rather, it aims to ensure that attention is given to the longer term result and the causes of problems.

To accomplish these two aspects the Agreement, which is a Schedule to the Bill, sets out clearly defined purposes, objectives and strategies which directly address these aims. Commonwealth and State Ministers will meet annually to determine the priorities for the provision of structural adjustment assistance. They will determine which industries are in particular need of adjustment assistance at any time and, if necessary, the types of farm build-up and farm improvement activities which should receive priority attention. For example, if a series of widespread good years has occurred, Ministers may decide to emphasise the provision of assistance for drought proofing or soil conservation measures directed at giving businesses in the agricultural sector the long term capacity to accommodate climatic variations within their normal operations. Provided productive activities of this type can be identified and implemented, Commonwealth funding of the Scheme need not necessarily decline in good times when demand for funds, due to the impact of variability of costs and output, declines.

To ensure that a long term approach is adopted, the legislation retains the previous Commonwealth commitment to provide funds for seven years. The Commonwealth and the States have developed a range of policy measures with each State having the freedom to choose which measures it will use. For example, some States may wish to engage in limited land trading to facilitate the exit of non-viable farmers from the industry or farm build-up. Other States may decide not to utilise that particular policy measure. The Bill also allows for new policy measures to be developed and implemented in the future to meet changing needs and circumstances.

The role of the Commonwealth will be to develop, in consultation with the States, Ministerial determinations which will set out the broad policy parameters to be applied to each policy instrument. It will be up to the States to develop the management guidelines to govern the use of each policy instrument. This legislation will also allow for variation between the States in the management procedures adopted with respect to specific policy measures.

The third key policy aspect is that there is to be a much stronger emphasis on the notion that farming is first and foremost a business-a business which must be run along sound business management lines if it is to survive and prosper.

Two provisions are made in the Bill specifically to facilitate meeting this objective. Training for farmers is recognised as an appropriate activity to be funded under the Scheme. In addition, provision is made for ongoing funding to improve the quality of financial analysis which is undertaken before assistance is provided to the farmer. In this context, the Bill aims to ensure that the real causes of a farmer's business problems are identified before assistance is provided. Hopefully, this type of analysis will also allow the States to:
integrate the provision of assistance to farm businesses from a number of sources such as the Rural Adjustment Scheme, State extension services, rural counsellors and private financing bodies; and
use a number of the Scheme's assistance measures together, in conjunction with each other, more effectively in order to address the adjustment needs of particular farm businesses.

The other adjustment policy measure incorporated in the legislation which deserves special mention is the new arrangement for the provision of re-establishment assistance under Part C of the Scheme. The new arrangement will enable farmers, whose businesses are clearly not capable of surviving without assistance into the long term, to leave the sector with dignity and to provide a base from which to establish themselves once they have left farming.

To facilitate less traumatic and more dignified adjustment the legislation provides for the payment of a re-establishment grant of up to $28,000 to a farmer leaving the sector. This amount is indexed annually and subject to an assets test (excluding personal effects). A farmer will be able to leave the sector with a maximum of $28,000 of assets plus $28,000 re-establishment grant. As the value of assets rises above $28,000 the re-establishment grant will decline on a dollar for dollar basis.

In association with this, the provision of household support assistance under Part C will be changed in a number of ways including making it available for a maximum of two years. Commonwealth and State Ministers considered this period allowed more than enough time for the farmer, once he or she has taken the decision to leave farming, to sell the business. It was felt that the old arrangements were having a negative adjustment impact and, in some circumstances, may have been eroding the capital base of the farmer's business.

As I have pointed out, structural adjustment policy is not the only matter addressed by the Bill. It is also a landmark piece of legislation in terms of being the first attempt at applying, in the context of co-operative Commonwealth-State relations, the principles of devolution of financial management encapsulated in concepts such as program budgeting and the financial management improvement program.
To implement this devolution, the legislation and Agreement:
include a clear mission statement for the Rural Adjustment Scheme;
provide for the State rural adjustment authority to have sole responsibility for the management and administration of the policy measures available under the Scheme;
provide for the State rural adjustment authority to have total freedom, within the bounds of responsible financial administration, to manage funds provided for the purpose of the Scheme; and

provide for the establishment of a Management Information System to meet the States' own management requirements and to allow them to report to the Commonwealth on the effectiveness of the Scheme's operations.

This approach has been adopted because it has been demonstrated, by the experience of the last three years, that it is impractical for the Commonwealth to control the detailed financial and managerial operations of the State adjustment authorities. As a corollary to these changes it may, of course, be necessary for the States to improve the quality of resources available to their adjustment authorities.

The mission statement contained in the statement of purposes and objectives set out in the Agreement will, as I have already pointed out, change the policy focus of the Scheme. It will aid more effective operation and management of the Scheme. It will allow ends and means to be more directly related. It will allow for more efficient usage of funds. It will also aid the States in their accounting to the Commonwealth for the effective operation of the Scheme.

The legislation will allow the State adjustment authorities maximum management freedom. Policy guidelines will be determined by the Commonwealth; the responsibility for establishing and operating the management arrangements for effectively implementing these policies so as to achieve the Scheme's objectives will rest with the States. The Commonwealth will not have any part to play in the management process but it will participate in regular meetings of State adjustment authority officers to provide for exchanges of information on management priorities and hence the more effective operation of the Scheme.

The financial management of funds provided under the Scheme will also rest entirely with State adjustment authorities. They will, of course, need to have their annual accounts audited by a registered auditor in accordance with Australian Auditing Standards. The radical degree of financial and managerial freedom allowed to State adjustment authorities under the legislation will, no doubt, require auditors to consider carefully the nature of the auditing activities they undertake. Equally, I expect that State adjustment authorities will incorporate adequate fraud control measures into their managerial arrangements.

The legislation, as part of this greater financial management freedom, will allow the State adjustment authorities to retain, within the Scheme, current and future surpluses earned under the Scheme and will require them to take over responsibility for the provision of funds to meet possible bad debts incurred under the Scheme since its inception in 1985.

The last aspect of greater financial freedom for the State adjustment authorities will result form the States being given a single pool of funds under Part A of the Scheme. The Commonwealth will no longer determine the proportions of funds to be used for particular types of activity under the Scheme. It will not set nominal maximum interest rates for the use of Part A funds. Also, where appropriate, there will be greater freedom for Part A funds to be used to facilitate adjustment under Part C of the Scheme. In this context, I have in mind the new policy provisions for land trading on a limited scale.

State Ministers have accepted that the greater degree of policy flexibility and the total managerial and financial freedom allowed under this legislation, carries with it the responsibility to ensure, and account for, the effective achievement of the Scheme's objectives.

I cannot stress too much this requirement for accountability. A State which misuses this freedom, for example, to distort the Scheme's objectives or to shift the risk of other State activities onto the Scheme, will lose access to Commonwealth funds.

It is for this reason, and also to facilitate more efficient management by State adjustment authorities, that the Commonwealth and the States have agreed to set up a compatible Management Information System for the Scheme. Under this arrangement the States will provide the Commonwealth with data on the operations and finances of the Scheme in an electronic form. This will considerably reduce the State adjustment authorities' reporting workload.

The Commonwealth will undertake its own analysis of this data to evaluate the effectiveness of the Scheme's operations. The reports prepared as a result of this work will be provided to the State adjustment authorities and where appropriate to the Commonwealth Auditor-General, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Department of Finance.
Three provisions of the new Bill will impact on the amount of funds provided to the States under the Scheme.
An additional $1.2 million will be provided in 1988-89 to allow the States to improve the quality of financial analysis which is undertaken before assistance is provided to the farmer.

The new arrangements for Part C will mean some reduction in household support payments but larger payment for re-establishment assistance. It is not possible to assess how these two factors will balance out but it should be noted that funding for Part C remains open-ended.
The new arrangements for meeting State administrative expenses are expected to result in a saving to the Commonwealth of $0.4 million in 1988-89.
New Part A funding will remain unchanged in 1988-89 at $6.7 million.
In closing I would like to make three other points.

Firstly, I would like to congratulate the consulting firm Coopers and Lybrand W. D. Scott for the excellent report they prepared reviewing the existing arrangements for the operation of the Rural Adjustment Scheme. That report played a key part in the development of this legislation.

Secondly, I wish to reiterate that the purpose of this Scheme is to allow effective structural adjustment to take place in farm business enterprises. It is not aimed at keeping farmers on the land. Using the Scheme to prop up farm businesses that are not viable in the long term is not on. The Scheme is aimed at making farm businesses independent of assistance as soon as possible or, if this cannot occur, help farmers to leave the sector with dignity. The retention of farming as a desirable lifestyle will be a result of effective management of farm businesses and effective adjustment, not an objective of it.
Finally, I would point out that this Scheme is only part of a package of measures, pursued both at the Commonwealth and the State level, to achieve effective adjustment.

At the Commonwealth level other measures which are part of the agricultural adjustment process include tariff adjustment, the funding of research and development, assistance for education in rural areas, the rural counselling scheme, Country Link and the Country Towns Water Supply Improvement Program.
There are also relevant programs at the State level; for example, extension services have a key role to play.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill is intended to provide the legal procedures that will apply to Government acquisition activities in the transition from the operation of the current Act, the Lands Acquisition Act 1955, and the commencement of the Lands Acquisition Act 1988. Provision is also made in the legislation for amendments to be made to existing Acts where necessary so that the existing powers and functions of authorities under their enabling legislation is not affected.

In my second reading speech to Parliament on the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 I identified significant benefits to individuals that can be expected to occur as a result of passage into law of the new lands acquisition legislation. You will be aware that the legislation in general provides for the acquisition process:
to be more open to public scrutiny;
to provide individual landowners rights of appeal to the administrative appeals tribunal of the decision to acquire the land;
to require that Commonwealth acquiring authorities meet set time limits in carrying out acquisition activities; and
to provide landowners recourse to more comprehensive compensation provisions in respect of Commonwealth acquisition activities.
The Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 has the interests of individuals as its primary focus.

The Government is concerned that the benefits of the new provisions of that Bill should be applied as soon as possible to landowners affected by Commonwealth acquisition initiatives. This Bill has been drafted to give effect to that intention by applying the provisions of the new Act as much as possible to acquisitions initiated but not completed by the Commonwealth under existing legislation.
I would like to take the opportunity to comment on some provisions of the Bill which most exemplify the Government's intentions in this area.

Clauses 7 and 8 are probably the most significant clauses in the Bill. They provide that where the Commonwealth has initiated action to acquire an interest in land but negotiations have not been concluded and the interest has not been acquired by the time the 1988 Act commences, then those acquisitions will be undertaken according to the 1988 Act. This applies to acquisitions both by agreement and by compulsory process and implies for example that the property owners would be issued with a pre acquisition declaration giving them the right to appeal the decision to acquire their properties.

Clause 8 of the Bill also provides that where an owner's land was compulsorily acquired after 25 May 1988 even if the acquisition had been completed under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 compensation will be assessed according to the provisions of the 1988 Act. If compensation has already been assessed and paid according to the 1955 Act and the owner would be entitled to a greater amount of compensation under the provisions of the new legislation compared to the amount applicable under the 1955 Act then this additional amount will be paid to the owner.

The specified date in this provision is pertinent because it was on that date that the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 was introduced into Parliament identifying the proposed new compensation entitlements.

Section 9 of the Bill provides that persons whose land the Commonwealth had entered onto and/or temporarily occupied in the three year period prior to repeal of the 1955 Act will be entitled to compensation in accordance with the provisions of the 1988 Act.

When the Commonwealth compulsorily acquires property in some instances the former owner is able to remain in possession for a time. This is provided for in a general way in the 1955 Act but the details of any agreement are typically arranged between the Commonwealth and the former owner on an individual case basis. The 1988 Act makes specific provision for this to happen and section 11 of this Bill provides that persons in possession of such land under an agreement with the Commonwealth immediately before the commencement of the 1988 Act will have extended to them the protection of the more detailed occupancy provisions of section 47 of the 1988 Act.

This Bill also amends several existing acts. The general intention behind most of those amendments is to retain the status quo in terms of ministerial responsibilities. The need arises because the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 is far more precise than the 1955 Act in specifying what activities will be bound by it with exceptions having to be precisely identified.

In some other instances the amendments substitute a reference to the 1988 Act for a reference to the 1955 Act. I would like however to make some broad observations about particular categories of legislation and the relationship of those Acts to the Lands Acquisition Act 1988.

Honourable senators will note that there is a group of Acts being amended by this Bill which deal with Aboriginal communities. These Acts provide to such communities, through Aboriginal councils and land trusts, limited powers to deal in land. In general, amendments to these individual acts are intended to preserve these powers despite the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1988 and where applicable to provide that existing provision in these acts for the issue of licences for mining and exploration of minerals shall continue to apply regardless of anything contained in the Lands Acquisition Act 1988.

The Government has decided that certain authorities or instrumentalities should be able to operate in a totally commercial environment and so should not be bound by the requirement of the Commonwealth's general land acquisition legislation. Bodies such as the Defence Housing Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation are examples of such organisations. Amendments to the enabling legislation of such organisations are being made to alter references to the 1955 Act to be references to the 1988 Act retaining that commercial independence. I would like honourable senators to note that such amendments proposed in this Bill only preserve existing powers and do not confer any additional legislative powers to the authorities involved.

Individual amendments to other Acts are varied in nature in terms of the result to be achieved. However, as I have noted earlier, these amendments do not introduce any new policy initiatives by government and are purely intended to preserve the `status quo' where the new Lands Acquisition Act 1988 might otherwise introduce change.

This Bill is complementary to, and is a necessary part of, the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 legislative package. Passage of this Bill will allow the new legislation to be implemented without undue delay.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the main purpose of this Bill is to permit faster migration clearance of overseas passengers at airports. It flows from the Government's Master Plan for Passenger Processing at Australia's airports.
It is the Government's objective to provide visitors to Australia and Australian travellers fast and efficient service at our international airports.

The amendments contained in this Bill will provide that visas issued overseas will become an entry permit on entering Australia at an international airport; pre-cleared flights to operate to Australia; and safeguards of records and data bases which impact on immigration processing of passengers.

In addition, the opportunity was taken to make some consequential amendments to the Migration Act flowing from the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987. This amendment relates essentially to the redefinition of entry permit to clarify the status of statutory visitors.

The Government has been concerned for some time to ensure that legislative and administrative requirements for entry to and departure from Australia keep pace with the demands of our burgeoning tourism industry. At the same time, we are concerned to maintain the necessary safeguards as to who enters Australia.

My Department has embarked on a comprehensive program of computerising many of the manual processes associated with visa issue and entry permit issue. The Department has also put in place systems whereby data obtained at visa issue is brought to Australia and used to facilitate entry processes.

The progressive computerisation of visa issue at major overseas posts in the past 18 months has enabled dramatic improvements to be made in the levels of service provided. Typically at our major tourist source posts we now offer an across the counter service where that is sought and a 24 hour service in all other cases. Computerisation has produced significant productivity gains and reduced demands for extra staff to meet the dramatic growth we have seen in tourism to Australia.

Officials in my Department have recently demonstrated the Australian visa system at the International Civil Aviation Authority Facilitation meeting in Montreal where the Australian visa format was adopted as the world standard.

More recently, the Government has addressed the issue of movements of people through our international airports. That review jointly chaired by my department and the Australian Customs Service and involving all agencies associated with movements through our airports as well as representatives of the airlines and the tourism industry, culminated in endorsement by government of a Master Plan for passenger processing at Australian airports. My colleague, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business and I jointly gave some details of the Government's decisions on 8 September.
The Master Plan will result in a wide range of adjustments to processes and procedures applied by the range of agencies impacting on movements through airports.

As far as my portfolio is concerned we have sought to reduce the range of formalities associated with the entry/departure processes. We have sought to simplify decision processes without jeopardising the controls necessary in Australia's wider national interests.
The most significant step is to put in place a system, whereby a visa obtained for travel to Australia will, on entering Australia, unless cancelled operate as an entry permit.

Under current arrangements persons wishing to enter Australia must first obtain a visa. Upon arrival in Australia the holder of that visa may or may not be granted an entry permit pursuant to the provisions of the Migration Act. If granted an entry permit the person then enters Australia.

The new arrangements flowing from this Bill will provide for a system whereby a person will hold only one document which will serve a double purpose, that is, it will be a visa for the purpose of travel to Australia and an entry permit after entry to Australia at a proclaimed airport.

The present Act provides for entry permits to be in a form and specify conditions as determined by the Minister. No similar discretions exist in terms of the visa. The Bill seeks to inject the necessary discretion to enable the determination of visa conditions.

There will be a need to fix the date and place of entry into Australia. Such a provision is necessary from the viewpoint of both the holder of the visa and the department. For example as proof of entitlement to remain in Australia within the currency of the visa/entry permit or as proof of entry at a proclaimed airport. The Bill proposes the use of the current port and date stamp and departmental computer records as a prima facie evidence of arrival.

The present stand alone entry permits provisions will need to continue for several reasons: first, the new arrangements are only to operate in respect of entries at proclaimed airports which handle the bulk of travellers; secondly, to take account of persons who apply for change of status, that is permanent entry status after arrival as a temporary entrant. The third reason is that there will have to be transitional provisions to take account of the fact that not all persons travelling to, and entering Australia, will be holders of a visa in the new form. Additionally, present arrangements regarding fee collection for permit renewal and for issue of resident return visas will remain.

The concept of pre-clearance or the performance of immigration entry procedures offshore has been under consideration for some time. The concept involves the disembarkation of flights at other than international airports subject to satisfaction of health, quarantine and customs considerations. The concept provided for in the Bill is for individual designated flights flying non-stop from a place of departure to Australia. Passengers on these flights would be examined and immigration cleared for entry prior to departure for Australia. Upon disembarkation, they would enter Australia without further immigration formalities.
It is proposed to provide that a stamp in the form indicating the date, airport and country of departure for Australia will be placed in the passport of a traveller embarking on a pre-cleared flight.
If a pre-cleared flight lands at any other country prior to arrival in Australia the pre-clearance has no effect. Passengers would then be processed in the usual way.
The amendments empower the Minister for Immigration to proclaim flights for the purposes of pre-clearance.

Given the pivotal role of electronic records and systems in my department's task in processing passengers, it is necessary to guarantee the integrity of such records and systems. This is essential in securing the general confidence in the new system. The Bill therefore provides that perusal of alteration of records and systems associated with passenger processing be limited to authorised officers in the performance of their duty and provides penalties for breach of these provisions.

The further consequential amendments flowing from the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987 seek to place a statutory visitor who might be granted an entry permit on a equal footing with other entry permit holders. The adjustments contained in the present Bill essentially correct oversights in the initial consequential legislation.

Mr President, the package of provisions in this Bill, as they relate to the important task of passenger processing at Australia's international airports, provides the legislative base for the progressive introduction of a system of passenger processing which is arguably the most advanced in the world.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

The major amendment to the definition of an agency includes what we believe is a serious oversight by the Government; that is, the private sector. During either the debate on the second reading motion or an earlier participation in the committee stage debate I pointed out that there is a serious problem with regard to the privacy of information contained within the private sector. During the second reading debate we heard all sorts of paranoid comments about the tax file number legislation and about what officers in the Australian Taxation Office were likely to do. The fact remains that ever since that agency has come into operation the privacy of the information contained within that section of the Department has been protected, and I think protected very well. The Australian Taxation Office has a good record of protecting the privacy of information.

There is not such a good record in the private sector. Newspaper reports from time to time indicate that, for malicious reasons or otherwise, people feed incorrect information into, say, credit reference bureaus so that somebody's credit rating is diminished and he or she perhaps cannot get a loan from somewhere else. Even if the Privacy Bill were standing alone, one would have thought, in the interests of a broad sweep, that the Government would wish to pick up the private sector. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not prepared to accept the amendments. SPEECH.PARA: It has been a feature of some surprise to me in the last couple of weeks that the private sector has apparently accepted the guidelines set down in schedule 2 as appropriate, whereas previously the Government had envisaged that there would be a period of consultation between the Privacy Commissioner, aided by the consultative committee which would be established and be representative of users as well as those concerned with privacy issues, and the private sector. Even without that consultation, the Parliament has devised a series of guidelines which will, from the proclamation of this legislation, apply to the private sector. I am sure that will take some adjustment by the private sector right from day one. To add to that, the proposition that the private sector be bound by the information privacy principles (IPPs), which is what Senator Haines's proposition amounts to, would be to impose too much at this stage on the private sector.

Of course, that is not to say that some of the arguments put forward by Senator Haines do not have some weight. Indeed, it will be known by honourable senators that the Privacy Commissioner has been given a specific function of encouraging corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information consistent with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is like trying to encourage affirmative action. They do it if they feel like it and they don't if they don't.
—Well, under clause 27 (1) (n), the Commissioner has the following functions:

SPEECH.PARA: to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information that are consistent with the Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data issued by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development;

It is in that process, and in the reporting by the Privacy Commissioner to the Parliament in his annual report, that the Parliament will then be best placed to make an assessment as to how the application of privacy principles to the full range of the private sector might take place within the constitutional limits of Commonwealth power. It is one thing to impose the information privacy principles on Commonwealth agencies, in relation to which we have full constitutional power and therefore responsibility and the operation of which we have a real understanding of. But if this Parliament were to impose information privacy principles immediately on the private sector within the constitutional limits indicated by the Australian Democrats' amendments, without the benefit of some experience of how in the various sectors of the private sector these principles might best be made to operate, we would probably create a regulatory regime which would not work and would not be satisfactory from the point of view of either those in the private sector who have such information or those within the community who fear that their privacy might be invaded by the misuse, abuse and wrongful disclosure of information held by private sector record keepers.

I emphasise that the guidelines proposed by the Parliament in relation to tax file number information will apply to employers and financial institutions to whom tax file number information can be properly disclosed. In relation to the information privacy principles, I believe that, with the assistance of the Privacy Commissioner and in the light of the reports of the Privacy Commissioner to the Parliament, the Parliament will be well placed to make an assessment of the extent to which further IPPs might be applied in the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note what the Minister says, namely that clause 27 (1) gives the Privacy Commissioner a range of functions, including one to encourage corporations to develop programs, and clause 27 (2) goes on to say that `The Commissioner has power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of his or her functions under subsection (1)'. What exactly does that mean? What powers does the Commissioner have? Who decides what is necessary? And, for heaven's sake, what does `convenient' mean? Does it mean if the Commissioner has time to do it, or if the company has time to do it, or if it suits the company to do it? Who defines what `necessary' is? Necessary to whom? Necessary to the company, to the individuals employed by the company, to the Commissioner, or to the Government-to whom? How long do we give a company to get its act together in this way? How do we make the company come to the decision that it needs to act in this way?

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that there is a company in Australia that has even heard of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) guidelines, much less has a copy of them. Is the Government going to provide every company in the private sector in Australia with a copy of the OECD guidelines, or somehow communicate to them that they have to get them? It is fine to say in a piece of legislation, `we are going to encourage people'. One can put down a plate of mashed pumpkin and peas in front of a three-year-old and stand to one side and say, `Darling, I am encouraging you to eat this'. As a mother, I can tell honourable senators that one will get a long way fast. What we have confronting us is the private sector privacy problem that equates to mashed pumpkin. If the Government does not give the private sector companies a reason for doing it, they are not going to do it. How are we going to get the Commissioner to impose on corporations these requirements to develop programs? What sorts of programs? What proof do we need that they are undertaking a program? How long do we give them to get that program under way? What sanctions are there if people say, `Bother you; we are not going to eat the pumpkin-we are not going to put into practice, or even develop, a program for protecting privacy or a program for handling records of personal information.'?

This has to be one of the most meaningless clauses of this legislation, because it does nothing. It says the Commissioner has, amongst a series of other functions, the power to encourage; and, furthermore, to give that encouragement in line with guidelines on the protection of privacy and trans-border flows of personal data issued by the OECD. I would be fascinated to hear from the Minister how this is going to be achieved. I know he has some extremely capable advisers sitting on his left, but I think this stretches even their capabilities. Could they please give me some idea of how the Commissioner is going to go about this encouragement, what he is going to do if nobody does anything about it, what help he is going to give corporations-if any-in doing something about it if they choose to do something about it, and how long we have to wait before the Government decides that simple encouragement is not going to work?

The Minister mentioned court actions. He said maybe we should give other parts of the legislation a chance to work before we give people the option of taking things to court. It may be that before I came into this place I was a touch naive, but that was quickly knocked out of me. By and large, corporations do not do things unless they have to. That is why we have tax laws, and even then half the corporations in the country do not pay any tax because we also give them ways of wriggling out of it and then complain about the fact that our surplus is not high enough to help people in need. Is this going to be the same sort of thing? Are we going to write into the legislation that the Commissioner can encourage corporations to do things according to OECD guidelines and say, rather hopefully in the next subclause, that he has all the powers necessary or convenient-whatever that may mean-to encourage these programs, but not put any sting in the tail of it all? What is the point of it?

I repeat: can the Minister tell me how the Commissioner goes about this? What happens when people do not get encouraged? What are `all things that are necessary' and, much more important, what are `all things that are convenient'? And, for whom? And how much of the Commissioner's time is going to be expended on encouraging private companies large and small to protect the personal information about people that is contained in their records?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps one of the problems Senator Haines had in bringing up her children was that she wanted them to eat their mashed pumpkin while it was still hot. She did not allow it time to cool down. She is a `things have to be done right now' sort of woman. I am a great believer in letting things cool down. Perhaps her children would have developed a taste for cold mashed pumpkin. I certainly prefer cold soup to hot soup.
—Tell us about your knowledge of child rearing.

—By the way, I am a bachelor. What I am trying to say is that I believe this legislation goes a long way to starting a process of bringing the private sector into line with the need to ensure that the privacy of individuals in relation to information that is required from them is properly safeguarded. I have indicated that that is certainly the case in relation to tax file number information. In relation to more general privacy matters, perhaps I should have emphasised that clause 27 (1) (n) gives the Commissioner the function of encouraging corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information and clause 27 (2) is the normal standard form of clause which, the functions having been outlined in clause 27 (1), confers on the Commissioner the power to undertake all those actions which are necessary or convenient in order to perform those functions. It is a perfectly straightforward and well understood form of conferring a power on a person who previously has been vested with certain functions and tasks to undertake.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be of interest to remind honourable senators of a part of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report, Feasibility of a National ID Scheme: The Tax File Number. The Committee, of which Senator Hill I believe was a distinguished member, concluded at paragraph 7.27:

. . . the Committee recommends that the question of the possible regulation of the private sector by privacy legislation be referred to the privacy watchdog, which the Committee recommends be established, for investigation.

I think that is the correct approach, as I have indicated, and I want to emphasise in relation to that particular function which is given to the privacy watchdog that under the clause which requires the Privacy Commissioner to report to the Parliament there is an express requirement-one of only two or three-that he report in relation to the operation of clause 27 (1) (n). I believe the fact that the Privacy Commissioner will be hereby empowered to devise strategies to encourage corporations to adhere to these principles-which, by the way, were devised by a committee chaired by Mr Justice Michael Kirby for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)-will add to the effectiveness of the legislation in the sense that the private sector, which will be approached by the Privacy Commissioner, will know that the Parliament intends to take a particular interest in its voluntary adherence to these particular OECD principles, and it will be on notice that it is the Parliament's intention to put that particular function of the Privacy Commissioner under particular scrutiny. I believe that that is a sufficient position to have reached at this stage in the development of privacy legislation in Australia. For that reason, as I say, the Government will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As much as I would like to repay Senator Haines's courtesy, the Opposition had to decide the question of this amendment on its merits. We will oppose the amendment. However, I hope that in a few moments I will have an opportunity to repay Senator Haines's courtesy in relation to some of her other amendments. After listening to Senator Tate, it seems that the Opposition, like the Government, has adopted a cautious approach in this matter. Obviously it is an issue that was debated within the Opposition, just as it was an issue which was debated within the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as was just mentioned by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). The Opposition reached the same conclusion as that Senate Committee did, which is basically that it would be a mistake to rush into attempting to effectively bind the private sector in relation to these privacy principles and that rather a step-by-step approach should be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that, principally, we also adopted the same type of arguments that were mentioned by the Senate Committee, such as concerns about a cost-benefit analysis. As far as we could determine, there has been no real analysis of the cost to the private sector of this exercise. Nor has there been an assessment to weigh those costs against potential benefits. We were also concerned about the constitutionality of the proposal. I note that Senator Haines has made efforts to ensure that her amendment falls within the constitutional capacity of the Commonwealth which, of course, means that partnerships are not included, sole traders are not included, and presumably--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are stuck with the Constitution, Senator.

—Well, from time to time, I have supported amendments to the Constitution, but they do not get passed very often. This really means that a two-tiered approach is needed to effectively bind the private sector: the Commonwealth passes legislation within its constitutional capacity and the States pick up what is left. Of course, that concern was raised by the Australian Law Reform Commission when it prepared its report on privacy. The Commission recommended that the private sector should relate to only the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and external Territories. As I have just indicated, Senator Haines has gone one step further than that. Nevertheless, I am sure that she would not claim that her amendment covers the field. So that is a further reason we think the matter should be further considered. We believe that, although there is a great deal of personal information held within the private sector, the level is nothing like that which is held by the public sector, and that factor came out during the considerations of the Senate Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair to say that we were all stunned not only at the volume of personal information held by government but also at the ease with which it is transferred from department to department and from agency to agency. Therefore, as a committee that represented all parties in this chamber, we believed that the real goal, at least in the first instance, would be to put down a Bill that would bind the public sector and, therefore, the private sector could be looked at at a later date. I guess we also took into account the additional argument that much of this information is gained under compulsory powers in the public sector. This is not the case in the private sector, although if one does not supply financial information one does not receive, say, a bank loan. Therefore, effectively, although the situation might not be very different, technically much of the private sector information is gained at the peril of committing an offence and suffering a penalty if the information is not provided. So it seemed to us that there was a greater obligation to use care in relation to that information and therefore-in a cautious step-by-step approach-the first target had to be the public sector.

The Opposition is not ruling out for ever an extension into the private sector. We believe it is a matter that should be reviewed in due course. We note the recommendation of the Senate Committee, that is, that the new privacy watchdog-the Privacy Commissioner in this instance-should give consideration to private sector provisions. We think that would be a worthwhile exercise in due course. If we had more basic information upon which to make a cost-benefit analysis in the future, perhaps we could be more confident in determining a position on the private sector in the future.

Finally, I agree with the argument of Senator Haines in relation to clause 27 (1) (n). I know that it was raised by the Minister, I guess not as an alternative but nevertheless in an attempt to indicate that some effort has been made in relation to the private sector. I would not place any great faith in that provision advancing the issue any further whatsoever. It seems to me that it is one of those additional `sound good' provisions that are added to a clause, that do not primarily relate to the principal function of the legislation but which, nevertheless, are useful in that Ministers can refer to them in debates such as this. I do not think such a provision will advance us much further in this instance. As I have said, the Opposition decided, obviously after considerable debate, to adopt a more cautious approach in relation to the private sector and, therefore, as I have indicated, we will not support the Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed but not surprised at Senator Hill's approach. Unlike him, I think it is better that we go part of the way down the track rather than not go any of the way at all. Simply because we cannot reach the end of the exercise is no real justification for not picking up part of the problem. We do not make other decisions with regard to legislation in this place because only those groups in the community that the Federal heads of power are able to deal with are picked up. We did not not proceed with sex discrimination legislation, for example, because it covered only those public and private organisations that the Federal Government had some jurisdiction over.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill argues, apparently, that, while there is some intrinsic merit in our amendment to include the private sector in the purview of this legislation, the Liberal Party will not support the amendment, for what I gather are three reasons: first, that it does not go far enough; secondly, the time is not right; and, thirdly, it will be costly to the private sector to pick up. If we stopped passing legislation in this place simply because there was some cost to the organisations to which the legislation applied, we would never get through anything here. Of course, there will be costs.

Regulations protecting consumers or small businesses from predatory big businesses involve cost. All sorts of measures that we take in this place impose some costs on organisations. The collection of payroll tax, or even ordinary taxes, imposes costs on organisations. They habitually use it as a tax deduction; so the taxpayer ends up funding at least half of it. We all know what happens when there is some sort of cost involved in an organisation complying with government legislation and regulations-it passes that on to the consumer. The Minister said that he believes that this report process goes a long way towards starting the process of including the private sector in the purview of this legislation. While getting into a car might go a long way towards starting the process of travelling somewhere, in itself it achieves nothing. Again, I ask the Minister whether he can give some indication of what procedures the Commissioner will actually undertake in order to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information. Furthermore, how will they be encouraged to do that in a manner that is consistent with Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With due respect, I think Senator Haines is being unduly filled with foreboding by what is really an attempt in this particular definition to take account of the fact that personal information about an individual can cover such a wide range of matters that it has been necessary to cast the definition in a way which does not allow an argument to be raised to the effect that the information that is held is really not personal information because it does not name a person or perhaps have a unique identifier, or something like that.
