TALK.START.PARA: —The structure of the Bill provides that in the normal situation under clause 36 (1):

SPEECH.PARA: An individual may complain to the Privacy Commissioner about an act or practice that may interfere with the privacy of the individual.

Senator Haines asks, `Well, what if an act or practice which indeed amounts to an interference with the privacy of an individual is nevertheless not properly the subject of a complaint by the individual concerned because of a mixture of identities or some such thing?'. It might be worth looking at clause 27 (1) (a), combined with the very powerful clause 27 (2), which allows the Commissioner to do all things that are necessary or convenient to carry out his or her functions. Clause 27 (1) (a) says that the Commissioner, in effect, can:

investigate an act or practice of an agency that may breach an Information Privacy Principle and, where the Commissioner considers it appropriate to do so, to endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matters that gave rise to the investigation.

I believe that that would enable the Privacy Commissioner to undertake an investigation of an act or practice without the need for it to be triggered by a particular complainant correctly identifying herself as the victim of an improper disclosure of information held.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —(South Australia-Leader of the Australian Democrats) (6.16)-I thank the Minister. I am not 100 per cent convinced but I guess that I never will be. I want to move on to the definition of `tax file number information'. On page 6 of the Bill it is defined as meaning:

SPEECH.PARA: information (including information forming part of a database), whether compiled lawfully or unlawfully, and whether recorded in a material form or not, that records the tax file number of a person in a manner connecting it with the person's identity.

It worries me that we are acknowledging that information is or may be collected unlawfully and put on some form of database. In any event, as it stands, the definition of `tax file number information' seems to mean information that records the tax file number of a person in a way connecting it with the person's identity. This necessarily excludes information which is associated with the tax file number-or tax file numbers, because with business and corporation structures people are legitimately likely to have more than one-recorded in a way which is not connected with a person's identity but which can be linked to a person's identity via other information in the record. Either way, it seems that the original record does not constitute tax file number information. The Bill does not control its collection, storage, use and security.

I am particularly concerned about the security of the information which lawfully or unlawfully may be collected. Let me tell honourable senators why. Quite recently I had a complaint from a constituent drawn to my attention. The constituent placed an advertisement for a room to let in her house for the period of the Grand Prix in Adelaide. She received a long phone call from a person claiming to be a Canberra public servant. That phone call included questions about her attitude to homosexuality; in other words, presumably whether she would mind if the person renting the house were a homosexual. Some time later she received a letter written on the letterhead of a Queanbeyan hotel, but posted in Canberra, from this apparent public servant, who identified himself only by his first name. The letter contained reference to her Department of Social Security (DSS) benefit number and her account number with the State Bank of South Australia. The constituent, I might add, did not give the person who phoned, claiming to be a Canberra public servant, her address. She has a silent phone number. Her phone number, name and address are not linked in any public document such as the phone book. The phone number was in the advertisement, but that did not in any way provide the additional information. She had given him her name, obviously, when he rang up. So the two pieces of information that he had at the end of the phone call were her phone number and her name. Presumably, if he knew the prefix of the phone number and assumed that it was not a business number, the use of the electoral roll would have been sufficient to get that information. The public servant went on to say that soon he would be going on 12 months leave, that he was a professional gambler and that he was looking for somewhere close to the Adelaide casino to stay for the period of that leave. Remarks contained in the letter were to the effect, `If you don't tell Big Brother, neither will I'. Perhaps the Minister can confirm this most extraordinary situation. I have the name of the woman concerned and her phone number. I would be delighted if somebody took up this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you refer it to the police?

—There has been some suggestion from her that the police actually referred her to me in the first place, presumably because it is a Federal breach, not a State breach, and the State police force is not in a position to act. All I can say is that this constituent approached my office having had what is supposedly confidential information made available to this individual. Clearly, she reported it to the police. The police may well have said that they cannot do anything about it because it is outside their State jurisdiction.
—The Federal Police will investigate. On the facts that you have given there would be a fair chance of identifying the person.

—That is fine. I would be happy if the Australian Federal Police (AFP) picked it up. I have received this information only today and I have not had an opportunity to pass it on to the AFP. If the Minister wishes to do so in his capacity, I will pass on the relevant details to him. The point I am trying to make is that we are dealing with a lot of additional information in this legislation that is supposed to be protected by the privacy legislation but which may well not be. While there are legal avenues open to people after the event, or before it if one is clairvoyant or gets a tip-off, the security of information is not necessarily assured. Here is a case where a silent phone number is involved and still somebody was apparently in a position to trace enough information to come up with this woman's social security benefit number and, of all things, her account number with the State Bank, presumably because that is on the DSS form for purposes of assessing other income for means test use.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the Minister to give us some assurances that there will be sufficient security of information contained under the definition `tax file number information' and all the clauses of the legislation that relate to that to prevent this sort of thing happening. Clearly, it can happen. We know that it can happen. Earlier I said that Telecom Australia had gone out of its way to discredit the credit rating of an individual who unknowingly owed Telecom money. It is all very well to say that at the moment we do not have privacy legislation in place and that apparently there is no immediate recourse to justice, much less compensation, for the two cases that I have mentioned. But I am not at all satisfied, and neither should those who are likely to vote on this issue be satisfied, that any information-however we define it and however we attach it to other people-is secure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The illustration that Senator Haines used raises many questions, including the true identity of the person who claimed to be a public servant and who initiated a telephone call in response to an advertisement apparently placed in relation to accommodation for the Grand Prix. I do not think we ought to jump to the conclusion immediately that the person properly described himself or is properly described as a public servant.
—I did not say he was; I said he claimed he was.
—I know that and I acknowledge it. I will certainly take--
—It is worse if others have access to this information.

—That is right. It is an extraordinary instance and whatever information Senator Haines has had faxed to her today from, I take it, her Adelaide office should perhaps be made available so the matter can be investigated. This sort of thing is normally raised in the adjournment debate. In accordance with adjournment debate practice, I will take the information--
—It is relevant to this.
—I know. All I can do at the moment is take such information as Senator Haines feels she can make available to me, with the permission of the constituent concerned, and have it investigated.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to tax file number information, this Parliament, in passing this Bill-if it chooses so to legislate-is trying to achieve, as far as possible, the sorts of safeguards that have been spoken of by including, in schedule 2, the guidelines which were not in the Bill as originally introduced. Clearly, the Government's first preferred position was to leave the matter rather bare, allowing the Privacy Commissioner, after consultation with the public and private sectors-using the consultative committee as much as possible-to devise guidelines in relation to the security, collection, storage and use of tax file number information. That was not satisfactory. We have tried to go a step further by the Parliament itself setting down interim guidelines concerning the proper protection of tax file number information. I believe that those guidelines, whilst in somewhat general terms, do indicate the important steps in achieving that safeguarding of tax file number information. I believe that in setting them down, the Parliament has gone a long way to indicating the manner in which it believes the general principle of the legislation ought to be achieved in practice.

The guidelines, which are subject to improvement and modification and will be brought back to the Parliament, and particularly this chamber, and the Privacy Commissioner's second thoughts, if you like, on those guidelines, will come into operation only if this chamber decides they should. They may either supplement or displace the interim guidelines in schedule 2. I believe that we have a structure which indicates, at least in the beginning, how tax file number information might be better protected. It is certainly an improvement on the original Bill and helps to allay at least some of the fears that can be aroused when one looks at a bare section of an Act without the benefit of this fleshing out of the guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was discussing schedule 2 in relation to the definition of `tax file number information' in clause 6 of the Bill before us. I had raised some concerns about the security of that information, citing a particularly unfortunate example that had been drawn to the attention of my office whereby an alleged Commonwealth public servant had been able to match information on a woman from her name and her unlisted telephone number. The Minister drew my attention to schedule 2, the interim guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. I have to say that this does not allay my concerns in any real sense because all the way through this schedule the phrase `all reasonable steps' is used. In schedule 2, paragraph 2.2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax file number recipients collecting tax file number information shall take all reasonable steps in the circumstances to ensure that the manner of collection takes account of the rights of persons to control the accumulation and dissemination of information relating to themselves.

Again, I am not exactly sure what `the rights of persons' as a phrase is defined as, nor how people are in a position to control the accumulation, much less the dissemination of information relating to themselves. Given the problems that I raised earlier about the definition of `personal information' itself, I wonder exactly what the term `information relating to themselves' means. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the guidelines which are set out in Schedule 2 have to be seen as supplementary to the very stringent sanctions outlined in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. Indeed, the Bills have been debated cognately for that very reason. In the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill it is very clearly set out, for example, that a person shall not divulge or communicate another person's tax file number to a third person other than in the lawfully prescribed way set out in the Bill. We have there, obviously, as is proper for this very important safeguarding of tax file number matters, a criminal law regime. A penalty of $10,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both, is a sanction applied to breach of the relevant clauses in the legislation, such that a very precise obligation is laid on a person in relation to safeguarding tax file number information in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2 of the Privacy Bill provides for a fleshing out of the prudent steps which ought to be taken by a government agency, an employer or a financial institution in the private sector as further safeguards to the tax file number information, and quite practical guidelines for its storage, security, protection and so on. The Parliament will be without the benefit of the normal consultation process between the Privacy Commissioner and the advisory committee that is outlined in the Bill to aid his deliberations. Nevertheless, the steps are set down and the phrase `all reasonable steps', which occurs from time to time, is, I believe, a very sensible recognition of the fact that, unlike in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, in this situation what we require of employers and financial institutions in the private sector is a reasonable regime of further safeguards, protections and precautions-prudent practices that they might undertake in order to safeguard the tax file number information.

As the Privacy Commissioner and the rest of the community become more used to the problems that might be thrown up in the proper storage, security and disclosure of tax file number information, the refinements and the more precise wording that Senator Haines is perhaps looking for at this stage will probably come in the second round, which will supplement, amend or displace these interim guidelines. But I think it is quite sensible that at the moment the sort of language used in the guidelines be adopted. It is not meant at all to provide for a loose regime, but it is meant to indicate that, because we are trying to cover such a wide body of tax file number recipients, precise guidelines as to every situation cannot possibly be formulated. Therefore, the flexibility inherent in the term `all reasonable steps' I think is warranted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am starting to feel a touch dizzy because it seems to me that what has happened with the Minister's answer is that we have now come full circle to the original question I asked about the definitions; that is, the meaning of the term `personal information'. The Minister has just gone to the other Bill that was a part of the cognate debate; namely, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, and said that the specifics with regard to security of the information and the penalties attached are contained within that Bill. I accept that, but again we then get to the question: how do we trace the source of the leak? Personal information of the sort defined on page 5 of the Privacy Bill is defined as all sorts of information or opinion, whether true or not, that is contained in records or recorded in some form. `Record' is defined as `a document, a database, however, kept, or a photograph or other pictorial representation of a person'. How detailed is that database? How accessible is it and to whom is it accessible?

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well to say that the tax file number legislation provides security steps and penalties, and that schedule 2 of the Privacy Bill supplements those but we come back to the situation of finding out how, in Heaven's name, anybody traces a leak of personal information when it is defined as broadly as this and contained in so many places. As Senator Hill said to me earlier this evening before the dinner break, there might be a chance of finding the person who got hold of the personal information about a Department of Social Security (DSS) number of my constituent whose case I raised earlier. But if I read the term `personal information' correctly and follow that up with a reference to the definition of the term `record' which is referred to in the definition of `personal information', I presume that those databases are not discreet or discrete-both words apply-and that we do not have department specific records. We have one shared database and if somebody's DSS number is revealed one of a hundred or more persons could be responsible for that. It is a bit cloud-cuckoo-land to write into legislation steps to ensure security, penalties and sanctions to follow a breach in security, to have a piece of privacy legislation attached to the Bill that could cause the problems in the first place, to have that privacy legislation not cover the private sector, and to make the whole thing so circular that it is impossible to protect any information on anybody from anyone else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has really just rehearsed almost all of the arguments which lead her to find inadequacies in the privacy legislation and, indeed, in the tax file number legislation. She obviously raises a difficult problem for investigators when there is a leak, particularly of the kind brought to the attention of the chamber before dinner. But that is no different from the task that faces investigators and the Australian Federal Police from time to time in trying, as best they might, to go to the source to try to locate the person who is responsible for an abuse of information which ought to be held and used only for the purpose for which it was gathered. That is only a very typical problem which faces any investigation of such a leak of material.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the privacy legislation in itself can overcome those difficulties of locating the person responsible for misuse of information held, except in so far as the Privacy Commissioner has an ability to have access to all records held in the agencies concerned. Indeed, if he has reason to believe that a person has information or a document relevant to the investigation, he can give to the person a written notice requiring that person to give information, produce documents and so on. No doubt that would be part of the process by which the investigation would be conducted. I believe that the sorts of processes set out in the Bill which vest very considerable power and oversight in the Privacy Commissioner will be an additional means for attempting to locate the sorts of leaks which Senator Haines speaks about. But in general, the matter that she has raised is no different from the difficulty of pursuing a leak from within government agencies at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have to pursue this point because the Minister has missed the very issue that I raised; that is, there is a difference here in what has been the norm to date. As I understand it, at the moment the Department of Social Security (DSS) contains within its database information on social security recipients. This information is not in some other department's database. The Minister may correct me if I am wrong but most people around here assume that there is no sharing of that information. I can find no definition in either the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill or the Privacy Bill of the database that we are referring to in the definition of `record' which is used throughout this legislation. Who has access to this database? Is it a single database? Does the Department of Social Security have its database, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) have its, and other organisations have their own? Is the information contained in the DSS database also contained on the Australian Taxation Office database?

SPEECH.PARA: If the answer to that is yes, we have a very different problem from the one we currently face. If information on people's tax returns is leaked from the ATO then there is a chance that we can pinpoint the area. We have a chance of finding out which office, and what part of the office, has dealt with that person's tax return. If information regarding somebody's social security pension is made available, presumably we can go through the same process. While it might be difficult for the Australian Federal Police or the State police forces, they at least have a starting point. If my suspicion is correct and this database contains information from more than one department or section, we no longer have a reasonably sized finite group of potential culprits in the event of a leak; we have an almost infinite bank of potential culprits. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no Peter Sawyer database in the sense of--
—I don't give Peter Sawyer much credibility either.

—I am just saying this because Senator Haines asked what the database is. There is no phrase within the definition of `personal information' or `record' which speaks of `the database'. There is no such sort of composite entity in existence. In the two definitions, one of personal information and the other of record, we are trying to say that we have to recognise that the computer age is with us and that to refer to documents would be too narrow a way to talk about those methods of recording personal information available within bureaucracies, whether they be in the private or public sector. Therefore the definition speaks of information which can form part of a database, and the definition speaks of record. It speaks of a document or a database, however kept. I think that is a simple recognition of the fact that information can be recorded and stored and retrieval can occur from an entity and there does not have to be any written documentation in the traditional filing sense that is the basis of the method of holding that particular information. That is all those references to databases are meant to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to particular agencies, one would have to go through the various secrecy provisions which protect the information in relation to their holdings, whether they are held in documentary form or in a database within the agency. Those secrecy provisions-for example, in relation to the Australian Taxation Office-are well known to honourable senators and are part of the way in which that information is, one hopes, held secure. So that is the situation. It is merely a description attempted in these definitions of the way in which this information can be held within the private sector or within the Commonwealth agencies concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that there is no exchange of information between, say, the Department of Social Security and, say, the Australian Taxation Office; that data or personal information held by the DSS is not shared with-and that means added to the information held by-another department such as the ATO, or vice versa.

—There is no common database for the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office. I ought to make that clear straight away. As Senator Haines would know, there is provision in the information privacy principles (IPPs)-and she will come to them, no doubt; IPPs 10 and 11-which indicates that there can be a transfer of information in situations where, according to principle 11 (1) (e), `the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue'. As honourable senators will know, that particular provision cannot override explicit secrecy provisions contained in legislation. It has to be seen in that context as not overriding or displacing those particular secrecy provisions. But there is there a recognition that we hope the Parliament will accept that there are situations where disclosure of personal information by one agency to another for those purposes could be required. In that situation the exception outlined in principle 11-I think we will probably come to a full debate on it-indicates that all personal information is not to be held so sacrosanct to the agency to which it was first provided that other major matters of public interest or other major matters of concern such as the protection of the public revenue or the enforcement of the criminal law cannot themselves be advanced.

—I will leave clause 6, the Minister will be pleased to know, but only to return to the same issue when we get to information privacy principle (IPP) 11. Can I just raise a question with regard to clause 7, which no doubt will make the advisers somewhat relieved that they do not have to come up with yet more arguments to get the Minister out of a hole on clause 6? Clause 7 (1) (a) (iv) excludes the National Crime Authority (NCA) from the Bill. I would like the Minister to say why. The exemptions in the IPPs in the Bill, as the Minister would know, already protect the National Crime Authority in its information gathering activities, and its databases are protected from access and correction by the Freedom of Information Act. In addition, I remind the Minister, in case he needs reminding, that the NCA has its own secrecy clause. Given all of that, it does seem somewhat inappropriate that the Privacy Commissioner should not be able to audit the information collecting, recording and disclosure practices of the NCA around those other criteria that operate to protect it. I would be interested to know why the Government felt compelled to add a further exclusion relating to the NCA in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think honourable senators will know that the National Crime Authority (NCA) holds a unique status. It is true that it is, at least in part, a creature of this Parliament, but of course it also has legislative underpinning from all the State parliaments and the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory. I think it is the only national law enforcement institution which is founded on and sustained by legislation of all the various parliaments around the Commonwealth. That gives it a certain special status, which is not the case with other Commonwealth agencies. It is also the case obviously that it is vested by this Parliament with extraordinary powers that are not available to other law enforcement agencies. Because of that, the type of surveillance that it is put under to keep it operating within proper democratic bounds is set down in the statute and includes the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority which provides a means and a process by which any abuse of the powers which it has can be exposed to democratically elected representatives. It is within that sort of framework that the overall supervision and curtailing, ensuring that the NCA acts in a proper manner in the exercise of its power, is to take place. That is the scheme which the Parliament at the moment considers sufficient.

SPEECH.PARA: If we had a report from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority which indicated that that Authority might be brought within the purview of this sort of legislation, that might give material which would require a response and reflection and deliberation. But at this stage the Government, having not heard any real argument that the NCA ought to be brought within this privacy legislation, has determined that with the concurrence of the Parliament it ought to be excluded from the scope and ambit of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. I would appreciate it if he could refer that very question to the joint parliamentary committee concerned. Can we now look at the information privacy principles in clause 14? I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Page 11, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 2, lines 37 and 38, leave out `the individual concerned is generally aware of', insert `the individual concerned is informed, in writing, of'.

This is an amendment to information privacy principle (IPP) 2 which relates to the solicitation of personal information from an individual; that is, it relates to someone in officialdom requesting personal information from a particular individual. As it stands, IPP 2 requires those collectors of information to make the people quaintly known as information subjects `generally aware' of the purpose of the collection of the information. `Generally aware' is not satisfactory, as it can mean all sorts of things. One could simply say, `We need this information'. Since people tend to be intimidated by government officials, simply being told vaguely that the information is required may well lead them to provide the information without seeking anything more specific. Indeed, it may well be that the person collecting the information may simply believe that the argument that the Government needs the information is quite sufficient. I do not happen to believe that, and I hope that the majority of the Committee supports my feelings in this matter.

I think it is quite unacceptable that such a general term as `generally aware' is in this legislation. I think it is unacceptable that people from whom information is to be gathered should be told in such a vague way, or be put in a position where they may be told in a very vague way, why the information is being gathered. If we are to go through this exercise-and thanks to the collusion of the Opposition we are-at the very least we should be giving the people from whom information is collected as much information in return about why it is being collected. They should be told in quite specific terms the purpose of the collection. I hasten to point out to the Minister that this is not some nuisance amendment that I have dreamed up in order to take up the time of the chamber, and Senator Hill can look as disbelieving as he likes about that. It is based on the recommendations of both the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Australian Law Reform Commission. I think it is a perfectly acceptable argument that, if the Government is seeking information from an individual, it should provide that individual with the specific reason that the information is being collected.

The amendment, by obliging the person or department collecting the information to inform the individual in writing as to why the information is being collected, will improve the situation to the greatest extent that we in this place are able to do. Written advice will necessarily require that the collector of the information sets down clearly what he or she believes to be the purpose of the collection. In this way, all sorts of vague verbal statements about the purpose will be avoided-statements that can be misunderstood, misheard, kept deliberately vague or even sound menacing in some instances. There is certainly much less opportunity for the written specific word being misinterpreted by either side compared with some vague verbal statement which gives people a general awareness of why the information is being collected.

I hope that the Opposition sees its way clear to tighten up this particular IPP so that people of whom a request is made for information will receive the courtesy of being told precisely why the information is being collected. I do not wish to sound paranoid, but simply requiring that an individual is made generally aware of why the information is being requested can set all sorts of hares running in all sorts of directions. Fishing expeditions, to mix the metaphor thoroughly, are not unlikely under the current scenario. If somebody, when requesting information from an individual, has to say why that information is being requested, not only does the provider of the information know what he is getting himself into but also there is a possibility that he could challenge the reason, the need and the validity of the request. All of this legislation is hedged with a whole lot of if's and but's and apparent appeal mechanisms for people, most of which are after the event. At the very least I think we should give them some `before the event' information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government believes that the present provision is sensible and adequate. We do not want mountains of paper inundating the working of the system. It is believed that it is important that a person from whom information is solicited be generally aware of the purpose. Clearly, that would entail different steps in relation to different agencies. If one were applying for a benefit from Social Security or Veterans' Affairs and certain information was solicited, I guess the general reason for that requirement would be quite apparent. Clearly, it would be in relation to the obtaining of the benefit. It just seems to me to be an unnecessary complication to require in relation to each benefit that yet another piece of paper be produced. It is quite clear that the person wishing to obtain the benefit would be generally aware of the purpose for which the information was being sought with respect to status, income or situation. It is also the case that, as I say, these rather general rules will have to be applied in particular circumstances in greater detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 27 (1) (e) provides that the Privacy Commissioner has one of the following functions:

to prepare, and to publish in such manner as the Commissioner considers appropriate, guidelines for the avoidance of acts or practices of an agency that may or might be interferences with the privacy of individuals;

I imagine that there would be circumstances in which the Privacy Commissioner, in relation to the activities of certain agencies, would see as a prudent and sensible guideline a requirement that something along the lines indicated by Senator Haines should be provided to a person from whom personal information is solicited. Once again, I think the Parliament really has to see how this legislation works. By that, I do not mean that people should be left exposed to mischievous, intimidating or wrongful claims that information must be provided.

Senator Haines spoke of some sort of general assertion that `we need the information'. That would not be sufficient. Even on the most lax reading of information privacy principle 2, it is quite clear that the person has to be made generally aware of the purpose for which the information is being collected and, further, has to be made aware, if the collection of the information is authorised or required by or under law, of the fact that the collection of the information is so authorised or required, and so on.

I think that, consistent with information privacy principle (IPP) 2, one will find that soliciting of information could not be undertaken on a simple assertion of need for information due to something being intimidating or seductive. That would not be sufficient. One also has to go back to information privacy principle 1, which makes clear:
Personal information shall not be collected by a collector for inclusion in a record or in a generally available publication unless:
(a) the information is collected for a purpose that is a lawful purpose directly related to a function or activity of the collector; and
(b) the collection of the information is necessary for or directly related to that purpose.

It is paragraph (b) that is perhaps the more pertinent. I believe that, taking information privacy principle 1(b) in tandem with IPP 2-and all these information privacy principles are to be read together and are obviously cumulative in their impact-the sort of general framework that is provided is quite adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the arguments for and against the amendment, and I decide in favour of the Australian Democrats in this instance. I think the wording at present is just too vague and ambiguous. If these provisions are going to be vague and ambiguous-and they are stated to be information privacy principles-then they will cease to have any worthwhile value. My only reservation is that in some circumstances it might not be appropriate that the individual be informed in writing. Had the Government been more precise with this provision and stipulated that a person `be made aware of' the necessary details, I might have been more sympathetic to the Government's argument. However, the stipulation at present that an individual is to be made `generally aware of' the purpose for which the information is being collected, and so on, leaves an enormous gap in information privacy principle 2 and really defeats the purpose for which it has been included. On that basis, the Opposition supports the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 12, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 3, paragraph (c), lines 18 and 19, leave out ``and is up to date and complete'', insert ``and is up to date, complete and accurate''.

Information privacy principle 3 relates to the solicitation of personal information generally. As this provision stands, it obliges collectors to ensure that information collected is up-to-date and complete. That seems reasonable enough. However, considering that this relates to departments that will be exchanging information-although it might not all be on the same database-I think there is an obligation to take reasonable steps to ensure that the information is accurate. The Minister can play semantics and talk about things being up-to-date and complete, but I think that, as per the Australian Law Reform Commission recommendation, accuracy should be specifically stated as one of the criteria. My amendment would ensure that information is not only up-to-date and complete but also accurate. I do not want to get into a semantic dissertation, but is seems to me that it is better to stipulate `up-to-date, complete and accurate' in this provision, and to risk tautology perhaps, than to leave out one of those terms and risk an injustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe I can persuade Senator Hill to forgo his normal courtesies to Senator Haines and to be persuaded by the argument which I will now put.
—Merit is better than courtesy.
—That is right. Once again, I think we do need to read these information privacy principles as a whole. For example, principle 7 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall take such steps (if any), by way of making appropriate corrections, deletions and additions as are, in the circumstances, reasonable to ensure that the record:
(a) is accurate; and

(b) is, having regard to the purpose for which the information was collected or is to be used and to any purpose that is directly related to that purpose, relevant, up to date, complete and not misleading.
This indicates a real obligation on the record keeper to ensure that the records are accurate. One finds a further dimension to this in information privacy principle 8, which provides:

A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall not use that information without taking such steps (if any) as are, in the circumstances, reasonable to ensure that, having regard to the purpose for which the information is proposed to be used, the information is accurate, up to date and complete.

I think that overall one will find that within the scheme of the information privacy principles there is a very real attempt to ensure that records containing personal information are accurate, and particularly when it comes to their further use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has convinced me that `accurate' might as well be included in information privacy principle 3, because as he has already pointed out it is in principle 7, which is comforting, and that is in relation to alteration of records containing personal information and the obligation to ensure that deletions and additions are accurate. That is to be applauded. Further, information privacy principle 8 stipulates that a record keeper must check accuracy, et cetera of personal information before use; in other words, an obligation to ensure that the information is accurate, up-to-date and complete before it is used. That information privacy principle is also in a form of which we approve. Therefore, one asks why `up-to-date, complete and accurate' was not included in principle 3, relating to the solicitation of personal information generally. I can only presume that it was an oversight and it now looks as though we have the opportunity to correct that. Therefore, the Liberal Party of Australia supports the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 13, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 5, subparagraph 1 (b) (ii), line 4, leave out the subparagraph, insert:
``(ii) each purpose for which that information is used;''
(5) Page 13, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 5, after subparagraph 1 (b) (ii), insert the following new subparagraphs:
``(iia) the purposes of disclosure of records to third parties;
(iib) the record-keeper's policies and practices regarding storage of, retrievability of, access to, controls over, retention of and disposal of, records; and''.

The amendments relate to information privacy principle (IPP) 5, and that concerns the very principle that the Minister referred to a moment ago, namely, information relating to records kept by the record keeper. It seems to me that the obligations imposed on the record keeper by IPP 5 are inadequate as the provision now stands. The Australian Democrats' amendment would extend the obligation of the record keeper to require that person-and I have with some whimsy used the term that appears all the way through the legislation-`to take reasonable steps' to enable people to find out the purpose of disclosure of records to third parties and the record keeper's policies and practices in relation to storage of, retrievability of, access to, controls over and retention and/or disposal of records. I think the amendment will strengthen what is quite clearly a weak provision. People ought to have that sort of power over databases, records, or whatever, that contain information about them.

I think there must be obligations on the part of people who collect information and who periodically check and update it and ensure that it is accurate and so on to take all steps possible and reasonable to enable people to ascertain what is behind disclosure of those records to others. There are all sorts of instances where information is disclosed to third parties. I mentioned one this afternoon. According to a complainant who came to my office, Telecom Australia, without telling the individual concerned, had circulated that person's name to banks and other lending institutions, claiming that that individual was not creditworthy. It did that because a bill was outstanding, yet the outstanding bill, while certainly not for a very large amount, had never been received by the individual concerned. It seems to me that there is a moral obligation on people who hold information about citizens of this country, when they are going to divulge such information-presumably they will do it beforehand-to let the individual know.

We have already seen under the definitions in clause 6 that we are dealing with personal information that may not be true. The definition of `personal information' actually states that this means `information or an opinion . . . whether true or not . . . about an individual whose identity is apparent . . .'. I think it is pretty appalling if we have a situation where information on a person or an opinion about that person, whether it is true or not, can be disseminated to a third party without the person concerned being given preferably prior notice, but certainly some adequate notice. Our amendment, which leaves out a subparagraph and inserts another, would make sure that the reason the information is being released is provided to the individual concerned. I thought simple justice would have required that that be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats. Whilst I can see what Senator Haines is trying to achieve, when one considers the range of manners in which an agency might be able legitimately to use information provided to it by a particular person, it might be impractical to require that each purpose for which the information could be used be outlined to a person. The example that I have been given is that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would hold personal information in order to provide a range of services to its clients. It also uses that information to provide other services to veterans. Information may be used in the provision of medical care and in the assessment of eligibility for housing under the defence service homes program. To have informed the veterans in the first instance of the main purpose for which the information was sought, perhaps in relation to the obtaining of a benefit, a level of benefit or some particular service, would, I believe, be an adequate indication of the reason the information was obtained by the agency concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As to third parties and so on-once again this perhaps foreshadows some argument in relation to information privacy principles 10 and 11-the fact is that if we once again look at the IPPs as a whole, we see that information privacy principle 2 (e) requires notification of the usual disclosure practice at the time of collection. I repeat for the benefit of honourable senators that it requires:

any person to whom, or any body or agency to which, it is the collector's usual practice to disclose personal information of the kind so collected, and (if known by the collector) any person to whom, or any body or agency to which, it is the usual practice of that first-mentioned person, body or agency to pass on that information.

That obligation on the collector indicates, as Senator Haines said, that the person should be informed in advance, where possible, of the usual disclosure practices that might be involved in the use of the information made available to an agency. I have already indicated that under information privacy principle 5 there is a requirement for the notification of the main purpose for which the information is to be used.

In relation to the second part of amendment (5), the requirement concerning the record keeper's `policies and practices regarding storage of, retrievability of, access to, controls over, retention of and disposal of, records' et cetera, IPP 5 paragraph 1 (b) (iii) already provides for some of this material to be clearly set out. This is dealt with in a number of paragraphs, which I will not enumerate. A record keeper has to maintain a record setting out the steps to be taken to obtain access to information. No doubt the Privacy Commissioner will once again play a role in publishing guidelines for record keepers on the appropriate storage and security measures and the retrievability of, access to, controls over, retention of and disposal of records. I believe that once again the role of the Privacy Commissioner, as set out in functions enumerated in clause 27, will provide a much more detailed application of the matters which are of concern to Senator Haines. We are setting out a general structure here, and when the Privacy Commissioner gets to work I believe we will find that the more particular application of these general principles will be found to be more usefully applicable to the Commonwealth agencies concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would prefer the principles to be more precise rather than less precise. It seems to us that to provide an obligation to indicate the main purpose for which information is used not only can be unhelpful but also might place the record keeper himself or herself in a particularly difficult position. If personal information is held for government purposes, we cannot see why the person to whom such information relates should not be able to find out the purpose or, if it is held for a number of purposes, each of the purposes. It seems to us, therefore, that the Australian Democrats' amendment which refers to substituting `each purpose' for `the main purposes', as I read it, appears soundly based and we therefore support it.

SPEECH.PARA: The subsequent two subclauses in the Democrats' amendment (5), which I think were advocated by the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties, also appear to us to be reasonable. In effect, as has been said, they will ensure that where records are provided to third parties, the person to whom the records relate will be able to find out the purposes of disclosure of the records to such third parties. That seems to us to be reasonable. Furthermore, that person will be able to find out the records keeper's policies and practices regarding storage of, retrievability of, access to, controls over, retention of and disposal of, such records. We think it is reasonable that such a person can find out that information.

The Minister refers to how these things will work out in practice. If in due course, the administration finds that these principles are providing such onerous obligations that they in effect bog down the efficient management of bureaucratic function, no doubt the Government will come back to this Parliament with amendments and, presumably, evidence to substantiate the fact that the principles have become too certain in their application. As far as we are concerned, at this stage in trying to put these provisions in place we would prefer to see them, as I said, more precise rather than less precise. We will therefore support the Democrats' amendments 4 and 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for the clear-sightedness that is being seen to emanate from the Opposition parties. I hope it keeps on keeping on. I just say to the Minister in response to his answer a moment ago that, yes, I can see what is contained in principle 3, in that section that lists what the record keeper shall maintain. However, there is a vast difference between the record keeper maintaining a record setting out all of those things and the person about whom the record is kept knowing all of those things. Nothing in that principle requires the record keeper even to tell the person concerned that such a record is maintained and that that person has access to that information. I think the point that Senator Hill raises is a valid one. It is better to be more precise than less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not linger on this point too much longer. However, under principle 5.4 it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A record-keeper shall:
(a) make the record maintained-
which we have adverted to-
available for inspection by members of the public;
I think that there is an obligation on the record keeper to make the principle 5.3 record available in a way which is accessible to members of the public. It is a mandatory requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could members of the public know that it is being made accessible?

—One has to use a bit of commonsense. I believe that if the agency is under a mandatory obligation to make the record under principle 5.3 available for inspection by members of the public clearly it has to be in a form that is accessible and in a way that is known to the public, otherwise obviously they cannot inspect it. A little bit of commonsense has to be used, particularly in regard to the fact that, once again, the Privacy Commissioner as we all know is required to be given a copy of the record so maintained. One of his functions is to supervise the way in which an agency adheres to the requirements contained in principle 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister that there are 16 1/2 million people living in this country, at least half-if not all-of whom, presumably, will have records kept on them. I fail to see how simply making the record, maintained under principle 5.3, available for inspection by members of the public, will mean that they are going to have access to that or will know where to have access or that they will benefit from having access. Having access to it could well mean plonking eight million pieces of information down and saying, `Go to it, son'. What we are simply saying-I am pleased to see the Opposition supporting this-is that it has to be made perfectly clear to the persons about whom the information is being kept that they can have access to this information; that they can know the purpose for which the information is being used; that they can know the purposes of disclosure of records to third parties; and that they can know the record keeper's policies and practices regarding storage of, retrievability of, access to, controls over, retention of and disposal of records. That is quite different from simply saying that it is going to be made publicly available. This gives people some specifics and far more clear cut rights than the section that the Minister referred to a moment ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without moving an amendment, I would like to raise a question with regard to principle 6 which continues to relate to access to records containing personal information. Principle 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a record-keeper has possession or control of a record that contains personal information, the individual concerned shall be entitled to have access to that record, except to the extent that the record-keeper is required or authorised to refuse to provide the individual with access to that record under the applicable provisions of any law of the Commonwealth that provides for access by persons to documents.

Any law of the Commonwealth would of course include the Freedom of Information Act. Conceivably, it could be used to deny, for example, corrections to inaccurate personal information. We have just had a dissertation on the information privacy principals (IPPs) that require up-to-dateness and accuracy. Yet one of the ways in which information can be checked by an individual is through a freedom of information request. It is bad enough that those are being made excessively expensive by the hourly costs and the various appeals costs, but to have this catch-all clause in principle 6 is suspicious, to say the very least. Why is it necessary? I would not have thought that correction rights should be tied to the purposes for which information is collected. I would have thought that it would not prejudice government interests, or anything else, if those correction rights were made available. I do not have an amendment to principle 6, the Minister will be relieved to know, but I would like to know why there is no capacity for general correction of information by the person concerned. Why are we excluding any law of the Commonwealth in this case? To what extent in fact is the freedom of information legislation going to be used to hamper people in providing record keepers referred to in other IPPs with accurate information?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it is true that principle 6 has regard to the question of freedom of information (FOI) legislation which will provide, as the Parliament determined, that certain records in certain situations will not be disclosed to a person seeking them. That is fairly straightforward. It is quite sensible for this legislation to note that particular situation applying under FOI legislation. It is, however, worth having some regard to clauses 34 and 35 of the Bill which allow the Privacy Commissioner to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . direct the agency to add to the document an appropriate notation setting out particulars of the amendments of the document that the Commissioner thinks should be made.

I am advised that that can occur if a person cannot get access to the document because it is an exempt document under the freedom of information legislation. So it is not entirely excluded from the possibility of correction and amendment. The Privacy Commissioner takes a role in that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 15, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 10, paragraph 1 (d), line 3, before ``use of the information'', insert ``the individual concerned has consented and''.
Page 15, clause 14, Information Privacy Principles, Principle 10, at end of clause 2, add ``and a note that the consent of the individual concerned was obtained''.

Principle 10 relates to limits on the use of personal information. Principle 10 (1) (d) permits the use and disclosure of personal information where it is reasonably necessary to do so for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty or for the protection of the public revenue. I would suggest that there is practically nothing that happens in this country that does not have something to do with the public revenue, either increasing it or decreasing it. If we are talking about a catch-all provision, the term `protection of the public revenue' is it. I cannot conceive of any piece of information about anybody that does not somehow relate to the protection of the public revenue.

Every child who is born is going to be picked up under this law because the parents are getting family allowance for that child. So virtually from birth principle 10 (1) (d) permits the use and disclosure of personal information on almost anybody, because public revenue is involved. All tax collecting and benefit providing authorities of the Commonwealth will be able, under this clause, to use and disclose personal information on the grounds that the public revenue is involved and needs protecting. Worse, it probably makes most government departments exempt from the two most important information privacy principles (IPPs) for most of their activities. That catch-all provision of protection of public revenue appears in principle 11. Principles 10 and 11 mean that any government department can use and disclose personal information, using the argument that the protection of public revenue is involved.

I think there are numerous examples from overseas-the United States is a classic example-showing what happens when inaccurate computer information is used against or released about people. Again, I refer honourable senators to the definition of `personal information', which contains that rather extraordinary clause `whether true or not'. It is conceivably possible for people to use and disclose information based on opinions which may not be true, if we consider the terms in which personal information is defined, and do so with no sanction against them because they complain that it is dealing with the protection of public revenue. I give as an example the issue that I raised about the woman who advertised for somebody to rent her house during the Grand Prix. It would be possible to argue that her Department of Social Security number was released to make sure that she was not renting that property and not declaring it. The person concerned could say, `Of course I disclosed that information. It was to ensure that the money she was given for renting that home during the Grand Prix was not squirrelled away by her somewhere and not disclosed because it could have affected her pension'.

We can argue the merits of whether people should rort the system. Most of us believe that they should not. But the line needs to be drawn when we consider that the words `true or not' and `opinion' appear in the definition of personal information. The term `protecting the public revenue' is thrown into IPPs 10 and 11. It is quite an extraordinary conjunction of terms that could lead to some massive release of information which nobody could challenge. The Privacy Commissioner could not argue against it, an injunction could not stop it, an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal could not produce a positive result from it and a court case would not stand up on it. All that the record keeper would have to do is say, `We disclosed that information, we used that information, because it was necessary to do so for the enforcement of the criminal law', or, more likely, `for the protection of the public revenue however tenuous that protection may be'.

I am not going to argue about the need to enforce the criminal law or to involve a law imposing a pecuniary penalty. That catch-all about the protection of public revenue means that there is no recipient of social security-I remind honourable senators that that includes people who receive family allowance benefits-taxpayer, invalid pensioner or hardly a person alive in Australia who is not going to find that information can be used and disclosed because it is somehow linked with the protection of the public revenue. Of all of the amendments that we have moved tonight the amendments relating to IPP 10 and IPP 11 are probably the most necessary as far as real protection of the privacy of individuals is concerned.

We have already ascertained tonight that there is not a common database. More importantly, we have learned that there is a linkage between databases and that relevant information is exchanged. That means that the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security are going to be exchanging information. That Department, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Community Services and Health are the main departments dealing with the protection of government revenue. People picked up in this way, including primary producers involved in income equalisation schemes, will find that information about them can be used and disclosed because public revenue is involved and has to be protected. Again, I remind the Committee that we are talking not about hard data but about opinion, in some cases, and information, whether true or not, that is kept on records. That is how personal information is defined in this Bill. I notice that Senator Puplick has joined Senator Hill in the chamber. He was on the original joint committee, as I was, and I know that one of his principal concerns was to ensure that information could not be misused on specious grounds. If ever I have seen a catch-all that can be used and abused by people who wish to do so, this protection of the public revenue is it.

I commend to the Committee the amendments dealing with information privacy principles. I remind it that people have been suspected of and sometimes taken to court for tax or social security benefit fraud as a result of inaccurate information, sometimes maliciously provided by other people in the community. Sometimes this has happened because of computer error. Whatever else people out in the world might think to the contrary, computers have been known to be wrong because the human programmers have hit the wrong key or reversed two numbers. The inaccuracy of the information can simply be the result of a data process error-comparing like with unlike data or not putting in sufficient information so that a particular transaction looks suspect.

I think the need for public disclosure, review and assessment of those programs is overwhelming. At the very least, it should be necessary for individuals to consent to the use and disclosure of information, because before they can consent they have to be told about the use and disclosure and, presumably, the contents of what is to be used and disclosed, which gives them some capacity to see whether the information is accurate, whether it has been taken out of context and whether it is being used fairly. I acknowledge that our amendments are not perfect solutions to this problem, but they go some way to correcting what could be one of the more massive injustices perpetrated under this so-called privacy legislation, which appears to contain more protections for the department concerned than for the individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was quite unfair of Senator Haines to conclude by saying that this is so-called privacy legislation which favours departments over individuals. However, it is true that in relation to information privacy principles 10 and 11, which for the first time set down limits on the use and disclosure of personal information, there is a recognition of the overriding public interest which has already been recognised by this Parliament in various situations. I make it absolutely clear, as the explanatory memorandum does, that the information privacy principles do not override the secrecy provisions that are to be found in various pieces of Commonwealth legislation. There is no catch-all provision, as I think Senator Haines called it, which opens the floodgates to all sorts of abuse by overriding the safeguards which the Parliament has erected, particularly in relation to the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Haines that in relation to the Taxation Office and, in particular, section 16 of the taxation law, which deals with the obligation on officers to observe secrecy, the Parliament itself provides for certain authorised recipients of information-in other words, certain exceptions-once again, in the public interest. One authorised recipient of information from the Commissioner of Taxation is the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, for the purpose of the administration of any law of the Commonwealth relating to pensions, allowances or benefits. So the Parliament has already recognised that even in relation to section 16 of the taxation law, which remains in place and in force and is not displaced by principle 11 1 (e) or 10 1 (d)-in this case we are talking about 11 1 (e) which deals with disclosure-there are situations where it is in order to ensure that Commonwealth laws relating to pensions, allowances or benefits are properly administered and that only those persons who are truly entitled to those allowances, pensions and benefits obtain them.

It is not true to say, as I think Senator Haines did at one stage, that all that was needed was some very tenuous connection-I think the phrase she used was `however tenuous'-for the requirement of the enforcement of the criminal law or the protection of the public revenue to be established. What is required in information privacy principle 11 is that the disclosure be reasonably necessary. That is a matter which can be subjected to the scrutiny of the Privacy Commissioner. I believe that it would be quite impossible for an agency to decide arbitrarily that information can be transferred willy-nilly on most tenuous grounds because the agency will know that ultimately the Privacy Commissioner, who has access to all transactions and transfers of information by agencies, will be able to assess whether a particular disclosure was reasonably necessary.

Regarding the great fear that Senator Haines seems to have about the disclosure of information flowing the other way, to the Taxation Office, it might be of interest to the Committee to recall the words of the former Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), Mr Ian Temby, who has commented on the need for exchanges of information by agencies in order to combat fraud on the Commonwealth. In a speech to the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration entitled `Impediments to Tackling Fraud' on 2 May this year he said:

Accepting that there is a need to safeguard the handling of information which may be private, confidential and sensitive nevertheless it becomes an absurdity when fraud on the Commonwealth is facilitated by the enforced lack of communication between agencies.

I believe that we must recognise as a very necessary fact that, if we are to combat fraud, there needs to be, when reasonably necessary, that flow of information which enables the criminal law to be enforced or the public revenue to be protected. Indeed, it is not uncommon for the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or the Director of Public Prosecutions to make information available to the Australian Taxation Office which enables the Taxation Office to raise an assessment and to audit particular cases-for example, where the Federal Police become aware that a person is deriving income from illegal activities such as drug trafficking. The Australian Taxation Office relies to an extent on Australian Federal Police and DPP information to identify and audit cases where those involved in criminal activity are clearly at the same time not making available to the Tax Office the proper extent of their revenue. That is rather a big program of auditing within the Tax Office which clearly allows for the recovery of many millions of dollars to the revenue.

So I believe that there are instances where dramatic and colourful scenarios can be painted. As I say, these information flows have already been recognised by the Parliament as necessary in order to protect the public purse against abuse. I think it is obvious to most people that to require that a person consent in writing to the notification by one agency, to the AFP for example, of personal information held which might enable the AFP to undertake an investigation is so absurd that it cannot seriously be contemplated, in that a person would be put on notice that an investigation by the law enforcement authorities was taking place. That cannot be seriously put forward as a way in which the proper balance between public interest and the privacy of personal information might be achieved. I do not believe that the Australian Democrats' amendments would properly achieve that balance. In fact they would undo much of the work which this Parliament has already put on the statute book, with safeguards, but recognising that exceptions have to be made in certain situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will probably fall from favour with the Australian Democrats again at this point, because we oppose these amendments. We do so basically because it is my view, with the greatest of respect, that Senator Haines has misinterpreted this provision. I do not see that protection of the public revenue should be read as a final catch-all. Rather, it should be read as qualified by the provisions that precede it. It seems to me that principle 10 1 (d) is looking at areas of provision of information in criminal law cases, in cases that involve a pecuniary penalty and then in the protection of the public revenue, and that it clearly relates to situations of abuse or potential abuse of the public revenue. Therefore, if I am correct in that interpretation, what we would be doing by agreeing to this amendment is potentially hindering the operation of the criminal law. We have no wish to do that. I think we would find that there would be very few cases in which consent would be obtained in order that such information could be used in criminal cases. We think that it is important that a proper balance be found and we are concerned that if we agreed to this amendment that balance would not be maintained and that we would, as I said, be running the risk of hindering the effective prosecution of the criminal law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did acknowledge when I was speaking to these amendments-and I will include in those the two amendments to information privacy principle (IPP) 11 as well, although I have not moved them, and will not be proceeding to move them because the same fate will befall them, I suspect: I will confine myself to simply speaking about them-that I did not require that the consent be in writing, just that it be given and noted; but that is a minor detail. I am still very concerned about-I think we are all concerned about it in this place; it is simply a matter of finding a form of words that does not cause one concern to change into another problem-the fact that information can be used and disclosed without the knowledge of an individual, without giving that individual the opportunity to correct the information, and that this could lead to certain injustices. I accept the fact that, as Senator Hill said, there will be instances where consent will be refused and that this will hinder the enforcement of the criminal law. It may well be that the best brains in this place can come up with some amendments to IPPs 10 and 11 that protect the rights of the individual so that he is aware of what is happening and is given the opportunity to make corrections and to insist on accuracies in the database without in any way impeding the collection of revenues and stopping the pursuit of defrauders of the system, but at the moment it is absolutely irrefutable that principle 10 in particular is deficient. I think we need to look much more closely at this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has said on a number of occasions that we ought to leave the legislation alone and wait to see whether any problems arise, and then take some steps to attend to them. Since I am not going to get those amendments supported by either side, I ask the Minister to add those principles to his list of areas we are going to watch to see whether problems arise and in relation to which we will duly look for ways in which we can protect the rights of individuals without impeding the legitimate actions by departments for protecting the public revenue and for enforcing the criminal law or the law imposing a pecuniary penalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give an undertaking to use what influence I can with the Privacy Commissioner when he or she is appointed to try to ensure that when the annual report is made available to this Parliament particular attention is paid to the way in which information privacy principle 10 1 (d) and principle 11 1 (e) have operated. I believe that that will be done in conjunction with the Commissioner's role under clause 27 (1) (h), which is:

SPEECH.PARA: to conduct audits of records of personal information maintained by agencies for the purpose of ascertaining whether the records are maintained according to the Information Privacy Principles;
