DEBATE.TITLE: AIDS: A TIME TO CARE, A TIME TO ACT-TOWARDS A STRATEGY FOR AUSTRALIANS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) I present a statement relating to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and I table the policy discussion paper entitled AIDS: a time to care, a time to act-Towards a strategy for Australians. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Just over three years ago, the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, first addressed the Parliament on acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

He said, and I quote `AIDs is potentially one of the most serious and expensive public health problems to face Australia since Federation . . . both as individuals and as a community, AIDS poses a potential threat to us all.'

The Minister reported that in Australia, as at May 17, 1985, there had been 79 cases of AIDS, of which 32 had died, and it had been estimated that some tens of thousands of Australians had been exposed to the virus.
Tragically, the events of the past three years have borne out the reality of that warning.
Today, on November 22, 1988, this country has suffered 1,100 cases of AIDS, and 538 of those people are dead. It is believed that between 15,000 and 25,000 people are infected with the virus.
For almost every day that has passed since that first statement, AIDS has struck another Australian life.

In this short time, the disease has already taken a great toll on the Australian community in terms of lives lost, threatened and ruined, and untold human suffering for people infected by the virus, their relatives, friends and carers.
As Dr Blewett told the Third National Conference on AIDS in Hobart last August, not since World War I has Australia been confronted with similar potential for damage to an entire generation.
And still the number of cases of AIDS mounts inexorably.

The Minister's prediction that AIDS would change our lives forever, challenging our deepest cultural, social and moral values, has come true, but so too has his hope that we would find the national maturity and strength to confront the virus with sensitivity, commonsense and determination.

The early initiative taken by the federal government has been followed by Australia's scientific and medical communities, state governments, community groups, particularly in the homosexual community, and the media. Our cooperative commitment has established urgent education, prevention, screening, counselling and treatment services and successfully secured Australia's blood product supply services. The bipartisan approach we have adopted in our fight against the virus-an approach exemplified by the work of the parliamentary liaison group on aids-has allowed us to rationally take quite radical decisions to protect public health and to minimise reactions born out of fear, ignorance and prejudice.

Thus, we have been able to openly face up to, and come to grips with, the need for public discussion and advocacy of condoms for safer sex, the acknowledgment of bisexual, as well as homosexual, preferences in Australian society, and the distribution of free clean needles and syringes to drug addicts.
Australia has earned international acclaim for strategies to combat the virus which are viewed as exceptionally coherent, innovative and effective.
We shall probably never know the quantitative extent of our success to date, although there is no doubt that some lives have been saved and some suffering avoided.

But what we do know, as an inescapable certainty, is that we cannot rest on our laurels. For the foreseeable future, AIDS is here to stay. This lethal virus will be a fact of life for our children's children. Much can be done to moderate its force, but it cannot be made to disappear.
The harsh reality for Australia is that the AIDS epidemic in this country is still in its infancy; the long haul is only just beginning.

We now stand at the threshold of a new period in our response to the epidemic, a period in which we must make difficult choices about how we deal with AIDS in the decades ahead-choices which will dictate the success or failure of our attempts to stem the tide.

The issues are complex-technically, legally and socially-and touch upon almost every area of our daily lives-health, housing, education, job security, insurance, welfare services, and our personal freedoms.

The policy discussion paper which I am tabling today AIDS: A Time to Care, a Time to Act: Towards a Strategy for all Australians, presents the issues which we must now address and discuss options for their resolution. It is the first step in the development of a national strategy to guide Australia in the management of AIDS during the next stages of the epidemic.

The commitment of Australian governments to strive for agreement on a uniform strategy is best demonstrated by the fact that this discussion paper is, in a historic example of bipartisan consensus, being tabled in every parliament of the land.

At the outset, I must pay tribute to officers of the Department of Community Services and Health and others who have contributed to the preparation of the discussion document, particularly Elizabeth Reid, who has worked tirelessly to produce a document unprecedented in its comprehensiveness, but which still remains relevant to the whole community.

It is testimony to the skills and efforts of Ms Reid and the editorial team that the discussion paper has been endorsed as a suitable basis for public discussion by both the Australian National Council on Aids (ANCA) and the Inter-Governmental Committee on Aids.

I must also stress that the discussion paper does not represent Federal Government Policy, or the policy of any State or Territory Government. Rather, it presents the facts, issues, options and arguments upon which the Australian people need to draw before they, through their governments, can chart a rational and reasoned course for the future.

The first part of the paper outlines what is known about the AIDS epidemic in Australia: how many people might be infected; how infection has and has not occurred; the way infection affects people; what evidence we have of people changing their behaviour; and the resources-human and financial-demanded, to date, by the epidemic.
This part of the paper provides the factual information needed to understand the nature of the problem and to elicit informed and appropriate responses.
The second part of the paper proposes a framework for a national AIDS strategy, and identifies three broad objectives for such a strategy:
to minimise transmission of the virus;
to support, care for and to treat infected people; and
to educate and to prevent the infection of people who care for infected individuals.

While the first two of these objectives have been accepted components of our national approach from the outset, identification of the third recognises the increasingly important role played by people who care for AIDS sufferers-health care workers, families, friends and volunteers.

Because many of the issues on which policies are needed are extremely complex, the paper identifies some key principles to guide discussion and development of strategies. Agreement on these basic principles would be a major step towards consensus on a national approach.

It is in this, the second part of the paper, that the most difficult, and frequently emotive, issues are presented for debate: testing, contact tracing, legal impediments to prevention programs, prevention strategies in prisons, occupational transmission and workplace education, to name but a few.

The last part of the paper deals with Australia's involvement in the international response to the global pandemic, with the research needed to support a National AIDS Strategy, and with monitoring and evaluating the strategy's programs.

The discussion paper canvasses numerous sensitive questions in a frank and forthright style designed to achieve increased understanding and awareness of the issues at stake and a willingness to seriously consider all of the available options so that the simplistic and superficially attractive approaches will not become the natural first choices.

As such, this document is bound to generate widespread discussion of subjects often inhibited in public debate. Such discussion should be encouraged as of central importance to the structuring of a considered, coherent and cooperative national strategy.

It is hoped that the discussion paper will be read and discussed by every section of the Australian community. Every Australian will have the opportunity to participate in the consultative process, as individuals, through community groups, through their elected parliamentary representatives.
It is hoped that the issues will be debated in every medium and in every forum, including this and other Australian parliaments.
The responses elicited from this national debate will be incorporated in the next stage of the preparation of a national strategy: the development of a policy statement on AIDS.

This second document, to be completed in time for consideration in the 1989-90 budget context, will set out a clear, broad national strategy to combat the disease and will delineate areas of responsibility for Federal, State and local governments, as well as other elements of the community.

The policy document will contain a definitive statement of the Commonwealth's policies on AIDS and will, within the strategy it outlines, set out the parameters for funding, administering, coordinating and monitoring AIDS programs and activities.
The preparation of this policy statement will take account of advice from advisory bodies, such as the Australian National Council on AIDS and the Inter-Governmental Committee on AIDS.
The discussion paper provides a framework for the formulation of a national strategy, to which all governments can be committed in principle.
It would be naive in the extreme to believe that we can achieve consensus on every issue raised and detailed decision to be taken.

There will, of course, continue to be diversity of opinion between different States, different communities, different organisations and different individuals, and that diversity will be reflected in the range of programs established to respond to the virus.

The preparation of a national strategy does not negate a diversity of responses-indeed, different approaches and different programs expand both our knowledge of the virus and the options available for dealing with it.

But a national strategy does seek a uniform commitment to principles, the acceptance of which and adherence to which are essential to containment of the epidemic-the difference, if you like, between lives and deaths.

These principles are self-evident when we carefully consider the medical, scientific and social evidence available to guide us in retaining the trust, support and cooperation of the whole Australian community in protecting this nation's public health.
These principles recognise that public health and human rights must march hand in hand where AIDS is concerned; that each is needed to reinforce the effectiveness of the other.

And above all, they recognise that, in the continuing absence of any effective vaccine or cure for the virus, our overriding goal must remain that of persuading people to change their behaviour so that they do not become infected.

In tabling this policy discussion paper, I would like to finish as I began, by reiterating to you part of the speech which the Minister for Health delivered three years ago-words which, despite the passage of time and events, are as relevant today as they were then.

He said: `In developing a national AIDS strategy, Australian health ministers need the active cooperation and support of their parliaments and the community. The Government seeks today the support, cooperation and understanding of honourable members on both sides of this House as we develop a strategy to combat this insidious disease and its tragic consequences'.
We should have no doubts that now is a time to care; a time to act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and the policy discussion paper.

The Senate has now been presented with a ministerial statement attached to a report entitled AIDS: a time to care, a time to act-Towards a strategy for Australians. This is a policy discussion paper on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) crisis. AIDS presents us with a huge variety of both threats and challenges. In the first instance, medically it presents us with the challenge of providing for care and searching for cure. Socially, it presents us with the challenges of social dislocation and personal distress. Legally, it presents us with the challenges of discrimination and the threats to our civil liberties. Economically, it poses the challenges of loss of income for thousands of people who are affected and enormous strains on the public health expenditure of the Commonwealth and the States. Above all, AIDS is a personal, human and individual tragedy.

It challenges our tolerance as human beings and as a community. It challenges the political willingness of governments to act and very often to take decisions in the face of public opinion, particularly when that public opinion is ill informed. AIDS is a worldwide problem and a worldwide phenomenon. It wreaks havoc in Central Africa and in some of the most underprivileged parts of the world. It presents crises in some of the most affluent cities of western Europe, North America and increasingly, one regrets to say, Australia.

A remarkable book was published quite recently, the author of which was Randy Shilts, a journalist working in San Francisco. The book is entitled And the Band Played On. I suspect this title is taken from the apocryphal stories about the sinking of the Titanic. In the prologue to the book, Shilts makes a number of points including that it was only after the announced death of the movie actor, Rock Hudson, on 2 October 1985 that people were prepared to confront the AIDS epidemic in a way which recognised that it was a problem not simply of some closeted minority but indeed a problem that the whole community had to face. In the prologue Shilts says, among other things:

The timing of this awareness, however, reflected the unalterable tragedy at the heart of the AIDS epidemic. By the time America paid attention to the disease, it was too late to do anything about it. The virus was already pandemic in the nation, having spread to every corner of the North American continent. The tide of death that would later sweep America could, perhaps, be slowed, but it could not be stopped.
Elsewhere in that prologue Shilts says:

There was no excuse, in this country and in this time, for the spread of a deadly new epidemic. For this was a time in which the United States boasted the world's most sophisticated medicine and the world's most extensive public health system, geared to eliminate such pestilence from our national life. When the virus appeared, the world's richest nation housed the most lavishly financed scientific research establishments-both inside the vast governmental health bureaucracy and in other institutions-to investigate new diseases and quickly bring them under control.

We, in Australia, are perhaps fortunate that we have been able to learn from some of the American experiences. Nevertheless, despite the fact that we have the opportunity to learn, we also have some quite frightening statistics. We know for example that the cumulative case analysis of people suffering from AIDS in Australia has now reached 1,079, of whom 525 persons have already died.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is yet to be written the definitive history of the AIDS epidemic in Australia. In particular, there has yet to be written the socio-political history of the AIDS epidemic in Australia. Undoubtedly, somebody is at work on it; undoubtedly, somebody's PhD thesis is nearing completion. I believe that we, as a nation, can take some comfort in the way in which there has been an attempt to bring together all the disparate elements which are necessary if we are to put in place an AIDS strategy which will work. There has been a remarkably bipartisan approach to handling most of the sensitive issues with which the AIDS epidemic has confronted us.

SPEECH.PARA: In this institution we have, for example, the parliamentary liaison committee on AIDS which has met for some years now under the chairmanship of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). It has on it representatives of all the major political parties and the independent members in the Senate. By and large we have had a good degree of cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States in an area where, notoriously, rivalries, jealousies and disputations have occurred in the past. We have had a remarkable degree of cooperation between the gay community and the wider Australian community in a number of areas.

We have had remarkable cooperation with individual groups such as the Haemophilia Society with people concerned with the blood transfusion services, with people involved in nursing, with people involved in research, with people involved in education, with people at universities, with people who work in the clinical side of the management of this disease. Although from time to time there have been disputes, rivalries, jealousies and arguments about funding and status and all the other things one comes to expect in an area of public policy as complicated as this, nevertheless I think that as a nation we have handled this crisis remarkably well.

Quite recently my friend and colleague Peter Shack, the shadow Minister for Health, prepared a paper entitled Understanding AIDS: A Necessary First Step Towards Proper Policy Development which he circulated extensively within the ranks of the coalition parties in an attempt to improve from our perspective the understanding of the AIDS crisis. It was an attempt to set forth in non-judgmental and non-technical language answers to the questions which each of us needs to understand in order to decide whether public policy being advocated by government is correct and is likely to achieve its stated goals and hoped-for outcomes. There have been numerous reports on the subject of AIDS in Australia. I draw the attention of the Senate to a couple of them. AIDS: Australia's Response Examined, a report of the second national conference on AIDS held on 31 October and 1 November 1986, is a very significant and useful document. The proceedings of the World Health Organisation Australian Inter-regional Ministerial Meeting on AIDS, held at Westmead Hospital in Sydney in July 1987, included the presentation of a large number of papers of great importance.

It is interesting that this World Health Organisation-sponsored conference, which was supported by authorities in Australia, was opened by His Excellency the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen. I pay great tribute to His Excellency for the way in which he has been prepared to lend the high prestige and respect of his office to the national campaign to do something about AIDS. His Excellency has served as a patron of the AIDS Trust of Australia. His willingness to participate and make significant contributions to international conferences and to national fora and seminars on this question indicates the extent to which he has been prepared to use high office in the most valuable service to the nation.

Here in the Parliament the Legislative Research Service recently produced a document entitled AIDS-The Social Issues, a most comprehensive and useful examination of social policy questions which we as parliamentarians and law makers have to face up to. The report entitled AIDS and the Workplace, a national consensus statement, was agreed to by all Australian governments at Federal, State and Territory level, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. There has been a coming together of people in the workplace, of unionists and employers, of Commonwealth and State governments, to attempt to lay down guidelines for dealing with this problem.

There have been investigations on the financial side of things. I look at the report produced by Touche Ross International for the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health entitled Costing the AIDS Epidemic in Australia which was published in March 1988. So there has been an attempt to come to an evaluation of the economic side of this problem. I will dwell for a moment on that side of the problem; it is something which in the climate in which we spend so much time talking about costs and prices needs to be at least mentioned in passing this evening. The report which we have before us estimates that the AIDS epidemic costs Australia somewhere in the vicinity of $400m a year in treatment costs and lost productivity.

If I look at an article which appeared in the journal Science in February 1988 entitled `The Economic Impact of AIDS in the United States', by Bloom and Carliner, I see that they calculate that, on the worst cost scenario projected in the United States, the public health expenditure costs of treating AIDS between 1981 and 1991 will be in the vicinity of $22 billion. I look at extracts from the public health reports of the United States in July 1987 and I read from the introduction of that report:

According to what the authors consider their best estimates, personal medical costs of AIDS in current dollars will rise from $630m in 1985 to $1.1 billion in 1986, to $8.5 billion in 1991. Non-personal costs for research, screening, education and general support services are estimated to rise from $319m in 1985 to $542m in 1986, and $2.3 billion in 1991. Indirect costs attributable to loss of productivity resulting from morbidity and premature mortality are estimated to rise from $3.9 billion in 1985 to $7 billion in 1986 and $55.6 billion in 1991.

So we are talking about vast sums of public money, going to the health and care system in Australia at a greater rate and greater level than we have ever had to confront in the past. The United States, as Shilts's book indicates, was slow off the mark in this regard. In fact, it has only recently come to the position which we achieved in Australia some years ago. On 24 June 1988 there was presented to the President of the United States a report of the Presidential Commission on the Human Immuno Deficiency Virus Epidemic, the so-called Watkins report-after its Chairman, retired United States Admiral James D. Watkins. In his report Admiral Watkins says:

The Commission has identified the following obstacles to a nationwide effort to improve the public's response to and participation in programs designed to quantify the HIV epidemic at the federal, state and local levels:
Continued focus on the label ``AIDS'', contributing to a lack of understanding of the importance of HIV infection as the more significant element for taking control of the epidemic.
Lack of strong CDC-
that is, centres for disease control-
leadership in the public health community for obtaining and coordinating HIV infection data.
Lack of uniform and strong anti-discrimination laws protecting those infected with HIV.
Excessive concern about potential problems with testing programs and reporting systems.
Inadequate counselling resources to assist those tested makes many support and interest groups reluctant to recommend widespread HIV testing.

All those issues in the Watkins report have been addressed in a number of reports in Australia over past years and have been addressed once again in the report which we have before us presented by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on behalf of the Minister for Community Services and Health this evening. The Minister's tabling statement included this point, which I think it is important to understand and to accept:
The harsh reality for Australia is that the AIDS epidemic in this country is still in its infancy; the long haul is only just beginning.

The Minister is correct. What we are looking at at the moment-which I have already described as a crisis and which other people have already described as a crisis-is a picture frozen in time. It is in many respects, because of the nature of the virus and its manifestation, the picture as it was some years ago. We do not know the real situation as of today. We know today of those who were infected some years ago and who are now starting to manifest the various symptoms of the HIV infection. We do not know yet, nor will we know for five, six, seven or perhaps eight years, exactly what today's situation is in Australia. That is something yet to be revealed to us. The only thing that one can say with confidence is that it will be worse, and that in itself is a further challenge for our medical resources, our medical researchers and our public policy analysts and planners.

I pause in my discussion of this report to draw attention to the fact that in the Minister's tabling statement he makes reference to the skill and dedication of Miss Elizabeth Reid, who has been the Government's primary adviser in the development of this discussion document. I would like to say on my own behalf and on behalf of all coalition senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the support of my colleague Senator Peter Baume-that the work which Miss Reid has undertaken has been of outstanding national value. She knows a great deal, for all sorts of reasons, about the AIDS tragedy. She has contributed in a remarkable way to the development of public policy in Australia and we are very much in her debt for the amount of effort which she has made in that regard. The report, AIDS: a time to care, a time to act-Towards a strategy for Australians, identifies the very broad outlines of a national strategy and it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Three objectives for a national AIDS strategy are proposed:
(1) To minimise transmission of the human immunodeficiency virus;
(2) to support, care for and treat people infected with HIV; and
(3) to educate and to prevent the infection of people who care for HIV infected individuals.
It is not a document which proposes anything more than a broad strategy; it is a document which sets out options, facts and alternatives.

The Minister is calling for public comment on this document to be received by him through a coordinating committee, until January next year. It is then proposed that in about May next year the Government will release a White Paper in which it will indicate its responses to the recommendations which have been put before it by both its expert advisers and the community and that will have some impact on decisions to be made for the 1989 Federal Budget. This is already a major Budget item. In the current Budget, $15.1m has been added into the Medicare hospital funding arrangements with the States to deal specifically with the treatment of AIDS patients. A further $25m is provided in 1988-89 of which $12.5m, including an additional $1.7m, has been allocated to a cost-sharing program with the States for education, prevention and counselling. Also, an amount of $12.5m includes an additional $1.3m for the national program covering research, media and education campaigns, community projects and information exchange programs. So we are already talking, even within the smaller Australian context, of large dollar sums.

As I have said, the report does not attempt to make any definitive recommendations to government; its purpose is to start the next phase of the discussion. Therefore, I will draw attention to one or two matters which I think are important and which need to be addressed. The first-and in many ways I think the most important-is what are the appropriate educational strategies? I refer to an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association of 12 August 1988 entitled `Stockholm Speakers on Adolescents and AIDS: ``Catch them before they catch it'' '. This report of the Fourth International Conference on AIDS, held in Stockholm, refers to the question of strategies designed primarily to address the behavioural changes which are necessary in adolescents in order to prevent them from engaging in risk behaviour.

I think this is the appropriate point at which to say that the question of AIDS is not a question of who you are; it is a question of how you behave. It is the behaviour modification rather than the categorisation of persons which is important in the public debate. It is, as I say, not who you are and not in that sense what you are, but how you behave which is central to the question of the control and eventual, one hopes, tackling of the general problem as far as AIDS is concerned. Of course, this leads one into complex and difficult areas. For example, we know that both the Tasmanian and Queensland State governments have had some difficulty in recent times with some of the educational material which has been circulated and which is designed to appeal to certain categories of individuals and to persuade people engaging in certain types of behaviour to seek behaviour modification. In fact, those State governments have had difficulty allowing the promotional activities of the `Safe Sex' campaign to take place.

There continues to be large areas of disagreement about the future prognosis for the community with respect to this disease. I refer to the transcript of a program called AIDS Now, which was broadcast on 7 September 1988 and which dealt with the question, `AIDS: Is there going to be a heterosexual epidemic?'. Dr Charles Farthing, Physician of St Stephen's Hospital, London, said:
A heterosexual epidemic is absolutely certain to occur. There's no question about that, it's just a matter of when, and how quickly.

At the same time an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association of April 1988 entitled `Preventing the Heterosexual Spread of AIDS' indicates that there are contrary views. It states that in fact that will not be the prognosis for the disease and that the widespread growth of AIDS within the heterosexual community is not something which is inevitable. So there continues to be disputation even among scientists and government advisers. Of course, there is an enormous political dimension to this. For example, a book recently published entitled The Myth of heterosexual AIDS argues that the AIDS public policy debate in the United States of America has been taken over by certain vested interests and groups and in fact has been steered in a political direction rather than in a direction which properly reflects the demands and requirements of public health policy in that country.

I will list-without attempting in any sense to explore any of the issues-the sorts of issues which this paper raises and which need to be addressed. There is the question of cost and the question of the direction of research. There is the question of treatment and the availability of pharmaceuticals. There are the questions of discrimination and confidentiality of record keeping. There are questions of advertising and of education. There are questions of how to reach the intravenous drug users who may be the primary conduit of the spread of the virus into the heterosexual community, including disputes about free heroin programs or the availability of needle exchange programs. There is the question of how one deals with the prison population. There is the question of how one deals with the peculiarities of this disease in the Aboriginal community. There is the question of how one reaches and deals with the prostitutes in Australia. There are questions of insurance.

There are questions of safety in the workplace and, perhaps above all, there are questions about the desirability of widescale and, in some instances, compulsory testing for the presence of the HIV virus. This will not be an easy exercise, nor will it be cheap. It will not be an exercise in which we will be able to avoid hysteria in some quarters and apathy in others. It will not be a debate in which we will manage to avoid some of the worst aspects of partisan politics, but at the same time it can be a debate in which we can draw upon the best aspects of bipartisan politics.

I very much welcome the publication of the report AIDS: a time to care, a time to act-Towards a strategy for Australians'. The Federal Opposition welcomes the publication of this discussion document. We now have to confront perhaps one of the most serious public health crisis ever to face this country. We must discharge our responsibilities not only as legislators, law makers and leaders of community opinion, but, indeed, as individual citizens and people of responsibility and, I hope, judgment and care. In order to do that I believe that this document should have the widest possible circulation and the widest possible debate. I congratulate those responsible for preparing the document and for publishing it. It is perhaps a signal event in Australian public policy that this document has been distributed today to every parliament of Australia, in upper and lower Houses of every State and the Commonwealth. I do not know that that has ever occurred before. I think it is an indication of the magnitude of the problem and of the seriousness with which Commonwealth and State governments and Ministers view the problem. They are prepared to turn their minds to doing something about this crisis.

I commenced my remarks by drawing attention to Randy Shilts's book And the Band Played On. It is to be hoped that, unlike the band on the Titanic, we are able to get everyone into the lifeboats and away securely and safely. To the extent that the Federal Opposition can play any role in facilitating that process, I can assure the Government that we will do so to our utmost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Government wholeheartedly in its stand on the very difficult problem of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) as outlined in the excellent policy discussion paper before us. All Australians must face the fact that there may be no cure for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) this century. The problems associated with AIDS can be addressed positively now, but we must be prepared to carry the costs which the necessary course of action will inevitably entail.

SPEECH.PARA: In the most simplistic terms, we can think of our reaction to this problem in this way: Between the ages of four and seven most of us are taught to do one of the most dangerous things that we will ever do in our lives, that is, to cross the road safely on our own. Between the ages of 16 and 24 most of us are taught to use responsibly one of the most lethal machines known to society: the car. We must now undertake to teach all of our young people between the ages of perhaps 10 and 16 how to engage in sex safely.

All the challenges of the AIDS epidemic must be faced realistically and with compassion. However, there is no escaping the old wisdom that drastic problems require drastic solutions. The Government has identified three broad areas which must be addressed and discussed before a national AIDS strategy can be formulated. Broadly these areas are prevention or at least minimisation of the spread of the virus; support for and treatment of sufferers; and education, testing and prevention of the infection of carriers. In the area of prevention and minimisation, the Democrats believe that several steps should be taken immediately throughout the country. Some of these may appear at first to be rather radical, but they are all necessary in the crisis situation in which we now find ourselves. One of these steps is obviously easy access throughout the country to condoms and clean syringes. The Government is to be applauded for its efforts already taken in this direction.

We also believe that a pilot program should be approved immediately to provide the necessary injectables to addicted intravenous (IV) drug users who test HIV positive. This program should be carried out initially in Sydney, as this is the worst AIDS affected city of Australia's major population centres. IV drug users should be tested whenever possible. We also believe that all State governments should decriminalise prostitution so that all prostitutes can be registered and regularly tested for AIDS and all other sexually transmissible diseases. The difficult problem of Australia's prison system and the role of prisons as AIDS incubators is one which we must come to grips with as soon as possible. The solution will not be an easy one, as it must be acceptable to prison officers and to the majority of the occupants of the prison system. As with most problems associated with this difficult area, we must resolve the fine distinction between the basic human rights of the AIDS carrier and those of the people with whom the carrier comes into close contact.

Research into HIV identification procedures and into cures of the virus must receive huge increases in funding and must, of course, be encouraged at all levels. The current system of screening and testing blood donors in Australia is working extremely well and only needs refining as updated procedures become available. Our blood banks are to be congratulated on the prompt and effective steps they took at the first signs of the infection through blood donations. I believe we were the world leader in this field. The Democrats agree that support for infected people must be immediate, compassionate and thorough. We believe that funding must be provided for subsidised home care wherever possible, especially in the early stages of infection. More facilities should be established along the lines of the specialised ward at Sydney's Prince Henry Hospital. The establishment and design of this ward is a credit to the former Labor Government of New South Wales, and its continued existence is a credit to the current Liberal- National Party Government of that State. It has proved to be a very successful program and it should be extended to other sites as soon as possible.

AIDS education is a subject on which the Democrats have very strong views. We believe that adequate AIDS education should be mandatory in all Australian high schools and taught in the lower years before school attendance becomes optional. Education of the general public should continue along the very successful lines already established by the Government through television, radio and press advertising in both newspapers and magazines. The targeting of specific groups must be continued with educational material presented in a reader friendly form tailored to precise needs in such things as the very successful Streetwise comics, gay publications and materials distributed among IV drug users. This process must be broadened and accelerated.

The Government has also specified another target group, those who care for infected individuals. This is an area which has not been discussed previously in detail and one which must be addressed as soon as possible. The Australian Democrats applaud this government initiative. The policy discussion paper is well researched, well set out and obviously a sensitive, reasoned and intelligent approach to what is fast becoming the major health problem of the human race. We congratulate those who have contributed to the production of this excellent policy discussion document. I sincerely hope that this paper will have the widest possible circulation and will encourage discussion in all sections of Australian society, so that a co- hesive, comprehensive and positive strategy can be developed as soon as possible to combat this potentially devastating epidemic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the report tabled in the Parliament on 10 November on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, known as the Cross report. As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I lodged a dissenting report to the recommendations put forward. I want to put on record my reasons for doing so. I want to make it clear that I agree with many of the recommendations of the report. I also want to make clear that my criticism should not be interpreted as a lack of understanding of, or concern for, the problems currently experienced by service families.

SPEECH.PARA: I was impressed by the goodwill and dedication of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel and their families in making their presentations to the Committee. I hope that if the report's recommendations are implemented some of those problems will be alleviated. However, I see a basic contradiction in the simultaneous calls for normalisation and uniqueness. On one hand, the Committee heard urgent pleas for the stresses on family life to be reduced. On the other hand, there was a reiteration of the special position of the ADF. Family life stresses could be reduced by meeting personal needs for security, stability and better self-image. However, these same problems are exacerbated by what the report refers to as the uniqueness of life within the ADF institution.

The very reasonable calls for family life to be more normal will remain unmet as long as ADF families move as frequently as they do at present. What families need is stability to be able to educate their children in fewer than half a dozen or so schools; to be able to buy a home, which is only worth doing if a placement is for more than a two-year period; and for spouses to be able to find permanent employment and to build long term relationships outside the nuclear family unit. All of these things are common problems with other sections of the work force, such as business people, bankers and teachers, who are on the move as well-although the degree of family disruption is greater within the Services. This situation will not improve while the constancy of placement changes is maintained at the present level.

The disruptions and, therefore, the resignations also will continue while the emphasis on remote locations continues, removing families from many of the amenities available in the urban situation of education, employment and entertainment. Dissatisfaction with displacement also will continue if the Royal Australian Navy is relocated from Sydney to Jervis Bay-a move which is not popular, I gather, with many Navy families. The dissatisfaction also will continue while there is a great deal of time spent away from home base on exercises, many of which I would argue are not necessary for Australia's defence but which are held in remote locations far from Australia's shores and which suit our allies' needs rather than our own defence needs.

The dissatisfaction also will continue as long as service life is glamourised by such grand events as military tattoos, naval reviews and air shows which attempt to glorify service life out of all proportion to the reality. For example, last week during the Australian Grand Prix in Adelaide as well as all the noise and pollution from the racing cars there was the `added treat' for the public of Royal Australian Air Force planes doing their thing over Adelaide. It was a show of power and speed at great expense to the taxpayers, I might add, and also at great risk to the populace. I heard on good authority that the volunteer medical teams operating during the Grand Prix were told quite clearly that the greatest threat to the public was not from racing cars going out of control on the track, not from public stands collapsing, nor from fire, but from those planes on their demonstration flights across the city. An accident involving one of those planes on a display flight would have been disastrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?

—I got that information from one of the medical officers involved in providing services during the Grand Prix. That kind of glorification of war machinery we can do without. That kind of invited risk we can do without; as the West Germans have recently discovered to their great cost.

SPEECH.PARA: Young people often get the wrong idea about service life. This is often due to some of the advertising used by the Department of Defence to attract young people, for the wrong reasons. For example, I refer to the ad which was placed in the Australian Women's Weekly and various other magazines around the country headed `Navy Blues'. This has been criticised very rightly as being racist and sexist and has now been withdrawn. Senator Newman was among the critics of this particular advertisement which stated:
Aussie sailors are experts on the local brews from Bangkok to San Diego and have a well deserved reputation for really knowing how to enjoy themselves.
The advertisement continued:

After work they are just as likely to find themselves in some exotic new place and then it's on with the freshly laundered best blues and off with your mates to make a close study of the local wildlife. All work and no play makes Jack a very dull boy, but not in the Australian Navy.

The advertisement showed a very colourful picture of two or three women with sailors in tow, at very close quarters. The advertisement was also racist because the women very obviously were from countries other than our own. I am not going to get into an argument about Navy personnel or make judgments about whether in fact that is how the Navy behaves on leave, as portrayed in the advertisement. However, I think it is a disgrace that service life is promoted in that way. I am pleased to say that that advertisement has been withdrawn after community criticism.

Often life in the Services is very boring and very hierarchical. There are some quite nonsensical practices which are rigidly followed for no better reason than that they are traditional or that they impose discipline. For example, when I visited the Australian Defence Force Academy last year I was very amused to see personnel goosestepping around the quadrangles and in between the various buildings, not necessarily on parade or exercises. I could see no logical reason for that whatsoever. However, the advertisements for all branches of the Services generally show the he-man, action type of colour photographs with shots of male personnel all dressed up in their macho battle gear looking very aggressive. If that is what our service life is really like, I think that is a great shame. I believe that even people in the Services would agree that some of these advertisements are misleading, to say the least.

In other smaller countries such as Scandinavia and the Netherlands, work in the military is considered a normal vocation like any other job. It is not glamorised and service men and women fit into the community unobtrusively. Life would be a lot easier for service personnel and their families in Australia if we did not set the ADF so apart and if more emphasis were placed on the positive role of community services which the ADF actually provides within the community-for example, relief work during natural disasters such as fighting bushfires and assisting in flood situations. Obviously, this is a very positive role, which I do not think gets enough community emphasis, which would help the image of service people as part of the community instead of being set apart from the community. Another positive role which could be more emphasised is the peacekeeping role of the forces when they serve with the United Nations forces in various parts of the world. The United Nations Peacekeeping Force actually won the Nobel Peace Prize this year. These forces largely are unarmed and, in fact, see combat as a last resort. I think that this positive peacekeeping role should be emphasised rather than the macho image of men playing war games.

It would be worth while further developing some of the ideas put forward by Colonel Langtry in his submissions to the inquiry on an expanded role for the reserve which could result in a smaller Regular Army force. The days are gone when Australian Defence Force personnel and their families were prepared to be shunted around the country at the whim of the hierarchy. Their personal needs must be met. Lack of support from senior officers in dealing with family stress was referred to often in the submissions to the inquiry. I believe that this contributes to low morale. This is largely a consequence of the hierarchical nature of service life.

The input from the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses to the Committee was valuable. As a lobby group for more humane treatment and better conditions it is effective. However, its effectiveness is limited. For service personnel to be normalised within the wider community they need access to industrial action. Trade union activity would ensure that the conditions of workers were improved. After all, it is conditions of service that the high level of wastage is all about.

What the argument finally comes down to is dollars, as usual. If the Defence Department and the ADF want to maintain the alliance with the United States, if they want more and better equipment, which is highly expensive, and also better conditions for personnel, they are going to have to squeeze a lot more than around the 2 1/2 per cent of the gross domestic product and just under 10 per cent from Budget allocation out of government coffers. Defence expenditure has traditionally been at a figure less than 3 per cent of GDP in peacetime Australia. Will the Department of Defence and the ADF be able to convince the Australian public that they should be spending more on defence to satisfy both hardware and personnel demands? I think not. I certainly would be against that as I think that our defence dollars could be better spent. This was not the subject of the inquiry but because that wider aspect of defence policy was not addressed this report will probably not totally satisfy anyone.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The articles read as follows-
Aboriginal Housing Company Said to Have Breached Company Law
By Rod Campbell

A leading firm of chartered accountants has identified numerous breaches of company law and government grant conditions, and uncovered long-standing poor accounting methods, in its investigation into the financial affairs of the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Company.

The company, which is now in the hands of a receiver/manager after defaulting on a $148,000 loan, was set up in 1977 to provide housing and other accommodation for Aboriginal people in the Warrego region of western Queensland. Its government funding-through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission-ceased in 1986.

As reported in The Canberra Times yesterday, the accountants, Ernst and Whinney, reported a number of major areas in which the company's financial management practices were deficient. These included accountability for assets, control over and recording of income, and authorisation for payments.
The report identified a number of breaches of the Queensland Company Code, the company's articles of association and the terms of government grant agreements.

It also reported on substantial unbanked money, irregularities in payments, the granting of retrospective loans to directors of the company and the purchase by the company of property from directors, including the chairman, Ray Robinson. Mr Robinson is also chairman of the Queensland Aboriginal Legal Service.
More detailed findings on some of those matters are as follows:

During November 1987, the company purchased two vacant lots from Mr Robinson for $17,000, a house and land from Mr Robinson and his wife for $58,000, and a house and land from Mr Gregory Davidson and his wife for $48,000. Mr Davidson is a member of the company's committee.

The accountants noted that Mr Robinson had purchased ``certain properties'' and sold them to the company ``at a substantial profit''. In turn, Mr Robinson said the price paid by the company had been supported by independent valuations.
The accountants said a property purchased by Mr Robinson in March 1985 for $32,000 had been sold to the company six months later for $44,000.

They had access to two independent valuations on each of the properties purchased in November 1987. One had been prepared by A. J. Hamilton, of Charleville, and the other by J. E. Liley, of Toowoomba. Mr Hamilton had valued Mr Robinson's vacant lots at $16,000 in July, 1986, while Mr Liley had valued them at $8000 in November 1987. The company had purchased the lots for $17,000 that same month. Mr Hamilton had valued the Robinson house and land at $54,032 in October 1986, while Mr Liley had valued it at $37,000 13 months later. It had been purchased for $58,000. Finally, Mr Hamilton had valued the Davidson property at about $46,000 and Mr Liley, a month later, at $28,500. It had sold for $48,000.

The accountants found that a number of payments made by the company required further audit investigation before conclusions could be drawn about their propriety. These included a large number of payments to the ``CEP Market Garden'', certain payments noted as ``to be reimbursed'' by various individuals and organisations, a $2500 cash payment noted as being for ``Liquidator NAC Furniture'', several travel-allowance payments to Mr Robinson, and $5000 paid to a firm for legal fees and ``consultation and negotiation'' of a $20,000 loan.

The accountants had not been provided with any material concerning the CEP Market Garden account and could not investigate the payments made to it. While the practice of making such payments had not been unusual or uncommon between related entities, it was important that good quality accounting records be maintained to monitor reimbursements. There was no evidence that these had been maintained, they said.

The only documentation, other than a payment voucher, concerning the $2500 had been in a letter from the company administrator, Ken Munro, to the Aboriginal Development Corporation, to the effect that the money had been paid to the liquidator of the NAC for the purchase of the furniture being used in the community centre by ``the ex-NAC member and chairman of the company''. Mr Robinson, the chairman, had confirmed this.
A $5000 cheque had been paid to a company called Pelargic Pty Ltd, although this should have read Pelagic. The only supporting documentation had been a payment voucher.
Mr Robinson had said that the firm was a financial broker and had arranged meetings for Mr Robinson with Mercantile Credits to obtain a $148,000 loan.

The accountants could not contact anyone at Pelagic to discover the nature of the services provided. They wondered whether the reference to a $20,000 loan was related to the $148,000 or to something else.

The accountants said 128 cheques had been issued from the company's general account in the year ended June 30, 1987. Vouchers had been issued for 122 of these, 58 of which had been unauthorised. During that period, 48 cheques drawn on the community-worker account had been issued, 19 without authorisation.

The accountants said a $6500 loan to Mr Robinson had been noted in the company's 1986 financial statement. Other transactions were also noted. These included payments from Mr Robinson totalling $6870 and payments to him of $1200. The accountants concluded that if all the transactions related to loans, Mr Robinson still owed the company $830.

A company cheque for $150 had been paid to a Charleville publican in relation to a cheque cashed at a hotel by Martin Ebsworth, a company director. Mr Ebsworth had apparently repaid $100 of this. Another cheque, for $1000, had been paid to Mr Robinson and noted as ``advance of wage''. The word ``advance'' had been crossed out and ``loan'' written underneath. This had been repaid over several weeks.
With one minor exception, government grants to the company ceased in 1986. However, the accountants noted numerous breaches of grant conditions before this.

It said the company's purchase of properties late last year with money borrowed from Mercantile Credits could represent the borrowing of money in anticipation of a grant, contrary to ADC rules. Also contrary to ADC rules had been the unauthorised loans to directors, some of which came from grant money.

Assets acquired with grant money costing more than $500 had to be recorded in an asset register but no such register had been kept. Although ADC and departmental rules required assets to be safeguarded against loss or damage, one company house had not been insured and several had not been kept in a good state of repair.

In December, 1987, the company had mortgaged eight properties as security for the $148,000 loan without obtaining prior approval from the department or ADC. Unexpended grant money from 1985 and 1986 did not appear to have been satisfactorily acquitted.
Auditors slam Aboriginal company
By Rod Campbell

An Aboriginal housing company in Queensland, now in the hands of a receiver and manager, made unauthorised loans to its directors, engaged in a number of questionable transactions and had poor control over assets and income, a leading firm of chartered accountants has found.
The chairman of the company, the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Company Ltd, is Ray Robinson, also chairman of the Queensland Aboriginal Legal Service.

Mr Robinson has been a vocal critic of the Aboriginal Development Commission and in September, at a meeting in Queensland, moved a vote of no confidence against two senior ADC officers over their handling of a $300,000 loan to an Aboriginal group in NSW to purchase a Kangaroo works.

Mr Robinson was one of two of the Charleville company's directors who sold property to the company based on 12-month-old valuations and, in Mr Robinson's case, at a substantial profit. The accountants, Ernst and Whinney, said substantially lower valuations had been prepared by another valuer but it could not draw any conclusions on the conflicting valuations.

To finance these purchases, and to pay outstanding debts following the cessation of government funding, the company had borrowed $148,000 from Mercantile Credits but had failed to meet the monthly repayments. As a result, Mercantile Credits had appointed receivers and managers to the company in April. Ernst and Whinney concluded that the company was unlikely to be able to repay the loan or service the interest on the debt without the resumption of funding.
The accountants' report was sent to the Queensland regional office of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in June. The department had commissioned the report earlier in the year.
Detailed, audit work began in March after a large volume of company books, records and vouchers, which had been seized by Queensland Fraud Squad detectives, had been forwarded to Ernst and Whinney.

The accountants said that during November, 1987, the company had spent $123,000 to purchase three properties from directors of the company and their families. The purchase prices had been based on valuations, some more than a year old, which valued the three properties at $116,000. Another valuer, whose valuations were done at about the time of the sales, put a total valuation of $73,500 on them.
``We are unable to draw any conclusions as to the differences between the two valuations,'' the accountants said.

They found that the company's tenants owed it more than $35,000 in outstanding rent. On the other hand, it owed the Murweh Shire Council nearly $20,000 for rates, about $3700 to another firm of auditors and apparently owed Mr Robinson several weeks wages.

The accountants concluded that the company's directors and management were ``not skilled in accounting procedures or financial management'' and appeared to have ``limited knowledge of legal requirements for a public company'' incorporated in Queensland. Accountability for assets was poor, control over, and recording of, income from tenants was deficient and the authorisation and documentary support for payments was inadequate. A number of breaches of the requirements of the company's articles and the Queensland Company Code in relation to meetings and recording minutes had been noted.
The auditors said there had been a number of payments that required further audit investigation ``before conclusions could be drawn regarding their propriety''.

Payments were generally well supported by internally generated payment vouchers, although a large number of these bore no authorising signature. A significant number of payments were not supported by invoices or documentation that might provide evidence that the goods and services had been received. It was, the report said, very difficult to draw any specific conclusions about the reasonableness of many of the payments.
``Certain questionable transactions were identified and an explanation for them obtained from the directors,'' it said.

``In addition, various unauthorised loans to directors were made. While the majority of such loans have now been repaid, and certain of the loans were given retrospective approval by the directors, the practice of making such loans constitutes a breach of the code and represent a serious internal control risk, particularly given the company's unreliable accounting systems''.
Overall, the company's management had failed to conduct its affairs in a ``proper and accountable manner'', the accountants said.
More on the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Company tomorrow.

The better view has to be that he knew very well that the matter was still under investigation. He was not, as it was reportedly said, cleared. It suited his purpose and the purpose of the Minister, who had him flown to Canberra at public expense to speak in support of the Minister's legislation and to tell senators a different story.

We have not heard a word from the Minister, Mr Hand, after the transcript of evidence of 2 September appeared. Opposition senators have had to drag the information out of the Minister about Mr Robinson and the murky affairs of the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Co. Why did the Minister not make a correction to the evidence when he saw it? Is this whole episode yet another case where Minister Hand was not involved? Was the bringing of Mr Robinson and others to Canberra yet another serious and significant event in Aboriginal Affairs about which the Minister knew nothing? Did he just turn a blind eye? Was it a case of the left hand not knowing what the other was doing, if honourable senators would pardon the pun? A curious passage in those Senate committee proceedings of 2 September occurred when Senator Coulter asked Mr Robinson:
I understand the audit was held up while the Ombudsman's investigation into the ADC was proceeding.

He was referring to a complaint Mr Robinson had made to the Ombudsman earlier in the year. Mr Robinson replied, `That is not correct'. What is the truth of this matter? Did the Minister, Mr Hand, make some sort of deal with Mr Robinson last year to delay the appointment of an auditor? As a result of Mr Hand's direction was the commencement of the audit delayed for over five months until March 1988? The Opposition has heard allegations that there was a delay last year. Did this delay afford the company time in which to borrow $148,000 from Mercantile Credits Ltd, a sum which the company must have known it had no chance of repaying out of its own resources and against which it offered its Commonwealth funded housing stock as security without seeking or obtaining consent to do so? Is it a fact that those moneys were borrowed to permit the purchase of property from Mr Robinson and his fellow company director, Mr Davidson, at a price over 60 per cent above the valuations then current? Is it a fact that $28,000 of this money is still not accounted for?

The gullibility of the Minister, Mr Hand, in accepting various points of view, particularly from someone such as Mr Robinson with such a bad track record over 15 to 20 years, must be seriously questioned. I therefore ask the Minister to table the facts of this allegation. The quid pro quo for the Minister was getting Mr Robinson's support for ATSIC, something Mr Robinson delivered in evidence, albeit flawed evidence, before the Senate Select Committee and at an Aboriginal community committee in Rockhampton on 15 and 16 September when he tried unsuccessfully three times to get a motion supporting ATSIC adopted.

We are not just talking about anyone. By his own account given to the Senate Select Committee on 2 September, Mr Robinson holds a number of key positions in Aboriginal Affairs. He has stated in evidence that he holds the following positions: Chairman of the QEB Legal Service; Chairman of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Service for the whole of Queensland; Chairman of the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Co.; a member of the QEB Sporting Foundation; Treasurer of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Services Secretariat-that is, the national legal service coordinating body; and an executive member of the National Sporting Council.

It was apparent from evidence to the Estimates Committee that the Sporting Council included various mates of Charles Perkins. No-one elected them; they just got appointed by the former Secretary to the Department. Among them were Sugar Ray Robinson and Phillip Hall, two people with nasty criminal records. We are asked to believe that the Minister knew nothing of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I have sat patiently through this speech. Senator Tambling has made an allegation that a person lied to a Senate committee. He has made an allegation that the same person presented `flawed evidence' to a Senate committee. I have listened in vain for him to substantiate those allegations, but he has gone on to ask a series of questions which do not amount to a substantiation. The forum of the Senate is not available to malign people. An accusation that someone has lied is an accusation that, at best-if it is to be persisted with-should be supported with some evidence to justify it, otherwise the chamber can be ill-used to victimise individuals. More importantly, if Senator Tambling believes what he is saying, there is an obligation on him to inform the Senate why he has not taken action to refer it to the Privileges committee.

—Order! There is no point of order. However, I remind the Senate, as I reminded it today in respect of allegations about Senator Walsh, that resolution No. 9 can be referred to. If any of the people who have been named wish to refer the matter to me, they can do so.

—I am surprised about this, given the fact that we have called repeatedly for these audit reports and various other information to be tabled. I believe that most of the issues I have raised can be substantiated in the various Hansards of Senate select committees, Senate Estimates committees and the Senate. If Mr Robinson's record of converting Aboriginal moneys to his own use is half as good as evidenced in the auditors' report on just one of these organisations, we ought to be very worried about what may be happening in all of the others I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister ought to be worried now, even if he apparently was not before. He should tell us what he has done. We were told in the Estimates Committee that Mr Robinson has serious criminal charges hanging over him. We see, if the Canberra Times account is anywhere near correct, a man who has played fast and loose with the very homes in which the Aboriginal people of Charleville live and with the public money provided for that purpose. Yet he continues to hold office, and very influential office, in a whole range of organisations. How many of them are funded by DAA? He is even treasurer of the national body dealing with Aboriginal legal aid. The Minister, Mr Hand, has done nothing. He has continued to fund and support these various bodies. Perhaps this whole affair is something else that no-one told him about. How can he be satisfied to provide grant moneys to any of the organisations associated with Mr Robinson? No doubt he will tell us that the principle of self-determination must be observed and that the Auditor-General, Mr Menzies or someone else will find out the truth one of these days.

We are talking about public funds made available to assist Aboriginal people in need. Yet the Minister, Mr Hand, complacently sits by while there is a most serious risk of even more funds being creamed off. Already it seems that $150,000 had just disappeared and the people whose houses were mortgaged over their heads risk eviction. How much more proof does this Minister need? It is simply not good enough to say that this matter will be looked at by the Auditor-General and nothing will be hidden. In fact, the matter has been kept hidden for far too long already and there is at least a suspicion that there was a deal to keep it so. At a time when the Government apparently still thinks that the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is a valid way for the future management of Aboriginal affairs, the Minister, Mr Hand, scandalously neglects his clear duty to discipline the most blatant case of abuse so far uncovered by the Opposition. I say `uncovered': had we not asked questions in this place and persisted until some believable replies were given, this matter would have remained hidden. Mr Robinson would have been standing for election as a commissioner for ATSIC.

When will the Government do something to stop this kind of blatant misappropriation? The reality is that Mr Hand is so obsessed with his vision of a new world through ATSIC that he can see no harm in a few rorts, especially when those getting the benefits extend their political support to his dream of the future. When will Labor senators opposite wake up?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Tambling has just made an unparliamentary accusation against the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and he should withdraw it.
—I think there was a clear imputation against the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and I ask Senator Tambling to withdraw.

—I withdraw that remark, Mr President. In the meantime, hundreds of thousands of ordinary, decent Aboriginal people suffer in two ways: firstly, funds intended to improve their lot are diverted to the private benefit of so-called leaders in the name of self-determination and, secondly, they have to suffer the public's prejudice which they have done nothing to deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in the habit of regularly circulating to a number of members of the Australian Defence Force material on defence matters which have been discussed in this chamber. In the past I have not chosen to circulate the naive and dangerous unilateral disarmament nonsense which we receive regularly from Senator Vallentine. However, I intend to make an exception with her speech tonight because I think all members of the Defence Force should see just what dreadful drivel we have been subjected to in this place by the senator from Western Australia who should be ashamed of the language she has used tonight about our service men and women. I am sure that all honourable senators would condemn her for her attitude. I thought it was quite disgraceful. I hope that other senators share my concern. I believe that Australian service men and women should know of the total lack of support that they would receive at the hands of Senator Vallentine. But at least we are comforted by knowing that there is no chance that she and her like will ever get a chance to form a government in this country. God help Australia if that ever became an eventuality. For all its faults, at least the Labor Government has sufficient members who are prepared to support a defence force, even though two of its Ministers, in my opinion, have failed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine talked about glorifying the Defence Force. I imagine that she puts me in the class of those who do glorify the Defence Force. She does not believe that there should be any special help for servicemen and their families and she talks of Sweden. When she talks of little Sweden with its closely built-up areas and ease of communication and access for most of the inhabited areas, let me remind her of the vastness of our remote country and the difficult and lonely places to which our servicemen may be sent, with or without their families. Let me remind her of the 15 men sent to the Middle East whom our Government has forgotten, the men who are part of the force sent by the United Nations to the Iraq-Iran border. The force of which those men are a part has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. One would have expected Senator Vallentine at least to be prepared to give recognition to the noble work that they are doing in the cause of peace. But no, we get none of that from Senator Vallentine.

Let me tell Senator Vallentine how on Tuesday and Wednesday of one week they were ordered to go and by the Sunday they were on their way. Let me ask her just what that would do to a family-with the father being suddenly uprooted from his children and the mother left grieving. There is no other word for it; `grieving' is not too extreme. There is a sense of grief in those circumstances. But wives say to their husbands, `You are a soldier: you must go'. A wife of one of those 15 has a 2 1/2-year-old child and an eight-month-old baby. She has been left on her own. Senator Vallentine does not seem to think that she is worthy of any special care and attention because her husband is a serviceman. She says that those people are not unique and do not fulfil a special place in the life of our country. I deny that utterly.

Those men have been away from Australia for nearly four months and still the Government has not paid them their allowances. I drew the Senate's attention to that in Question Time today. Once again, Senator Richardson was not able to answer my questions. However, my questions demonstrate clearly that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has neglected those men and has not been able or willing to push the bureaucrats along to see that those allowances are paid. If those men are very lucky they might get their allowances by the time they return to Australia.

Senator Vallentine also went on with some nonsense about cadets goosestepping around at the Australian Defence Force Academy. If she knew as much about defence as she pretends to know, she would realise that Australian servicemen do not goosestep. It was a disgraceful exaggeration. She talked of the glamour of the naval review and military tattoos, et cetera. She should realise very well that this is glamour at a price. The cuts which were made by the Government this year in the day to day operating costs of the defence forces will mean that these activities have been undertaken, at the wish of the Government, at the price of the security of the nation. Senator Vallentine reveals by this criticism that she cannot bear to see the hundreds of thousands of Australians who have been turning out to see their Defence Force. One of the major spin-offs, in my opinion, of having these reviews from time to time is that it gives ordinary Australians a chance to see their defence forces at work.

I believe that Australians are proud of their forces. They do not talk about them much. They are not the subject of letters to the newspapers and journalists do not write about them very much. I think Australians on the whole do not even think about them very much, although they like to feel that they are there. They do not want to feel worried about them, but at the first signs of problems in the region or in times of national emergency, such as Ash Wednesday or the Darwin cyclone, Australians turn to their defence forces for help. These are not special people in the defence forces. They are ordinary men and women, but they are doing difficult jobs for us and they are a unique breed in that regard. I am proud of them and I urge this nation and this Government to show that pride to our defence personnel.

I utterly condemn Senator Vallentine for her cynical and disgraceful comments about our forces. On the other hand, I enthusiastically congratulate Mr Manfred Cross and the other members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inquiring into wastage rates because they have brought down an excellent report which the Government will ignore at its peril. Frankly, if I had any chance to do anything about it, so long as we had a Labor government in Canberra I would have Manfred Cross as the Minister for Defence. He, of all the members of this Government, knows enough about the subject to see that defence personnel are treated properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to comment on the speeches of honourable senators on the adjournment debate except for that of Senator Tambling. Since I took a point of order during that speech, it at least behoves me to comment a little on Senator Tambling's extraordinary outburst in what I regard as an abuse of this chamber when he defamed an individual quite deliberately. This chamber's strength is that we have parliamentary privilege which enables us to debate matters without let or hindrance, but it does not mean that we should abuse the proceedings and selectively defame individuals who under your ruling, Mr President, certainly have an opportunity to petition you for some protection.
—That is right.

—I do not quite know how they become aware of the fact that they have been defamed when the proceedings are not being broadcast but, nonetheless, I will report Senator Tambling's defamation to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). It should be said that if Senator Tambling wishes to make the wild accusations he has, if he has any self-respect, he ought, at least, to adduce some evidence to justify the accusations that he makes so that at least they can have some credible foundation, whether the foundation be true or not.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling asked a number of questions which raise inferences but do not actually provide any foundational base to make an accusation. That is a well-known ploy in debate. Where it involves an individual's reputation and he has little come-back, I think it is absolutely lamentable. I have no idea whether the individual concerned is guilty of the things that Senator Tambling accuses him of. I do know that if, to quote Senator Tambling, `serious criminal charges are hanging over his head', then he is entitled and will remain entitled-as long as I am a senator in this country and hopefully as long as we have this institution in place-to a presumption of innocence until he is proven guilty, and that he should not be attacked on the basis of an assumption of guilt until he is proven innocent. Yet that was the strong implication that Senator Tambling made. I think it is an example of what we sometimes lament as a misuse of this forum and is one of the reasons why sometimes commentators regard politicians with low esteem. I think that it is entirely regrettable. I think that Senator Tambling should retract some of his comments, if not now, at some other time. I just want to record my reaction to that speech.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
